questions.stem: A new agile team is in their third sprint. The Product Owner wants to add urgent items mid-sprint after the sprint backlog has been committed. The team has capacity concerns. What is the MOST appropriate action?

options.A: Add the items because the PO has final authority over what gets built
options.B: Cancel the current sprint and replan with the new items
options.C: The PO and team negotiate scope, potentially removing lower-priority items to accommodate the urgent work
options.D: Refuse the request because the sprint backlog is locked

questions.correct_text: The PO and team negotiate scope, potentially removing lower-priority items to accommodate the urgent work
questions.explanation: * Agile Manifesto Value 4 prioritises responding to change. However, sprint integrity matters. The correct agile approach is negotiation — the PO and team collaborate to adjust scope while protecting sprint goals. The PO decides WHAT, the team decides HOW MUCH. Simply adding (A) ignores team capacity. Cancellation (B) is extreme. Flat refusal (D) ignores the urgency.

questions.stem: An organisation is evaluating whether to use agile for a new regulatory compliance project. Requirements are well-defined by law, the technology is mature, and the deadline is fixed by regulation. Using the Cynefin framework, which domain does this project fall into?

options.A: Complex
options.B: Complicated
options.C: Simple/Obvious
options.D: Chaotic

questions.correct_text: Complicated
questions.explanation: * Known requirements, mature technology, and clear constraints describe a Complicated domain — the relationship between cause and effect can be determined through analysis. An expert can identify the right approach. Simple/Obvious (C) would mean best practices are self-evident. Complex (A) would mean emergent requirements. This project has knowable answers through expertise, making it Complicated. A traditional or hybrid approach may be more appropriate than pure agile.

questions.stem: A Scrum team has been running sprints for 6 months. The team lead tells the Scrum Master: "We should drop the daily standup because the team communicates well throughout the day." The team is still in the early stages of mastering Scrum. According to Shu-Ha-Ri, what is the BEST response?

options.A: Agree — if the team communicates well, the standup is redundant
options.B: Disagree — explain that the standup serves purposes beyond communication and the team should master Scrum before modifying it
options.C: Compromise — reduce the standup to three times per week
options.D: Escalate to management for a decision

questions.correct_text: Disagree — explain that the standup serves purposes beyond communication and the team should master Scrum before modifying it
questions.explanation: * A team at 6 months of Scrum is still in the Shu stage (follow the rules). The daily standup serves multiple purposes: inspect progress, identify impediments, and create accountability. Before removing any ceremony, the team needs to fully understand WHY it exists. Agreeing (A) enables premature process modification. Compromising (C) still modifies without understanding. Escalation (D) contradicts self-organisation.

questions.stem: During a Sprint Retrospective, only the senior developers speak. Junior team members remain silent even when asked directly. According to Timothy Clark's model, which stage of psychological safety is MOST likely missing?

options.A: Inclusion Safety
options.B: Learner Safety
options.C: Contributor Safety
options.D: Challenger Safety

questions.correct_text: Contributor Safety
questions.explanation: * The junior members are present (Inclusion Safety exists) and presumably feel safe enough to attend meetings (Learner Safety). However, they don't feel safe contributing ideas or opinions in front of seniors. This is a Contributor Safety gap — they don't believe their contributions will be valued. If Inclusion Safety (A) were missing, they wouldn't attend. If Learner Safety (B) were missing, they wouldn't ask questions at all.

questions.stem: Which of the following BEST describes the relationship between agile practices and agile values according to the "Agile Iceberg" metaphor?

options.A: Practices and values are equally visible and equally important
options.B: Values are the visible tip of the iceberg; practices are hidden underneath
options.C: Practices are visible above the waterline; values and mindset are the larger, invisible foundation below
options.D: The iceberg represents the hidden risks in agile projects

questions.correct_text: Practices are visible above the waterline; values and mindset are the larger, invisible foundation below
questions.explanation: * The Agile Iceberg places visible practices (standups, sprints, boards) above the waterline and the larger foundation of principles, values, and mindset below. Most failed agile transformations focus on the visible practices without addressing the invisible foundation. The metaphor illustrates why "doing agile" without "being agile" fails.

questions.stem: A company is transitioning from waterfall to agile. The VP of Engineering asks: "Which single agile framework should ALL our teams use?" What is the MOST agile-aligned response?

options.A: SAFe, because it provides the most comprehensive structure for enterprise adoption
options.B: Scrum, because it is the most widely adopted agile framework
options.C: It depends on the team's context, project type, and domain complexity — different teams may need different approaches
options.D: Kanban, because it requires the least change from existing processes

questions.correct_text: It depends on the team's context, project type, and domain complexity — different teams may need different approaches
questions.explanation: * One of the core agile principles is that context matters. The Agile Suitability Filter and Cynefin framework both teach that different situations demand different approaches. Mandating one framework for all teams contradicts agile thinking. The correct approach is to assess each team's context and select (or combine) frameworks accordingly.

questions.stem: In Extreme Programming (XP), which practice involves writing tests BEFORE writing the code that satisfies them?

options.A: Continuous Integration
options.B: Test-Driven Development (TDD)
options.C: Pair Programming
options.D: Refactoring

questions.correct_text: Test-Driven Development (TDD)
questions.explanation: * TDD follows the Red-Green-Refactor cycle: (1) Write a failing test (Red), (2) Write the minimum code to pass the test (Green), (3) Refactor the code while keeping tests green. This is distinct from Continuous Integration (automated builds), Pair Programming (two developers, one machine), and Refactoring (restructuring without changing behaviour).

questions.stem: A product development team uses Kanban. Their board shows the following WIP: "To Do: 15, In Progress: 8, Code Review: 6, Testing: 3, Done: 20." The team's WIP limit for "In Progress" is 5. What is the FIRST action the team should take?

options.A: Move 3 items from "In Progress" back to "To Do"
options.B: Stop pulling new items into "In Progress" and focus on completing current work or helping downstream
options.C: Increase the WIP limit to 8 since the team clearly has capacity
options.D: Add more developers to handle the excess work

questions.correct_text: Stop pulling new items into "In Progress" and focus on completing current work or helping downstream
questions.explanation: * When WIP exceeds the limit, the team should stop starting new work and focus on finishing work in progress. This is the fundamental Kanban principle of "stop starting, start finishing." Moving items back (A) hides the problem. Increasing the limit (C) defeats the purpose of WIP limits. Adding resources (D) doesn't address the flow problem.

questions.stem: According to the Agile Manifesto, which of the following statements is TRUE?

options.A: Documentation has no value in agile projects
options.B: Working software is valued more than comprehensive documentation, but documentation still has value
options.C: Plans should never be created in agile projects
options.D: Contracts should be avoided entirely in agile environments

questions.correct_text: Working software is valued more than comprehensive documentation, but documentation still has value
questions.explanation: * The Manifesto states "we value [left items] OVER [right items]" — not "instead of." This is the most commonly misunderstood aspect. Documentation, processes, contracts, and plans all have value. The Manifesto establishes a priority ordering, not an either/or choice. When forced to choose, lean toward the left side.

questions.stem: A Scrum team wants to improve their estimation accuracy. They currently estimate in hours, which leads to arguments about individual productivity. Which estimation technique would BEST address this problem?

options.A: Planning Poker using story points
options.B: More detailed task breakdowns in hours
options.C: Having the project manager estimate for the team
options.D: Tracking actual hours and adjusting estimates accordingly

questions.correct_text: Planning Poker using story points
questions.explanation: * Story points measure relative complexity/effort, not individual time. This removes arguments about "it takes ME 4 hours but YOU 8 hours." Planning Poker adds structured discussion and consensus-building. More detailed hour estimates (B) worsen the problem. Manager estimation (C) contradicts self-organisation. Tracking actuals (D) is useful but doesn't fix the estimation approach.

questions.stem: The Stacey Matrix plots two dimensions to determine project approach. What are these two dimensions?

options.A: Cost and Schedule
options.B: Requirements Certainty and Technology Certainty
options.C: Team Size and Project Duration
options.D: Risk and Complexity

questions.correct_text: Requirements Certainty and Technology Certainty
questions.explanation: * The Stacey Matrix evaluates how well-understood the requirements are (close to certainty vs. far from certainty) and how well-understood the technology is. Projects close to certainty on both axes suit predictive approaches. Projects far from certainty on both axes suit agile or complex adaptive approaches.

questions.stem: An agile coach observes that a Scrum team's Daily Standup consistently runs 30+ minutes with detailed technical discussions. What is the BEST advice?

options.A: Extend the timebox to 30 minutes since the discussions are valuable
options.B: Limit each person to answering the three standup questions and take detailed discussions offline
options.C: Cancel the standup since the team communicates throughout the day
options.D: Have the Scrum Master report status instead of hearing from each team member

questions.correct_text: Limit each person to answering the three standup questions and take detailed discussions offline
questions.explanation: * The Daily Scrum is timeboxed to 15 minutes for a reason — it's an inspection and synchronisation event, not a problem-solving session. Detailed technical discussions should happen in "parking lot" or "after-party" conversations with only the relevant people. Extending (A) sets a bad precedent. Cancelling (C) removes the synchronisation mechanism. SM reporting (D) is not agile.

questions.stem: Which Lean principle focuses on eliminating activities that consume resources but create no value?

options.A: Build Quality In
options.B: Eliminate Waste
options.C: Deliver Fast
options.D: Optimise the Whole

questions.correct_text: Eliminate Waste
questions.explanation: * The 7 Lean Wastes (adapted from manufacturing: Muda) include: Partially Done Work, Extra Processes, Extra Features, Task Switching, Waiting, Motion/Handoffs, and Defects. Eliminating waste means removing activities that consume time, effort, or resources without adding value to the customer.

questions.stem: An organisation has adopted SAFe. During PI Planning, a team identifies a significant dependency on another team that could block 40% of their planned work. What should happen?

options.A: The team should plan around the dependency and hope it resolves itself
options.B: The dependency should be visualised on the program board and both teams should agree on a resolution plan
options.C: The Release Train Engineer should assign the work to the other team
options.D: The team should reduce their PI objectives by 40%

questions.correct_text: The dependency should be visualised on the program board and both teams should agree on a resolution plan
questions.explanation: * PI Planning exists precisely to identify and manage cross-team dependencies. The program board makes dependencies visible. Both teams must collaborate to plan around or resolve the dependency. Ignoring it (A) creates risk. The RTE facilitates, not assigns (C). Reducing objectives (D) is premature — first try to resolve the dependency.

questions.stem: Which of the following is NOT a core role in the Scrum framework?

options.A: Scrum Master
options.B: Product Owner
options.C: Project Manager
options.D: Development Team

questions.correct_text: Project Manager
questions.explanation: * Scrum defines three roles: Product Owner (WHAT to build), Development Team (HOW to build), and Scrum Master (process facilitation and impediment removal). There is no Project Manager role in Scrum. Many organisations struggle with this transition, often relabelling PMs as Scrum Masters without changing the underlying command-and-control behaviour.

questions.stem: A team practising Scrum delivers working software every 2 weeks. However, they never release to production — all features are held until a quarterly release. Which Agile Manifesto principle is being violated?

options.A: Principle 1: Satisfy the customer through early and continuous delivery of valuable software
options.B: Principle 8: The best architectures emerge from self-organising teams
options.C: Principle 11: Continuous attention to technical excellence
options.D: Principle 12: Simplicity

questions.correct_text: Principle 1: Satisfy the customer through early and continuous delivery of valuable software
questions.explanation: * While the team delivers working increments every sprint, holding releases until quarterly denies the customer early value. Principle 1 emphasises "early and continuous delivery." Working software in a staging environment is not the same as delivered value. This is a common anti-pattern in organisations that adopt Scrum ceremonies without changing their release process.

questions.stem: What distinguishes Disciplined Agile (DA) from other scaling frameworks?

options.A: It is the most prescriptive framework, providing detailed instructions for every situation
options.B: It is a toolkit that helps teams choose their "Way of Working" based on context
options.C: It only works for teams of 3-9 people
options.D: It requires all teams to use Scrum as the base framework

questions.correct_text: It is a toolkit that helps teams choose their "Way of Working" based on context
questions.explanation: * DA distinguishes itself by being a process decision toolkit, not a prescriptive framework. It uses "process goal diagrams" and decision trees to help teams choose the best practices for their specific context. It recognises that one size does not fit all and embraces a "choose your WoW" (Way of Working) approach. DA is now owned by PMI.

questions.stem: A servant leader observes that one team member is consistently interrupted by stakeholders making ad-hoc requests. What is the MOST appropriate servant leadership action?

options.A: Tell the stakeholders to stop interrupting the team
options.B: Create a process that channels stakeholder requests through the Product Owner and shield the team from direct interruptions
options.C: Add the stakeholder requests to the sprint backlog immediately
options.D: Ask the team member to manage the interruptions better

questions.correct_text: Create a process that channels stakeholder requests through the Product Owner and shield the team from direct interruptions
questions.explanation: * Servant leadership involves shielding the team from distractions while maintaining positive stakeholder relationships. Creating a proper channel (through the PO) respects both the team's focus and the stakeholder's needs. Being confrontational (A) damages relationships. Adding unplanned work (C) disrupts the sprint. Putting it on the team member (D) is not servant leadership.

questions.stem: In a Kanban system, what is the PRIMARY purpose of WIP (Work in Progress) limits?

options.A: To limit the number of people who can work on a task simultaneously
options.B: To expose bottlenecks and improve flow by preventing the team from starting too many items at once
options.C: To reduce the team's workload so they can leave early
options.D: To create a ranking system for task priority

questions.correct_text: To expose bottlenecks and improve flow by preventing the team from starting too many items at once
questions.explanation: * WIP limits are the fundamental mechanism of Kanban flow optimisation. By limiting how many items can be in each stage simultaneously, bottlenecks become visible (work queues up before the bottleneck), and the team is forced to finish work before starting new work. This improves flow, reduces cycle time, and makes problems visible.

questions.stem: An agile team is working in the Complex domain (per Cynefin). Which approach is MOST appropriate?

options.A: Sense-Categorise-Respond (apply best practices)
options.B: Sense-Analyse-Respond (apply good practices through expert analysis)
options.C: Probe-Sense-Respond (experiment, observe results, then decide)
options.D: Act-Sense-Respond (take immediate action to stabilise)

questions.correct_text: Probe-Sense-Respond
questions.explanation: * In the Complex domain, cause and effect can only be determined in retrospect. The approach is to Probe (try something small), Sense (observe the results), and Respond (amplify what works, dampen what doesn't). This is exactly what agile iterations do: build a small increment, get feedback, adapt. Sense-Categorise (A) is for Simple. Sense-Analyse (B) is for Complicated. Act-Sense (D) is for Chaotic.

questions.stem: A Product Owner is writing user stories for a new feature. Which of the following user stories BEST follows the INVEST criteria?

options.A: "Implement the payment system"
options.B: "As a returning customer, I want to save my payment method so that I can check out faster on future purchases"
options.C: "The system shall process credit card payments securely using PCI-DSS compliant encryption"
options.D: "Build the shopping cart module by March 15"

questions.correct_text: "As a returning customer, I want to save my payment method so that I can check out faster on future purchases"
questions.explanation: * INVEST: Independent, Negotiable, Valuable, Estimable, Small, Testable. Option B follows the "As a [user], I want [goal] so that [benefit]" format, is user-focused, provides clear value, is negotiable (the team can decide implementation), and is testable (can you save a payment method? yes/no). Option A is an epic, not a story. C is a technical specification, not negotiable. D is a task with a deadline, not a user story.

questions.stem: A team has completed 5 sprints with the following velocity: 28, 32, 30, 35, 25. The product backlog contains 180 remaining story points. Using average velocity, how many sprints will it take to complete the backlog?

options.A: 5 sprints
options.B: 6 sprints
options.C: 7 sprints
options.D: 8 sprints

questions.correct_text: 6 sprints
questions.explanation: * Average velocity = (28+32+30+35+25) / 5 = 150/5 = 30 points per sprint. Remaining backlog = 180 points. Sprints needed = 180/30 = 6 sprints. Note: In practice, you would present a range (best case using highest velocity 35 = 5.1 sprints ≈ 6; worst case using lowest velocity 25 = 7.2 sprints ≈ 8). Average gives 6 sprints.

questions.stem: A stakeholder demands that all 50 backlog items be delivered in the next release. The team's velocity supports delivering only 30 items. Which prioritisation technique would be MOST helpful in negotiating scope?

options.A: Fibonacci sequence
options.B: MoSCoW prioritisation
options.C: Wideband Delphi
options.D: T-shirt sizing

questions.correct_text: MoSCoW prioritisation
questions.explanation: * MoSCoW (Must have, Should have, Could have, Won't have) directly addresses scope negotiation by categorising items into priority tiers. This helps the stakeholder understand that not all items are equal — some are Must-haves for the release, others can wait. Fibonacci (A) and T-shirt sizing (D) are estimation techniques, not prioritisation. Wideband Delphi (C) is also an estimation technique.

questions.stem: A team is using AgileEVM. Given: BAC = $200,000. The project has 200 total story points. After 4 of 10 planned sprints, the team has completed 90 story points and spent $95,000. What is the Cost Performance Index (CPI)?
questions.explanation:
*
- EV (Earned Value) = BAC × (Actual % complete) = $200,000 × (90/200) = $200,000 × 0.45 = $90,000
- AC (Actual Cost) = $95,000
- CPI = EV / AC = $90,000 / $95,000 = 0.947
CPI < 1 means the project is over budget (spending more than earning). For every $1 spent, only $0.947 of value is earned.

questions.stem: Using the Kano model, a customer survey reveals that a search feature is expected by 95% of users and its absence causes significant dissatisfaction, but its presence doesn't generate excitement. How should this feature be classified?

options.A: Performance (Linear)
options.B: Threshold (Must-Be/Basic)
options.C: Exciter/Delighter
options.D: Indifferent

questions.correct_text: Threshold (Must-Be/Basic)
questions.explanation: * Threshold features are expected — their absence causes dissatisfaction, but their presence is taken for granted (doesn't generate excitement). This matches the description: 95% expect it, absence causes dissatisfaction, presence doesn't excite. Performance features (A) have proportional satisfaction. Exciters (C) generate unexpected delight. Indifferent (D) features don't affect satisfaction either way.

questions.stem: What is the PRIMARY difference between an MVP (Minimum Viable Product) and an MBI (Minimum Business Increment)?

options.A: MVP is smaller than MBI
options.B: MVP tests a hypothesis in the market; MBI delivers the smallest unit of actual business value
options.C: MVP is used in Scrum; MBI is used in Kanban
options.D: There is no meaningful difference — they are synonyms

questions.correct_text: MVP tests a hypothesis in the market; MBI delivers the smallest unit of actual business value
questions.explanation: * An MVP is an experiment — it tests whether a product idea has market viability. It might not be a "real" product yet. An MBI is the smallest increment that delivers measurable business value and can be released to production. An MVP might lead to an MBI. They serve different purposes at different stages of product development.

questions.stem: A team is planning their next sprint. They have 8 user stories to discuss. The Product Owner wants quick relative estimates. Which estimation technique is MOST efficient for this situation?

options.A: Bottom-up estimation with task decomposition
options.B: Parametric estimation using historical data
options.C: Affinity estimation (grouping into size buckets)
options.D: Three-point estimation (optimistic, most likely, pessimistic)

questions.correct_text: Affinity estimation
questions.explanation: * Affinity estimation is the fastest technique for relative sizing. Stories are silently sorted into size groups (Small, Medium, Large, XL) without detailed discussion. It's ideal when you need quick estimates for multiple items. Bottom-up (A) is detailed and slow. Parametric (B) requires historical data models. Three-point (D) is time-consuming for 8 stories.

questions.stem: In WSJF (Weighted Shortest Job First), how is the priority score calculated?

options.A: WSJF = Duration / Cost of Delay
options.B: WSJF = Cost of Delay / Duration (or Job Size)
options.C: WSJF = Business Value × Time Criticality
options.D: WSJF = Risk / Effort

questions.correct_text: WSJF = Cost of Delay / Duration (or Job Size)
questions.explanation: * WSJF divides Cost of Delay (how much value is lost per unit of time the feature isn't delivered) by Duration (or Job Size). This produces a priority score that favours items with high cost of delay and short duration. Items with the highest WSJF score should be done first. This comes from Don Reinertsen's work and is prominent in SAFe.

questions.stem: A Cumulative Flow Diagram (CFD) shows that the "Testing" band is widening over the last 5 sprints while other bands remain constant. What does this indicate?

options.A: The testing team is becoming more efficient
options.B: There is a growing bottleneck in testing — work is accumulating faster than it's being completed
options.C: The team is delivering more features
options.D: Quality is improving

questions.correct_text: There is a growing bottleneck in testing — work is accumulating faster than it's being completed
questions.explanation: * On a CFD, a widening band indicates that work is entering that stage faster than it's leaving. If the Testing band is widening, items are queuing up in testing — this is a bottleneck. The team should investigate: Are there enough testers? Is test automation insufficient? Are stories too large to test efficiently? A narrowing band would indicate improvement.

questions.stem: A sprint burndown chart shows that the ideal trend line reaches zero on day 10, but the actual line is significantly above the ideal line on day 7. What does this MOST likely indicate?

options.A: The team is ahead of schedule
options.B: The team is behind schedule and unlikely to complete all sprint backlog items
options.C: The team has completed all work early
options.D: The sprint should be extended by 3 days

questions.correct_text: The team is behind schedule and unlikely to complete all sprint backlog items
questions.explanation: * On a burndown chart, the actual line should track at or below the ideal line. If actual is significantly above ideal on day 7 of a 10-day sprint, remaining work is higher than expected — the team is behind. The team should discuss in the daily scrum: Can they still meet the sprint goal? Should scope be renegotiated with the PO? Sprint extension (D) violates the timebox principle.

questions.stem:
A project has three investment options. Which metric would BEST determine which option returns value fastest?

| Option | Investment | Year 1 Return | Year 2 Return | Year 3 Return |
|--------|-----------|---------------|---------------|---------------|
| A | $100,000 | $40,000 | $40,000 | $40,000 |
| B | $80,000 | $50,000 | $30,000 | $20,000 |
| C | $120,000 | $20,000 | $50,000 | $80,000 |

options.A: ROI (Return on Investment)
options.B: NPV (Net Present Value)
options.C: IRR (Internal Rate of Return)
options.D: Payback Period

questions.correct_text: Payback Period
questions.explanation: * The question specifically asks about returning value "fastest." Payback Period measures how quickly the initial investment is recovered. Option B recovers its $80,000 investment in approximately 1.5 years (fastest). ROI (A), NPV (B), and IRR (C) measure total returns and profitability, not speed of recovery.

questions.stem: What is a Definition of Ready (DoR)?

options.A: A checklist that defines when a sprint is complete
options.B: A set of criteria that a user story must meet BEFORE it can be pulled into a sprint
options.C: A checklist that defines when the product is ready for release
options.D: A set of criteria that the development environment must meet before coding begins

questions.correct_text: A set of criteria that a user story must meet BEFORE it can be pulled into a sprint
questions.explanation: * The Definition of Ready ensures that user stories are sufficiently refined before entering a sprint. Typical DoR criteria: clear acceptance criteria, estimated, small enough to complete in a sprint, no blockers, mockups reviewed. It prevents teams from pulling in poorly defined work. Definition of Done (A, C) addresses completion criteria. D is not a standard agile concept.

questions.stem: An agile team is considering contracting with an external vendor. The project scope is highly uncertain and will evolve significantly. Which agile contracting model is MOST appropriate?

options.A: Fixed Price
options.B: Time and Materials
options.C: Graduated Fixed Price
options.D: "Money for Nothing and Change for Free"

questions.correct_text: Graduated Fixed Price
questions.explanation: * With highly uncertain scope, Fixed Price (A) creates conflict when changes occur. Pure Time and Materials (B) gives the client no cost predictability. Graduated Fixed Price starts with a higher price per iteration to cover initial risk and uncertainty, then reduces over time as scope becomes clearer. "Money for Nothing" (D) is about early termination rights, not scope uncertainty.

questions.stem: A team practices Planning Poker. Three developers show cards: 5, 8, and 13. What should happen NEXT?

options.A: Take the average (8.67) and round to 8
options.B: Use the highest estimate (13) for safety
options.C: The highest and lowest estimators explain their reasoning, then the team re-estimates
options.D: The Scrum Master decides the final estimate

questions.correct_text: The highest and lowest estimators explain their reasoning, then the team re-estimates
questions.explanation: * Planning Poker's value lies in the discussion, not the numbers. When estimates diverge significantly, the highest and lowest estimators explain their reasoning — this often reveals hidden complexity or misunderstandings. Then the team re-estimates. Averaging (A) loses the discussion benefit. Using the highest (B) is overly conservative. SM deciding (D) contradicts team ownership.

questions.stem: Using AgileEVM, if EV = $80,000, PV = $100,000, and AC = $90,000, what can you conclude?

options.A: The project is ahead of schedule and under budget
options.B: The project is behind schedule and over budget
options.C: The project is behind schedule but under budget
options.D: The project is ahead of schedule but over budget

questions.correct_text: The project is behind schedule and over budget
questions.explanation:
*
- SV (Schedule Variance) = EV - PV = $80,000 - $100,000 = -$20,000 (negative = behind schedule)
- CV (Cost Variance) = EV - AC = $80,000 - $90,000 = -$10,000 (negative = over budget)
Both variances are negative, meaning less value has been earned than planned (behind schedule) and more has been spent than earned (over budget).

questions.stem: Which of the following is the BEST example of a spike?

options.A: A high-priority user story that must be delivered this sprint
options.B: A timeboxed research task to investigate an unknown technology before committing to a user story
options.C: An urgent production bug that needs immediate fixing
options.D: A task to refactor existing code for better performance

questions.correct_text: A timeboxed research task to investigate an unknown technology before committing to a user story
questions.explanation: * A spike is a timeboxed investigation or research activity. Its purpose is to reduce uncertainty — the team doesn't know enough to estimate or implement a story, so they spend a fixed amount of time learning. Spikes produce knowledge, not deployable features. User stories (A), bug fixes (C), and refactoring (D) all produce deliverable outcomes.

questions.stem:
A Product Owner is deciding between two features using the following data:

| Feature | User Value | Time Criticality | Risk Reduction | Job Size |
|---------|-----------|-------------------|----------------|----------|
| Feature A | 8 | 5 | 3 | 8 |
| Feature B | 5 | 8 | 5 | 3 |

Using WSJF, which feature should be prioritised?

options.A: Feature A (WSJF = 2.0)
options.B: Feature B (WSJF = 6.0)
options.C: Both have equal WSJF
options.D: Cannot be determined from this data

questions.correct_text: Feature B (WSJF = 6.0)
questions.explanation:
*
- WSJF = Cost of Delay / Job Size
- Cost of Delay = User Value + Time Criticality + Risk Reduction
- Feature A: CoD = 8+5+3 = 16. WSJF = 16/8 = 2.0
- Feature B: CoD = 5+8+5 = 18. WSJF = 18/3 = 6.0
Feature B has a much higher WSJF (6.0 vs 2.0) and should be prioritised. Even though Feature A has higher user value, Feature B's small size and high time criticality make it the better economic choice.

questions.stem: Which type of burndown/burnup chart BEST reveals scope changes during a project?

options.A: Sprint burndown chart
options.B: Release burnup chart
options.C: Cumulative flow diagram
options.D: Velocity chart

questions.correct_text: Release burnup chart
questions.explanation: * A burnup chart shows two lines: work completed (going up) and total scope (may go up or stay flat). When scope increases, the total scope line moves upward, making scope changes immediately visible. Burndown charts (A) only show remaining work — scope changes are invisible (the line jumps up ambiguously). CFDs (C) show flow, not scope. Velocity charts (D) show throughput.

questions.stem: The "Monopoly Money" prioritisation technique works by:

options.A: Giving each stakeholder fake currency to distribute across features, revealing priority through investment patterns
options.B: Assigning dollar values to each user story based on projected revenue
options.C: Having the team bid on user stories they want to work on
options.D: Calculating the cost of each feature and ordering by cheapest first

questions.correct_text: Giving each stakeholder fake currency to distribute across features, revealing priority through investment patterns
questions.explanation: * Monopoly Money gives stakeholders a fixed budget of fake currency to distribute across proposed features. The distribution reveals true priorities — features with the most "money" are highest priority. This technique engages stakeholders actively in prioritisation and surfaces disagreements between stakeholder groups (who invest differently).

questions.stem: A team has the following AgileEVM data: BAC = $150,000, EV = $60,000, AC = $70,000, CPI = 0.857. What is the Estimate at Completion (EAC)?
questions.explanation:
*
- ETC (Estimate to Complete) = (BAC - EV) / CPI = ($150,000 - $60,000) / 0.857 = $90,000 / 0.857 = $104,999 ≈ $105,000
- EAC (Estimate at Completion) = AC + ETC = $70,000 + $105,000 = $175,000
The project is expected to cost $175,000 — $25,000 over the original budget of $150,000.

questions.stem: During a Sprint Review, the Product Owner notices that only 3 of 12 stakeholders attended. What should the Scrum Team address FIRST?

options.A: Send a summary email to absent stakeholders
options.B: Investigate why stakeholders aren't attending and redesign the review to increase engagement
options.C: Cancel future Sprint Reviews until stakeholder attendance improves
options.D: Have the Product Owner present the increment to each stakeholder individually

questions.correct_text: Investigate why stakeholders aren't attending and redesign the review to increase engagement
questions.explanation: * Low attendance signals a stakeholder engagement problem. The team should investigate root causes (is the review boring? wrong time? stakeholders don't see value?) and redesign. Emails (A) are push communication — not collaborative. Cancelling (C) removes the feedback mechanism. Individual presentations (D) are inefficient and eliminate group discussion.

questions.stem: A team is in the "Storming" phase of Tuckman's model. Team members are challenging the Scrum Master's authority and disagreeing about technical approaches. What is the MOST appropriate leadership action?

options.A: Establish clear authority and enforce compliance
options.B: Acknowledge the conflict as normal, facilitate constructive dialogue, and help the team establish shared norms
options.C: Remove the most disruptive team member
options.D: Skip to "Performing" by assigning clear roles and responsibilities

questions.correct_text: Acknowledge the conflict as normal, facilitate constructive dialogue, and help the team establish shared norms
questions.explanation: * Storming is a NORMAL and necessary phase of team development. The leader should normalise the conflict, facilitate healthy discussion, and guide the team toward shared agreements. Enforcing compliance (A) suppresses necessary growth. Removing members (C) avoids the development process. You cannot skip stages (D) — teams must work through Storming to reach Norming.

questions.stem: A Scrum Master notices a team member consistently working overtime to meet sprint commitments. The team member hasn't raised this as a concern. Which Goleman EI domain should the Scrum Master MOST exercise?

options.A: Self-Awareness
options.B: Self-Management
options.C: Social Awareness
options.D: Relationship Management

questions.correct_text: Social Awareness
questions.explanation: * Social Awareness involves perceiving and understanding others' emotions and situations — even when they don't explicitly communicate them. The SM needs to recognise the unspoken struggle. Self-Awareness (A) and Self-Management (B) are about the SM's own emotions. Relationship Management (D) would come after recognising the situation. First, the SM must notice and understand what's happening.

questions.stem: A Product Owner creates three personas for a B2B project management tool. Which element is MOST critical to include in each persona?

options.A: The persona's favourite colour and hobbies
options.B: The persona's goals, frustrations, and decision-making context related to the product
options.C: A detailed biography of the persona's education and career history
options.D: The persona's social media usage patterns

questions.correct_text: The persona's goals, frustrations, and decision-making context related to the product
questions.explanation: * Personas must capture what's relevant to the product: what the user wants to accomplish (goals), what blocks them (frustrations), and how they make decisions in the product context. While demographics and background add colour, goals and pain points drive product decisions. Favourite colours (A) and social media (D) are irrelevant. Full biographies (C) add noise without value.

questions.stem: A team is at Speed Leas' Conflict Level 3 (Contest). What characterises this level?

options.A: The disagreement is about a specific issue and can be resolved through dialogue
options.B: Team members have formed factions and the goal has shifted from solving the problem to winning the argument
options.C: The conflict is so severe that separation of the parties is the only option
options.D: There is mild tension but no visible conflict

questions.correct_text: Team members have formed factions and the goal has shifted from solving the problem to winning the argument
questions.explanation: * At Level 3 (Contest), the conflict shifts from problem-solving to winning. Factions form, positions harden, and the original issue becomes secondary to "being right." Level 1 (Problem to Solve) is dialogue-based (A). Level 5 (Intractable) requires separation (C). Level 1-2 might involve mild tension (D). Level 3 is the tipping point where collaboration becomes difficult.

questions.stem: An information radiator is BEST described as:

options.A: A detailed project status report distributed weekly via email
options.B: A highly visible display placed where the team and stakeholders can passively absorb information
options.C: A password-protected dashboard accessible only to the project team
options.D: A formal presentation given at each Sprint Review

questions.correct_text: A highly visible display placed where the team and stakeholders can passively absorb information
questions.explanation: * Information radiators (Alistair Cockburn) are large, visible displays placed in common areas so that anyone passing by can absorb information without actively seeking it. They "radiate" information passively. Email reports (A) require active reading. Password-protected tools (C) limit access. Formal presentations (D) are scheduled events, not passive information sharing.

questions.stem: According to Herzberg's Two-Factor Theory, which of the following is a MOTIVATOR (not a hygiene factor)?

options.A: Salary increase
options.B: Better office facilities
options.C: Recognition for achievement
options.D: Job security

questions.correct_text: Recognition for achievement
questions.explanation: * Herzberg distinguishes motivators (which create satisfaction) from hygiene factors (which prevent dissatisfaction). Motivators: achievement, recognition, work itself, responsibility, growth, advancement. Hygiene factors: salary, conditions, security, company policy, supervision, relationships. Salary (A), facilities (B), and job security (D) are all hygiene factors.

questions.stem: The Thomas-Kilmann model identifies 5 conflict modes. A Scrum Master faces a situation where two team members disagree on a technical approach, but both have valid points and the decision needs to incorporate both perspectives for the best solution. Which TKI mode is MOST appropriate?

options.A: Competing
options.B: Avoiding
options.C: Compromising
options.D: Collaborating

questions.correct_text: Collaborating
questions.explanation: * When both parties have valid perspectives and the best solution requires integrating both, Collaborating is ideal — it seeks a win-win by finding a solution that satisfies both concerns. Competing (A) means one wins. Avoiding (B) delays resolution. Compromising (C) means both parties give something up — acceptable when a win-win isn't possible, but not the best choice when integration IS possible.

questions.stem: Design the Product Box is a technique where stakeholders create a mock product box. What is its PRIMARY purpose?

options.A: To design the product's packaging for retail sale
options.B: To collaboratively define and communicate the product vision by highlighting key benefits and differentiators
options.C: To estimate the product's market price
options.D: To create marketing materials for the sales team

questions.correct_text: To collaboratively define and communicate the product vision by highlighting key benefits and differentiators
questions.explanation: * Design the Product Box is an Innovation Game that engages stakeholders in defining what makes the product compelling. Teams create a physical (or virtual) box highlighting features, benefits, and differentiators — forcing them to articulate the product's core value proposition. It's a vision alignment tool, not a packaging, pricing, or marketing exercise.

questions.stem: A team has been performing well for 8 months. A key team member leaves and a new person joins. According to Tuckman's model, what is MOST likely to happen?

options.A: The team continues performing at the same level
options.B: The team reverts to an earlier stage (likely Forming or Storming) as it adjusts to the new dynamic
options.C: The new member immediately performs at the same level as the departed member
options.D: The team should be disbanded and reformed

questions.correct_text: The team reverts to an earlier stage (likely Forming or Storming) as it adjusts to the new dynamic
questions.explanation: * Any significant membership change can cause a team to regress in Tuckman's model. The team needs to re-establish norms, integrate the new member, and re-form as a unit. This doesn't mean going all the way back to early Forming, but some degree of regression is expected. Assuming continuity (A) ignores group dynamics. Immediate performance (C) is unrealistic. Disbanding (D) is extreme.

questions.stem: Which communication technique is MOST effective for resolving misunderstandings between the development team and a non-technical stakeholder?

options.A: Send a detailed technical specification document
options.B: Use visual models (wireframes, prototypes, or diagrams) to create shared understanding
options.C: Have the tech lead explain the technical constraints in a meeting
options.D: Ask the stakeholder to attend a sprint planning session

questions.correct_text: Use visual models (wireframes, prototypes, or diagrams) to create shared understanding
questions.explanation: * Visual models bridge the communication gap between technical and non-technical stakeholders. Wireframes, prototypes, and diagrams create shared understanding without requiring technical knowledge. Technical documents (A) won't be understood. Tech lead explanations (C) may still use jargon. Sprint planning (D) is an internal team event, not designed for stakeholder education.

questions.stem: According to Daniel Pink's Drive model, what are the three elements of intrinsic motivation?

options.A: Money, Status, Power
options.B: Autonomy, Mastery, Purpose
options.C: Safety, Belonging, Esteem
options.D: Challenge, Reward, Recognition

questions.correct_text: Autonomy, Mastery, Purpose
questions.explanation: * Pink's Drive model identifies three intrinsic motivators: Autonomy (desire to direct our own lives), Mastery (desire to get better at something that matters), and Purpose (desire to do what we do in service of something larger than ourselves). These drive long-term engagement far more effectively than extrinsic rewards like money or status.

questions.stem: A Scrum Master is coaching a team that consistently avoids difficult conversations in retrospectives. They only discuss "safe" topics and never challenge each other's practices. Using Clark's model, which stage are they struggling to reach?

options.A: Inclusion Safety
options.B: Learner Safety
options.C: Contributor Safety
options.D: Challenger Safety

questions.correct_text: Challenger Safety
questions.explanation: * The team discusses safe topics (they have Inclusion, Learner, and Contributor Safety) but won't challenge each other or the status quo. This is a Challenger Safety gap — they don't feel safe pushing back on established practices or raising uncomfortable truths. The SM should model vulnerability, reward constructive challenge, and create structured formats for surfacing difficult topics.

questions.stem: A new stakeholder joins a project midway and demands to see "the project plan with Gantt charts." The team uses Scrum with a product roadmap and release plan. What is the BEST response?

options.A: Create a Gantt chart to satisfy the stakeholder
options.B: Explain that agile teams don't use plans and the stakeholder should adapt
options.C: Show the product roadmap and release plan, explain how agile planning works, and map it to the stakeholder's need for predictability
options.D: Ask the Product Owner to handle all stakeholder communication

questions.correct_text: Show the product roadmap and release plan, explain how agile planning works, and map it to the stakeholder's need for predictability
questions.explanation: * The stakeholder has a legitimate need for visibility and predictability. The agile team DOES have plans — they're just expressed differently (roadmaps, release plans, backlogs with velocity-based forecasts). The best approach is to meet the stakeholder's underlying need using agile artifacts. Creating a Gantt chart (A) sends mixed signals. Refusing (B) is dismissive. Deflecting (D) avoids the relationship.

questions.stem: When should a Scrum Master use the "Accommodating" conflict mode (Thomas-Kilmann)?

options.A: When the issue is critical and the Scrum Master has the right answer
options.B: When the issue is more important to the other party and preserving the relationship matters more than winning
options.C: When both parties need to compromise equally
options.D: When the conflict should be addressed at a later time

questions.correct_text: When the issue is more important to the other party and preserving the relationship matters more than winning
questions.explanation: * Accommodating means yielding to the other party's position. This is appropriate when the issue matters more to them, when preserving harmony is important, and when the stakes are low for you. It builds goodwill for future negotiations. For critical issues (A), Competing or Collaborating is better. Equal compromise (C) is Compromising. Delaying (D) is Avoiding.

questions.stem: An agile team works in a distributed environment across 3 countries. Which practice would MOST effectively create a sense of shared team identity?

options.A: Sending daily status emails to all members
options.B: Co-creating team working agreements, a team charter, and shared rituals that include all time zones
options.C: Having the project manager set rules for all teams to follow
options.D: Requiring all team members to be online during the same hours

questions.correct_text: Co-creating team working agreements, a team charter, and shared rituals that include all time zones
questions.explanation: * Shared identity comes from co-creation and inclusion. Working agreements and team charters that everyone contributes to create ownership and belonging. Shared rituals (virtual coffee, team celebrations, shared channels) build connection across distances. Status emails (A) are transactional. Manager-imposed rules (C) undermine self-organisation. Same-hours (D) may be impossible across 3 countries.

questions.stem: What is the BEST way to handle a stakeholder who consistently provides feedback AFTER features have been released, rather than during Sprint Reviews?

options.A: Ignore post-release feedback since it wasn't provided during the proper ceremony
options.B: Accept all post-release feedback and add it to the next sprint
options.C: Investigate why the stakeholder doesn't participate in Sprint Reviews and design a more accessible feedback mechanism
options.D: Assign a team member to collect feedback from this stakeholder before each review

questions.correct_text: Investigate why the stakeholder doesn't participate in Sprint Reviews and design a more accessible feedback mechanism
questions.explanation: * The root cause needs investigation. Perhaps the review time doesn't work for them, they don't understand the format, or they need to see the product "in the wild" to give meaningful feedback. Understanding WHY enables a solution. Ignoring (A) loses valuable input. Blindly accepting (B) doesn't fix the timing. Assigning someone (D) treats the symptom, not the cause.

questions.stem: A team member privately tells the Scrum Master that they disagree with the tech lead's architectural decision but are afraid to speak up. The SM should:

options.A: Raise the concern on behalf of the team member at the next team meeting
options.B: Coach the team member on how to raise concerns constructively, and work to strengthen the team's Challenger Safety
options.C: Tell the team member they need to toughen up and speak for themselves
options.D: Speak to the tech lead privately about being more open to feedback

questions.correct_text: Coach the team member on how to raise concerns constructively, and work to strengthen the team's Challenger Safety
questions.explanation: * The SM should coach the individual while simultaneously working to create an environment where people feel safe challenging ideas. Simply raising it for them (A) doesn't build the team member's capability. "Toughen up" (C) dismisses their valid concern about safety. Speaking to the tech lead (D) addresses part of the problem but doesn't empower the team member.

questions.stem: Push communication is appropriate when:

options.A: The team needs to have a discussion about a complex topic
options.B: Information needs to be shared broadly with stakeholders who don't need to respond immediately
options.C: A conflict needs to be resolved between two team members
options.D: The Product Owner needs input on backlog priorities

questions.correct_text: Information needs to be shared broadly with stakeholders who don't need to respond immediately
questions.explanation: * Push communication (emails, reports, newsletters) is for broadcasting information to a wide audience where immediate response isn't needed. Discussions (A) and conflict resolution (C) require interactive (pull) communication. Priority input (D) requires collaborative dialogue. Push communication is efficient for status updates, announcements, and documentation distribution.

questions.stem: A newly formed agile team of 7 has worked together for 2 weeks. They are polite, cautious, and defer to the Scrum Master for all decisions. According to Tuckman, which stage are they MOST likely in?

options.A: Forming
options.B: Storming
options.C: Norming
options.D: Performing

questions.correct_text: Forming
questions.explanation: * Politeness, caution, and deference to authority are hallmarks of Forming. The team is getting to know each other and hasn't yet developed the confidence to challenge or assert themselves. In Storming, they'd be pushing back. In Norming, they'd have established working patterns. In Performing, they'd be self-directing without needing the SM for all decisions.

questions.stem: A team uses Little's Law to analyse their Kanban system. If the average WIP is 12 items and the average throughput is 4 items per day, what is the average cycle time?

options.A: 48 days
options.B: 3 days
options.C: 0.33 days
options.D: 16 days

questions.correct_text: 3 days
questions.explanation: * Little's Law: WIP = Throughput × Cycle Time, therefore Cycle Time = WIP / Throughput = 12 / 4 = 3 days. On average, each item takes 3 days from start to completion. To reduce cycle time, the team can either reduce WIP or increase throughput (which often happens naturally when WIP is reduced).

questions.stem: During a retrospective, the team identifies 8 improvement actions. Only 2 can realistically be addressed in the next sprint. What is the MOST effective approach?

options.A: Attempt all 8 improvements simultaneously
options.B: Prioritise by impact and address the top 2, tracking the remaining 6 for future sprints
options.C: Vote on the most popular 2 and discard the rest
options.D: Assign each improvement to a team member regardless of sprint capacity

questions.correct_text: Prioritise by impact and address the top 2, tracking the remaining 6 for future sprints
questions.explanation: * Improvement work competes with sprint work for capacity. The team should prioritise improvements by impact and feasibility, commit to the most impactful 2, and maintain a visible improvement backlog for the rest. Attempting all 8 (A) creates overload. Discarding (C) loses valuable ideas. Individual assignment (D) ignores capacity constraints and team ownership.

questions.stem: A risk burndown graph shows risk severity INCREASING after Sprint 4 despite the team's mitigation efforts. What does this MOST likely indicate?

options.A: The team's risk mitigation strategies are ineffective or new risks are emerging faster than existing ones are being mitigated
options.B: The graph is incorrectly drawn — risk should always decrease
options.C: The team should stop doing risk management and focus on delivery
options.D: The project should be cancelled immediately

questions.correct_text: The team's risk mitigation strategies are ineffective or new risks are emerging faster than existing ones are being mitigated
questions.explanation: * An increasing risk burndown means either: (1) mitigation isn't working, (2) new risks are being identified faster than old ones are resolved, or (3) residual risks are larger than expected. The team should investigate which scenario applies and adjust their risk strategy. Risk doesn't always decrease (B). Stopping risk management (C) makes it worse. Cancellation (D) is premature.

questions.stem: A team performs a Five Whys analysis on "Sprint goal not met." The answers are: (1) Too many stories left incomplete → (2) Stories were bigger than estimated → (3) Hidden complexity wasn't identified during refinement → (4) The team didn't ask enough clarifying questions during refinement → (5) Team members felt uncomfortable questioning the Product Owner's stories. What is the root cause?

options.A: Stories are too big
options.B: Estimation is inaccurate
options.C: The team lacks psychological safety to challenge the PO during refinement
options.D: The Product Owner writes poor user stories

questions.correct_text: The team lacks psychological safety to challenge the PO during refinement
questions.explanation: * Five Whys drills through symptoms to root causes. Each answer reveals a deeper layer. The ultimate root cause is psychological safety — team members don't feel safe challenging the PO, which means complexity goes unquestioned, estimates are based on incomplete understanding, and sprints fail. Fixing stories (A), estimation (B), or the PO (D) addresses symptoms, not the root cause.

questions.stem: What is the process efficiency formula in Value Stream Mapping?

options.A: Process Efficiency = Total Cycle Time / Value-Added Time
options.B: Process Efficiency = Value-Added Time / Total Cycle Time × 100%
options.C: Process Efficiency = Throughput / WIP
options.D: Process Efficiency = Velocity / Sprint Duration

questions.correct_text: Process Efficiency = Value-Added Time / Total Cycle Time × 100%
questions.explanation: * Process Efficiency = (Value-Added Time / Total Cycle Time) × 100%. If a feature takes 20 days from request to delivery but only 5 days of actual work, process efficiency = (5/20) × 100% = 25%. The remaining 75% is waste (waiting, handoffs, queues). Most organisations operate at 10-25% efficiency, revealing significant improvement opportunity.

questions.stem: A team's velocity over 6 sprints is: 30, 28, 31, 29, 32, 30. The Product Owner asks for a delivery forecast. Using yesterday's weather, what velocity should be used for forecasting?

options.A: 30 (the most recent sprint)
options.B: 32 (the highest velocity achieved)
options.C: 30 (the average of all sprints)
options.D: 28-32 (a range based on lowest to highest)

questions.correct_text: 30 (the average of all sprints)
questions.explanation: * "Yesterday's weather" forecasting uses the average of recent completed sprints as the best predictor. Average = (30+28+31+29+32+30)/6 = 180/6 = 30. While a range (D) provides more honest transparency, the question asks about "yesterday's weather" specifically, which uses average velocity. The most recent (A) or highest (B) alone are unreliable.

questions.stem: Which retrospective format uses the metaphor of a sailing boat with wind, anchors, rocks, and an island?

options.A: Start/Stop/Continue
options.B: 4Ls (Liked, Learned, Lacked, Longed For)
options.C: Sailboat Retrospective
options.D: Mad/Sad/Glad

questions.correct_text: Sailboat Retrospective
questions.explanation: * The Sailboat Retrospective uses: Wind (what's pushing us forward), Anchors (what's holding us back), Rocks (risks ahead), and Island (our destination/goal). This visual metaphor makes abstract concepts concrete and is particularly effective for teams new to retrospectives.

questions.stem: In the Theory of Constraints, what are the 5 Focusing Steps in order?

options.A: Identify → Exploit → Subordinate → Elevate → Repeat
options.B: Plan → Do → Check → Act → Repeat
options.C: Identify → Measure → Analyse → Improve → Control
options.D: Define → Measure → Analyse → Design → Verify

questions.correct_text: Identify → Exploit → Subordinate → Elevate → Repeat
questions.explanation: * Goldratt's 5 Focusing Steps: (1) Identify the constraint, (2) Exploit it (maximise its output without additional investment), (3) Subordinate everything else to the constraint, (4) Elevate the constraint (invest to increase its capacity), (5) If the constraint has moved, go back to Step 1. PDCA (B) is Deming. DMAIC (C) and DMADV (D) are Six Sigma.

questions.stem: A Pareto chart of production defects shows that 3 out of 15 defect categories account for 78% of all defects. Using the Pareto Principle, what should the team focus on?

options.A: Address all 15 categories equally to be thorough
options.B: Focus improvement efforts on the 3 categories that produce the most defects
options.C: Ignore the other 12 categories entirely
options.D: Investigate only the least common defects since they're the most unusual

questions.correct_text: Focus improvement efforts on the 3 categories that produce the most defects
questions.explanation: * The Pareto Principle (80/20 rule) states that roughly 80% of effects come from 20% of causes. By focusing on the 3 dominant categories (20% of categories causing 78% of defects), the team gets maximum improvement for minimum effort. Addressing all equally (A) is inefficient. Ignoring others entirely (C) is extreme. Focusing on rare defects (D) inverts the principle.

questions.stem: A control chart shows that a team's cycle time has been within the upper and lower control limits for 15 sprints, but the last 3 data points are consistently above the mean and trending upward. What type of variation does this represent?

options.A: Common cause variation — no action needed
options.B: Special cause variation — investigate and address
options.C: Random noise — ignore it
options.D: Normal team growth — celebrate

questions.correct_text: Special cause variation
questions.explanation: * While each data point is still within control limits, a consistent trend (3+ points on one side of the mean moving in the same direction) is a signal of special cause variation — something specific has changed. Common cause variation (A) would be random scatter around the mean. The team should investigate what changed after sprint 15 that's increasing cycle time.

questions.stem: In BDD (Behaviour-Driven Development), what is the standard format for writing scenarios?

options.A: Input → Process → Output
options.B: Given → When → Then
options.C: Arrange → Act → Assert
options.D: Setup → Execute → Verify

questions.correct_text: Given → When → Then
questions.explanation: * BDD uses Given-When-Then format: Given (precondition/context), When (action/event), Then (expected outcome). Example: Given a logged-in customer, When they add an item to cart, Then the cart count increases by 1. Arrange-Act-Assert (C) is the unit testing pattern (similar concept, different context). The other options are not standard BDD format.

questions.stem: A team needs to plan a release. They have a prioritised backlog of 200 story points. Their average velocity is 25 points per sprint (2-week sprints). The Product Owner wants to release when 150 must-have points are delivered. How many sprints until the minimum release?

options.A: 6 sprints (12 weeks)
options.B: 8 sprints (16 weeks)
options.C: 5 sprints (10 weeks)
options.D: 7 sprints (14 weeks)

questions.correct_text: 6 sprints (12 weeks)
questions.explanation: * Must-have story points = 150. Average velocity = 25 per sprint. Sprints needed = 150/25 = 6 sprints = 12 weeks. This assumes the must-have items are prioritised first in the backlog (which they should be under MoSCoW). The remaining 50 points of should-have/could-have features would be delivered in subsequent sprints if time permits.

questions.stem: During a pre-mortem exercise, the team imagines the project has failed. The facilitator asks each person to independently write reasons for failure BEFORE group discussion. What is the PRIMARY benefit of this approach?

options.A: It saves time compared to group brainstorming
options.B: It prevents groupthink and ensures diverse perspectives, including concerns people might not raise in group discussion
options.C: It eliminates the need for follow-up discussion
options.D: It ensures the project manager's perspective is included

questions.correct_text: It prevents groupthink and ensures diverse perspectives, including concerns people might not raise in group discussion
questions.explanation: * Independent idea generation before group discussion prevents anchoring bias and groupthink. People who might hesitate to voice concerns in a group will write them down privately. This captures more diverse risks and ensures psychological safety doesn't limit the risk identification. It doesn't save time (A) — discussion follows. It doesn't eliminate discussion (C). It's not about any one person (D).

questions.stem: What is the PRIMARY purpose of a spike in sprint planning?

options.A: To deliver the highest-priority user story
options.B: To timeboxed research that reduces uncertainty and enables better estimation of future stories
options.C: To fix production bugs that were found during the previous sprint
options.D: To refactor code that has accumulated technical debt

questions.correct_text: To timeboxed research that reduces uncertainty and enables better estimation of future stories
questions.explanation: * Spikes are timeboxed research activities designed to reduce uncertainty. When the team can't estimate a story because the technology or approach is unknown, a spike investigates the unknowns. The output is knowledge, not working software. This enables better estimation and informed decisions about future stories.

questions.stem: An escaped defect rate of 15% means:

options.A: 15% of the team's time is spent on defects
options.B: 15% of all defects found were discovered AFTER release to production
options.C: 15% of user stories contain defects
options.D: The team's velocity decreased by 15%

questions.correct_text: 15% of all defects found were discovered AFTER release to production
questions.explanation: * Escaped defect rate measures the percentage of total defects that "escape" the team's testing process and are found by users in production. A rate of 15% means 85% of defects are caught before release. This metric reflects testing effectiveness. A rising escaped defect rate signals that testing practices need improvement.

questions.stem: A CI/CD pipeline should include all of the following EXCEPT:

options.A: Automated unit tests that run on every commit
options.B: Manual approval gate requiring management sign-off before each deployment
options.C: Automated build process triggered by code commits
options.D: Automated integration tests that verify component interactions

questions.correct_text: Manual approval gate requiring management sign-off before each deployment
questions.explanation: * CI/CD emphasises automation to enable frequent, reliable deployments. Manual management approval gates create bottlenecks that contradict CI/CD principles. While some regulated environments require approval gates, these should be minimised and automated where possible. Automated unit tests (A), automated builds (C), and integration tests (D) are core CI/CD components.

questions.stem: A team's Kanban board shows: Backlog: 20, Analysis: 2 (limit 3), Development: 6 (limit 4), Testing: 1 (limit 3), Done: 15. Which column has a WIP violation?

options.A: Backlog
options.B: Analysis
options.C: Development
options.D: Testing

questions.correct_text: Development
questions.explanation: * Development has 6 items but a WIP limit of 4 — this is a violation. All other columns are within limits: Analysis (2 of 3), Testing (1 of 3). Backlog typically doesn't have a WIP limit. The team should stop pulling new work into Development and focus on completing or moving existing items downstream.

questions.stem: The Deming Cycle (PDSA) stands for:

options.A: Plan-Deploy-Study-Adjust
options.B: Plan-Do-Study-Act
options.C: Prepare-Develop-Submit-Approve
options.D: Plan-Design-Standardise-Automate

questions.correct_text: Plan-Do-Study-Act
questions.explanation: * Deming's PDSA cycle: Plan (identify improvement opportunity), Do (implement on small scale), Study (analyse results), Act (adopt, adapt, or abandon based on evidence). This is the foundational model for continuous improvement in agile. Note: Some sources use PDCA (Check instead of Study) — Deming preferred "Study" as it implies deeper analysis.

questions.stem: A fishbone diagram for "Low Sprint Velocity" would categorise causes under which types of headings?

options.A: Past, Present, Future, Unknown
options.B: People, Process, Technology, Environment (and potentially other relevant categories)
options.C: Must Have, Should Have, Could Have, Won't Have
options.D: Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, Threats

questions.correct_text: People, Process, Technology, Environment (and potentially other relevant categories)
questions.explanation: * Fishbone (Ishikawa) diagrams organise causes into categories. Common categories include People, Process, Technology, Environment, Materials, and Methods. For a software team investigating low velocity, relevant categories might be: People (skills, availability), Process (ceremonies, workflow), Technology (tools, infrastructure), Environment (workspace, distractions).

questions.stem: A team is performing value stream mapping and finds: Total time from request to delivery = 40 days. Actual work time = 8 days. What is the process efficiency, and what does it suggest?

options.A: Stop inviting the stakeholder since they've declined multiple times
options.B: Add their feedback to the backlog without discussion since it always leads to changes
options.C: Explore alternative engagement methods (async video demos, one-on-one walkthrough, or attendance at just the demo portion) and negotiate a time-efficient way for them to participate
options.D: Escalate to the stakeholder's manager

questions.correct_text: 20% efficiency
questions.explanation: * Process Efficiency = Value-Added Time / Total Cycle Time = 8/40 = 20%. This means 80% of the total time (32 days) is waste — waiting in queues, handoffs between teams, approvals, etc. This is actually typical for many organisations. The improvement opportunity lies in reducing the 32 days of waste, not in making the 8 days of work go faster.

questions.stem: A new Scrum team is struggling to deliver working increments every Sprint. The Scrum Master notices that developers frequently say, "We've always done it this way" when asked about their workflow. During retrospectives, the team rarely proposes new experiments. Which concept BEST describes the team's current state?

options.A: They are in the "Shu" stage of Shu-Ha-Ri and need strict adherence to Scrum rules
options.B: They are exhibiting "Doing Agile" rather than "Being Agile"
options.C: They are at the "Advanced Beginner" level of the Dreyfus model
options.D: They are experiencing Tuckman's "Storming" stage

questions.correct_text: They are exhibiting "Doing Agile" rather than "Being Agile"
questions.explanation: The team is following processes mechanically without embracing the mindset of continuous improvement and adaptation — the hallmark of the Agile Iceberg concept. "Doing Agile" focuses on ceremonies and artifacts while "Being Agile" embodies the values and principles. Option A describes a natural learning stage but does not capture the resistance to experimentation. Option C is about individual skill, not team mindset. Option D would involve interpersonal conflict, not complacency.

questions.stem: A project manager transitioning to an agile environment asks which of the four Agile Manifesto values addresses the idea that a plan should be a living document rather than something to be rigidly followed. Which value is the project manager referring to?

options.A: Working software over comprehensive documentation
options.B: Individuals and interactions over processes and tools
options.C: Responding to change over following a plan
options.D: Customer collaboration over contract negotiation

questions.correct_text: Responding to change over following a plan
questions.explanation: This value directly addresses the relationship between planning and adaptability. The Agile Manifesto acknowledges there is value in planning but prioritizes the ability to respond to change. Option A deals with deliverables versus documentation. Option B addresses people versus process. Option D concerns stakeholder relationships versus contractual rigidity.

questions.stem: During Sprint Planning, a Product Owner presents a user story: "As a customer, I want to search products by category so I can find items faster." The development team estimates it at 8 story points. The Scrum Master asks the team to break it down further. Which Agile Manifesto principle MOST supports the Scrum Master's suggestion?

options.A: Simplicity — the art of maximizing the amount of work not done — is essential
options.B: Deliver working software frequently, from a couple of weeks to a couple of months
options.C: Business people and developers must work together daily throughout the project
options.D: The best architectures, requirements, and designs emerge from self-organizing teams

questions.correct_text: Simplicity — the art of maximizing the amount of work not done — is essential
questions.explanation: Breaking stories down into smaller increments supports the principle of simplicity by helping the team focus on delivering the most essential functionality first and avoiding unnecessary complexity. Smaller stories also reduce risk and enable faster feedback. Option B addresses delivery cadence. Option C addresses collaboration frequency. Option D addresses team autonomy in design decisions.

questions.stem: A team is working on a product where both the requirements and the technology are well-understood. Stakeholders have a clear vision, and the team has built similar products before. According to the Cynefin framework, which domain does this project MOST LIKELY fall into?

options.A: Complex
options.B: Complicated
options.C: Clear (Simple/Obvious)
options.D: Chaotic

questions.correct_text: Clear (Simple/Obvious)
questions.explanation: When both requirements and technology are well-understood and the relationship between cause and effect is obvious, the project falls into the Clear (formerly Simple/Obvious) domain of Cynefin. The appropriate approach is Sense-Categorize-Respond using established best practices. Complicated would involve knowable but not immediately obvious cause-and-effect. Complex would mean the relationship is only understood in retrospect. Chaotic involves no perceivable cause-and-effect relationship.

questions.stem: An organization is adopting Scrum. A manager asks the Scrum Master, "Who is responsible for deciding how the work gets done?" What is the BEST answer?

options.A: The Product Owner prioritizes the work and decides how it is implemented
options.B: The Scrum Master coaches the team on best practices and assigns tasks
options.C: The Developers are responsible for deciding how to turn backlog items into Increments
options.D: The project sponsor defines the technical approach during Sprint Planning

questions.correct_text: The Developers are responsible for deciding how to turn backlog items into Increments
questions.explanation: In Scrum, the Developers are a self-managing team responsible for deciding how to accomplish the work. The Product Owner decides what to build (ordering the Product Backlog), but the "how" belongs to the Developers. The Scrum Master facilitates and coaches but does not assign tasks. There is no project sponsor role in Scrum.

questions.stem: A team of six developers shares an open workspace. A developer overhears a conversation between two teammates about a design challenge and contributes a solution that resolves the issue within minutes. This interaction BEST illustrates which agile concept?

options.A: Pair programming
options.B: Osmotic communication
options.C: Daily standup effectiveness
options.D: Communities of practice

questions.correct_text: Osmotic communication
questions.explanation: Osmotic communication, a concept from Alistair Cockburn's Crystal methodology, describes how information flows through a co-located team's ambient environment. Team members passively absorb relevant information from nearby conversations and contribute when they have something valuable to add. Pair programming involves two developers working at one workstation. This was not a formal standup. Communities of practice are cross-team groups organized around a domain of interest.

questions.stem: A Scrum team has been working together for four Sprints. Their velocity has stabilized at approximately 30 story points per Sprint. During the current Sprint, the Product Owner asks the team to commit to 45 story points because an important stakeholder wants faster delivery. What should the Scrum Master do FIRST?

options.A: Accept the higher commitment to satisfy the stakeholder
options.B: Protect the team from external pressure and explain sustainable pace to the Product Owner
options.C: Add more developers to the team to increase capacity
options.D: Extend the Sprint length to two weeks to accommodate the additional work

questions.correct_text: Protect the team from external pressure and explain sustainable pace to the Product Owner
questions.explanation: The Agile Manifesto principle states that agile processes promote sustainable development, and sponsors, developers, and users should maintain a constant pace indefinitely. The Scrum Master serves the team by removing impediments, which includes protecting them from unrealistic commitments. Option A undermines team autonomy and sustainable pace. Option C violates Brooks's Law in the short term. Option D changes the Sprint cadence, which disrupts predictability.

questions.stem: Which of the following statements correctly represents the Agile Manifesto's position on items listed on the right side of each value statement?

options.A: Items on the right side have no value and should be eliminated
options.B: Items on the right side have value, but items on the left are valued more
options.C: Items on the right side are only valuable in traditional project management
options.D: Items on the right side are secondary objectives to be addressed after the project ends

questions.correct_text: Items on the right side have value, but items on the left are valued more
questions.explanation: The Agile Manifesto explicitly states: "That is, while there is value in the items on the right, we value the items on the left more." This is a crucial distinction — agile does not reject documentation, contracts, processes, or plans; it simply prioritizes the corresponding left-side items. Options A, C, and D all misrepresent the Manifesto by suggesting the right-side items should be discarded or deferred.

questions.stem: A Product Owner is overwhelmed with feature requests from multiple stakeholders. She asks the Scrum Master for advice on prioritization. The Scrum Master recommends a technique rooted in Lean thinking that focuses on understanding what the customer truly values. Which technique is the Scrum Master MOST LIKELY recommending?

options.A: MoSCoW prioritization
options.B: Value Stream Mapping
options.C: Weighted Shortest Job First (WSJF)
options.D: Kano Model analysis

questions.correct_text: Value Stream Mapping
questions.explanation: Value Stream Mapping is a core Lean technique that helps visualize the flow of value from request to delivery, identifying waste and bottlenecks. It helps the Product Owner understand which activities truly deliver value to the customer. While WSJF is also from Lean/SAFe and is a valid prioritization technique, the question specifically asks about understanding what the customer values, which is the primary purpose of Value Stream Mapping. MoSCoW is a general prioritization method, and Kano is about categorizing features by satisfaction impact.
