questions.stem: A development team practicing Extreme Programming (XP) is debating whether to continue with Test-Driven Development (TDD). A senior developer argues that writing tests before code slows them down. Which response BEST reflects XP philosophy?

options.A: Allow the senior developer to skip TDD since experienced developers can produce quality code without it
options.B: TDD may slow initial coding speed but reduces total cost by catching defects early and improving design
options.C: Replace TDD with code reviews since they achieve the same purpose more efficiently
options.D: Adopt TDD only for complex modules and skip it for straightforward features

questions.correct_text: TDD may slow initial coding speed but reduces total cost by catching defects early and improving design
questions.explanation: TDD is a core XP practice that follows the Red-Green-Refactor cycle. While it may initially appear to slow development, it produces cleaner designs, higher code quality, and significantly reduces the cost of defects found later. XP values technical excellence and understands that cutting technical practices creates technical debt. Option A undermines the team practice. Option C ignores that TDD and code reviews serve different purposes. Option D creates inconsistency in quality standards.

questions.stem:
A team lead is reviewing a Kanban board and notices the following Work-in-Progress (WIP) situation:

| Column       | WIP Limit | Current Items |
|-------------|-----------|---------------|
| To Do       | --        | 12            |
| Development | 4         | 6             |
| Testing     | 3         | 3             |
| Done        | --        | 8             |

What action should the team take FIRST?

options.A: Increase the WIP limit for Development to 6 to match reality
options.B: Stop starting new Development work and help clear the Development bottleneck
options.C: Move two Development items back to the To Do column
options.D: Add more testers to prevent future bottlenecks

questions.correct_text: Stop starting new Development work and help clear the Development bottleneck
questions.explanation: The Development column has exceeded its WIP limit (6 items against a limit of 4). A fundamental Kanban principle is "Stop starting, start finishing." The team should swarm on completing in-progress work rather than pulling new items. Option A defeats the purpose of WIP limits, which are designed to expose bottlenecks. Option C moves work backward, which is wasteful. Option D may be a long-term solution but does not address the immediate WIP violation.

questions.stem: An organization wants to scale agile across 12 teams building a single product. They need coordinated planning, shared architectural vision, and aligned delivery cadences. A consultant recommends a framework that uses Program Increments (PIs), Agile Release Trains (ARTs), and a Program Board. Which scaling framework is the consultant recommending?

options.A: Large-Scale Scrum (LeSS)
options.B: Nexus
options.C: Scaled Agile Framework (SAFe)
options.D: Scrum@Scale

questions.correct_text: Scaled Agile Framework (SAFe)
questions.explanation: SAFe is the scaling framework that specifically uses Program Increments (8-12 week planning cycles), Agile Release Trains (long-lived teams-of-teams aligned to a value stream), and the Program Board (a visual tool for mapping features, dependencies, and milestones across teams during PI Planning). LeSS uses Sprint cycles across teams without ARTs. Nexus uses a Nexus Integration Team. Scrum@Scale uses an Executive Action Team (EAT) and Executive MetaScrum (EMS).

questions.stem: During a retrospective, a team member says, "I have an idea to improve our process, but I'm afraid it might sound stupid." According to Timothy Clark's 4 Stages of Psychological Safety, which stage has this team NOT yet achieved?

options.A: Stage 1: Inclusion Safety
options.B: Stage 2: Learner Safety
options.C: Stage 3: Contributor Safety
options.D: Stage 4: Challenger Safety

questions.correct_text: Stage 3: Contributor Safety
questions.explanation: Clark's 4 Stages of Psychological Safety progress from Inclusion Safety (feeling accepted), to Learner Safety (feeling safe to learn and ask questions), to Contributor Safety (feeling safe to contribute ideas without fear of embarrassment), to Challenger Safety (feeling safe to challenge the status quo). The team member's fear of sounding stupid when contributing an idea indicates Stage 3 has not been established. They clearly feel included and safe to learn but not yet safe to contribute freely.

questions.stem:
A Scrum Master observes the following behaviors in a team:
- The team waits for the Scrum Master to assign tasks during Sprint Planning
- Developers ask the Scrum Master for permission before changing their approach
- The Scrum Master resolves all interpersonal conflicts on behalf of the team

Which BEST describes the Scrum Master's leadership issue?

options.A: The Scrum Master is practicing servant leadership effectively
options.B: The Scrum Master is acting as a command-and-control manager rather than a servant leader
options.C: The Scrum Master is correctly shielding the team from distractions
options.D: The Scrum Master is demonstrating the "Ri" stage of Shu-Ha-Ri mastery

questions.correct_text: The Scrum Master is acting as a command-and-control manager rather than a servant leader
questions.explanation: A servant leader empowers the team to self-manage, facilitates rather than directs, and coaches the team to resolve their own issues. Assigning tasks, requiring permission, and resolving conflicts for the team are all command-and-control behaviors that undermine team autonomy. Option A is the opposite of what is happening. Option C confuses shielding (removing external impediments) with controlling internal decisions. Option D represents mastery and innovation, not dependency.

questions.stem: A newly formed agile team is learning Scrum. The Scrum Master insists the team follow every Scrum rule exactly as prescribed in the Scrum Guide, even when team members suggest modifications. Using the Shu-Ha-Ri model, the Scrum Master's approach is MOST appropriate when?

options.A: The team has been practicing Scrum for over two years
options.B: The team is new to Scrum and needs to build foundational understanding
options.C: The team has mastered Scrum and is ready to innovate
options.D: The team is transitioning from Scrum to Kanban

questions.correct_text: The team is new to Scrum and needs to build foundational understanding
questions.explanation: In the Shu-Ha-Ri model of learning (borrowed from Japanese martial arts), Shu ("obey") is the first stage where practitioners follow rules strictly to build a foundation. This is appropriate for new teams. Ha ("detach") involves breaking rules with understanding, suitable for experienced teams. Ri ("transcend") is for masters who innovate beyond the rules. Option A and C describe teams beyond the Shu stage. Option D is a framework change, not a mastery question.

questions.stem: A team is using the Stacey Matrix to assess a new project. Requirements are highly uncertain — stakeholders disagree on what the product should do. However, the technology is mature and well-understood. Where does this project MOST LIKELY fall on the Stacey Matrix?

options.A: Simple zone — close to agreement and close to certainty
options.B: Complicated zone — close to certainty but far from agreement
options.C: Complex zone — far from both agreement and certainty
options.D: Anarchy/Chaos zone — far from agreement and far from certainty

questions.correct_text: Complicated zone — close to certainty but far from agreement
questions.explanation: The Stacey Matrix plots projects on two axes: agreement (on requirements/goals) and certainty (on technology/approach). High technology certainty but low stakeholder agreement places the project in the Complicated zone. This zone calls for negotiation and political techniques alongside technical approaches. Option A would require high agreement and high certainty. Option C would require uncertainty on both axes. Option D represents the extreme of both dimensions.

questions.stem: An agile coach is evaluating whether a team should use Scrum or Kanban. The team supports a production system with unpredictable incoming work, operates under strict Service Level Agreements (SLAs) for response times, and cannot batch work into time-boxed iterations. Which framework is MOST appropriate?

options.A: Scrum, because its ceremonies provide necessary structure
options.B: Kanban, because it supports continuous flow without time-boxed iterations
options.C: Extreme Programming (XP), because it emphasizes technical excellence
options.D: SAFe, because it provides governance for SLA management

questions.correct_text: Kanban, because it supports continuous flow without time-boxed iterations
questions.explanation: Kanban is ideal for environments with unpredictable, continuous flow of work where time-boxing is impractical. It uses WIP limits to manage flow, explicit policies, and service-level metrics — all well-suited for SLA-driven operations. Scrum requires time-boxed Sprints, which conflict with the team's inability to batch work. XP focuses on engineering practices, not flow management. SAFe is a scaling framework for multiple teams, which is not the issue here.

questions.stem: During PI Planning in a SAFe environment, Team A discovers that one of their features depends on a service that Team B will deliver in the third Sprint of the Program Increment. How should this dependency be captured?

options.A: As a risk on the team's risk board
options.B: As a string on the Program Board connecting the two teams' features
options.C: As a note in the Sprint Retrospective minutes
options.D: As an impediment for the Scrum Master to resolve independently

questions.correct_text: As a string on the Program Board connecting the two teams' features
questions.explanation: In SAFe's PI Planning, the Program Board is a large visual display that maps features to iterations across teams. Dependencies between teams are represented as strings (or lines) connecting dependent features on the board, making cross-team dependencies visible. This transparency enables the Release Train Engineer and teams to manage dependencies proactively. Option A captures risks but does not visualize the dependency. Options C and D are inappropriate timing and mechanisms for cross-team dependency management.

questions.stem: Which of the following is an example of one of the seven wastes of Lean (Muda) as applied to software development?

options.A: A developer completes a feature that is deployed to production and immediately used by customers
options.B: A developer writes comprehensive automated tests that prevent regression defects
options.C: A team builds five features that stakeholders requested but only two are ever used by end users
options.D: A Product Owner refines the backlog weekly with the development team

questions.correct_text: A team builds five features that stakeholders requested but only two are ever used by end users
questions.explanation: This is an example of "overproduction" or "extra features" — one of the seven Lean wastes adapted for software by Mary and Tom Poppendieck. Building features that are not used represents wasted effort and resources. Option A represents ideal value delivery. Option B prevents future waste (defects). Option D is a necessary refinement activity that improves flow. The seven Lean software wastes are: partially done work, extra features, relearning, handoffs, delays, task switching, and defects.

questions.stem: An organization has adopted Scrum but has made the following modifications: the Sprint Review has been replaced with a management status report, the Daily Scrum lasts 45 minutes with the Scrum Master assigning tasks, and retrospectives are held quarterly instead of every Sprint. This pattern is BEST described as:

options.A: Hybrid agile adapted to organizational needs
options.B: ScrumBut — claiming Scrum while violating its core framework
options.C: Disciplined Agile's "Choose Your WoW" approach
options.D: A mature team in the "Ri" stage of Shu-Ha-Ri

questions.correct_text: ScrumBut — claiming Scrum while violating its core framework
questions.explanation: "ScrumBut" is an anti-pattern where organizations claim to use Scrum but modify it in ways that undermine its core principles: "We use Scrum, but..." These modifications — replacing inspection with status reporting, removing self-management from Daily Scrum, and reducing retrospective frequency — remove the empirical and self-managing pillars of Scrum. Option A implies intentional hybridization. Option C involves conscious process tailoring. Option D implies mastery, whereas these changes reflect misunderstanding.

questions.stem: According to the Agile Manifesto's twelve principles, what is the primary measure of progress in an agile project?

options.A: Adherence to the project schedule and budget
options.B: Working software
options.C: Velocity trend over time
options.D: Percentage of backlog items completed

questions.correct_text: Working software
questions.explanation: Agile Manifesto Principle #7 states: "Working software is the primary measure of progress." This shifts the focus from traditional metrics like schedule adherence or budget tracking to actual deliverable functionality. Option A reflects traditional project management measures. Option C (velocity) is a useful planning metric but not the primary progress measure. Option D (backlog completion percentage) does not account for whether the software actually works.

questions.stem: A multinational company is scaling agile using Disciplined Agile (DA). The agile coach explains that DA differs from SAFe because it does not prescribe a single framework. Instead, it helps teams choose their approach based on context. What is this DA concept called?

options.A: Agile Release Train (ART)
options.B: Choose Your Way of Working (WoW)
options.C: Nexus Integration Team
options.D: Scrum of Scrums

questions.correct_text: Choose Your Way of Working (WoW)
questions.explanation: Disciplined Agile's core concept is "Choose Your WoW" (Way of Working), which provides a toolkit of strategies and practices that teams can select based on their unique context rather than prescribing a single approach. This goal-driven approach distinguishes DA from more prescriptive frameworks like SAFe. Option A is a SAFe concept. Option C is a Nexus concept. Option D is a coordination mechanism used across several scaling approaches.

questions.stem:
A Scrum team has the following Sprint Burndown data mid-Sprint:

- Sprint length: 10 days
- Total Sprint commitment: 40 story points
- Day 5 actual remaining: 28 story points
- Ideal burndown at Day 5: 20 story points

What does this data MOST LIKELY indicate?

options.A: The team is on track and will complete all committed work
options.B: The team is behind the ideal pace and may not complete all committed stories
options.C: The team has over-committed and should reduce scope immediately
options.D: The burndown is inaccurate because story points cannot measure remaining work

questions.correct_text: The team is behind the ideal pace and may not complete all committed stories
questions.explanation: At Day 5 (the midpoint), the team should ideally have 20 points remaining but has 28 points — they are 8 points behind the ideal pace. This indicates the team is at risk of not completing their Sprint commitment. However, it does not necessarily mean they must reduce scope immediately (Option C) since Sprint dynamics can change. The Scrum Master should facilitate a conversation about the gap. Option A contradicts the data. Option D incorrectly dismisses the burndown as a tool.

questions.stem: A team is deciding between Scrum and XP for a new software project. The project requires extremely high code quality due to regulatory compliance, frequent customer collaboration, and the ability to accommodate changing requirements weekly. Which framework is MOST appropriate and why?

options.A: Scrum, because it provides the most prescriptive process for regulatory compliance
options.B: XP, because its engineering practices (TDD, pair programming, CI) directly support high code quality and frequent releases
options.C: Kanban, because regulatory environments need continuous flow
options.D: Waterfall with agile elements, because regulatory compliance requires upfront planning

questions.correct_text: XP, because its engineering practices (TDD, pair programming, CI) directly support high code quality and frequent releases
questions.explanation: XP is specifically designed for environments demanding high code quality with practices like TDD, pair programming, continuous integration, collective code ownership, and refactoring. These engineering practices directly address regulatory quality requirements while supporting frequent changes. Scrum provides a management framework but does not prescribe specific engineering practices. Kanban manages flow but does not emphasize code quality practices. Waterfall with agile elements does not accommodate weekly changes.

questions.stem: A Release Train Engineer (RTE) in a SAFe organization is preparing for PI Planning. Which of the following activities is the RTE MOST LIKELY responsible for?

options.A: Writing user stories for each team's Sprint backlog
options.B: Facilitating the PI Planning event, managing dependencies, and ensuring alignment across teams
options.C: Approving the final Program Increment plan before teams can begin work
options.D: Assigning individual developers to specific Agile Release Trains

questions.correct_text: Facilitating the PI Planning event, managing dependencies, and ensuring alignment across teams
questions.explanation: The Release Train Engineer (RTE) in SAFe is a servant leader and facilitator for the Agile Release Train (ART). Their primary responsibilities include facilitating PI Planning, managing cross-team dependencies, removing escalated impediments, and ensuring alignment across teams. The RTE does not write stories (that is the Product Owner/Product Manager), does not approve plans (teams own their commitments), and does not assign people (teams are self-organizing).

questions.stem: An agile team is experiencing the following issues: the Sprint Backlog never changes during a Sprint; no new learning is incorporated; and the team follows a fixed plan from Sprint Planning to Sprint Review without adaptation. Which agile anti-pattern does this BEST represent?

options.A: Gold plating
options.B: Mini-waterfall within Sprints
options.C: Scope creep
options.D: Feature factory

questions.correct_text: Mini-waterfall within Sprints
questions.explanation: Mini-waterfall is an anti-pattern where teams treat each Sprint as a small waterfall project — planning everything upfront, following a fixed plan, and only delivering at the end without adapting based on learning during the Sprint. Agile embraces emerging requirements and adaptation within a Sprint. Gold plating means adding unnecessary features. Scope creep means uncontrolled expansion of requirements. A feature factory produces features without considering value or outcomes.

questions.stem: According to the Dreyfus Model of Skill Acquisition, a practitioner who can recognize patterns, apply rules flexibly based on context, and see the larger picture but still relies on analytical thinking rather than intuition is at which level?

options.A: Competent
options.B: Proficient
options.C: Expert
options.D: Advanced Beginner

questions.correct_text: Proficient
questions.explanation: The Dreyfus Model has five stages: Novice (follows rigid rules), Advanced Beginner (recognizes recurring situations), Competent (manages complexity through planning), Proficient (sees the big picture and applies rules flexibly but still thinks analytically), and Expert (acts intuitively from deep experience). The description matches the Proficient level — flexible rule application with holistic perspective but not yet intuitive mastery. Option A (Competent) still relies heavily on planning and procedures. Option C (Expert) would act on intuition.

questions.stem: A company has 8 Scrum teams working on a single product. They want a minimalist scaling approach that preserves Scrum's core principles and avoids adding new roles beyond those in the Scrum Guide. Which scaling framework BEST fits this requirement?

options.A: SAFe (Scaled Agile Framework)
options.B: LeSS (Large-Scale Scrum)
options.C: Disciplined Agile (DA)
options.D: Nexus

questions.correct_text: LeSS (Large-Scale Scrum)
questions.explanation: LeSS (Large-Scale Scrum) is designed to scale Scrum with minimal additional process. LeSS preserves Scrum's roles, events, and artifacts and applies them at scale without adding significant new roles or processes. For up to 8 teams, "basic" LeSS applies. SAFe adds considerable structure (ARTs, PIs, new roles). DA is a process decision framework, not strictly a Scrum scaling approach. Nexus adds the Nexus Integration Team role, though it is also minimalist. LeSS is the most explicitly "descaled" option.

questions.stem: A Scrum Master notices that during Daily Scrums, team members only report status to the Scrum Master and do not talk to each other. What should the Scrum Master do to improve this?

options.A: Cancel the Daily Scrum since the team is not using it effectively
options.B: Step back and let the Developers own the Daily Scrum, facilitating self-organization
options.C: Create a more detailed status report template for each developer
options.D: Extend the Daily Scrum to 30 minutes to allow more discussion

questions.correct_text: Step back and let the Developers own the Daily Scrum, facilitating self-organization
questions.explanation: The Daily Scrum belongs to the Developers — it is their event for planning and coordinating work toward the Sprint Goal. When team members only report to the Scrum Master, the event has become a status meeting, violating its purpose. The Scrum Master should coach the team to use the Daily Scrum for peer-to-peer coordination. Option A removes a valuable Scrum event. Option C reinforces the status-reporting anti-pattern. Option D violates the 15-minute time-box and does not fix the root cause.

questions.stem: During a crisis, an organization's production system goes down and the root cause is completely unknown. There is no time for analysis — immediate action is required to restore service. According to the Cynefin framework, what is the appropriate approach?

options.A: Sense-Categorize-Respond (apply best practices)
options.B: Sense-Analyze-Respond (apply good practices)
options.C: Probe-Sense-Respond (run experiments)
options.D: Act-Sense-Respond (take immediate action, then assess)

questions.correct_text: Act-Sense-Respond (take immediate action, then assess)
questions.explanation: In the Chaotic domain of Cynefin, there is no time for analysis or experimentation — the priority is to act immediately to stabilize the situation, then sense the results of that action, and then respond to move the situation into a more manageable domain. Option A is for the Clear/Obvious domain. Option B is for the Complicated domain. Option C is for the Complex domain. The key differentiator is that Chaotic requires action first.

questions.stem: A team practicing Kanban wants to improve their flow efficiency. Their current board shows that the average cycle time for a work item is 12 days, but actual value-adding work takes only 3 days. The rest is wait time between process steps. What is the team's flow efficiency?
questions.explanation: Flow efficiency is calculated as: (Value-Adding Time / Total Cycle Time) x 100. In this case: (3 days / 12 days) x 100 = 25%. This means only 25% of the total time is spent on work that adds value, while 75% is waste (waiting, queuing). The team should focus on reducing wait times between steps. This is a key Lean metric, and many teams initially discover flow efficiency between 15-40%.

questions.stem: In Scrum@Scale, which body is responsible for removing organizational impediments that block multiple Scrum teams and cannot be resolved at the team level?

options.A: The Nexus Integration Team
options.B: The Executive Action Team (EAT)
options.C: The Release Train Engineer (RTE)
options.D: The Agile Center of Excellence (ACoE)

questions.correct_text: The Executive Action Team (EAT)
questions.explanation: In Jeff Sutherland's Scrum@Scale framework, the Executive Action Team (EAT) is the organizational Scrum Master responsible for removing impediments that cross team boundaries and cannot be resolved locally. The EAT operates as a Scrum team itself, using empiricism to address systemic organizational issues. Option A is from Nexus. Option C is from SAFe. Option D is a generic organizational structure, not specific to Scrum@Scale.

questions.stem: A software development organization is evaluating its agile maturity. Which of the following is the BEST indicator that the organization has truly embraced the agile mindset rather than just agile practices?

options.A: All teams use Scrum and hold daily standups consistently
options.B: Velocity is tracked and reported for every team each Sprint
options.C: Teams continuously experiment with their processes and the organization adapts its structure based on feedback
options.D: The organization has hired certified Scrum Masters for every team

questions.correct_text: Teams continuously experiment with their processes and the organization adapts its structure based on feedback
questions.explanation: The Agile Iceberg concept distinguishes between visible practices (ceremonies, artifacts, roles) and the deeper mindset (continuous learning, adaptation, experimentation). Options A, B, and D all describe "Doing Agile" — implementing visible practices. Only Option C demonstrates "Being Agile" — teams and the organization itself are learning, adapting, and evolving. True agile maturity means the mindset drives behavior, not just adherence to a framework.

questions.stem: An agile coach is working with a team that has been using Scrum for two years. The team has modified several Scrum practices: they hold retrospectives bi-weekly instead of every Sprint, they have eliminated the Sprint Review because stakeholders prefer ad-hoc demos, and they have combined the Product Owner and Scrum Master roles. The team claims these modifications improve their efficiency. How should the agile coach respond?

options.A: Support the team's modifications because agile is about adapting to context
options.B: Challenge the modifications because removing core Scrum elements likely hides underlying dysfunctions
options.C: Recommend switching to Kanban since the team does not want Scrum's structure
options.D: Report the team to management for non-compliance with organizational Scrum standards

questions.correct_text: Challenge the modifications because removing core Scrum elements likely hides underlying dysfunctions
questions.explanation: While mature teams can adapt practices (Ha/Ri stages of Shu-Ha-Ri), removing core Scrum elements often masks underlying problems rather than solving them. Eliminating Sprint Reviews removes stakeholder feedback loops. Reducing retrospective frequency slows improvement. Combining PO and SM roles creates conflicts of interest between delivery pressure and team protection. The coach should help the team understand why these elements exist before modifying them. Option A ignores that these specific changes undermine empiricism.

questions.stem: Which Agile Manifesto principle MOST directly supports the practice of co-locating team members?

options.A: Build projects around motivated individuals. Give them the environment and support they need, and trust them to get the job done.
options.B: The most efficient and effective method of conveying information to and within a development team is face-to-face conversation.
options.C: At regular intervals, the team reflects on how to become more effective, then tunes and adjusts its behavior accordingly.
options.D: Continuous attention to technical excellence and good design enhances agility.

questions.correct_text: The most efficient and effective method of conveying information to and within a development team is face-to-face conversation.
questions.explanation: This principle (Principle #6) directly supports co-location by recognizing that face-to-face communication is the most effective form of information exchange. Co-location maximizes opportunities for this type of communication. Option A addresses environment and trust but not specifically communication method. Option C addresses continuous improvement through retrospection. Option D addresses technical practices.

questions.stem: A Scrum team completes their Sprint Planning and determines the following: Sprint length is 2 weeks, the team has 5 developers each available 6 hours/day for Sprint work, and there are 10 working days in the Sprint. What is the team's total capacity for this Sprint in ideal hours?

options.A: 240 hours
options.B: 300 hours
options.C: 400 hours
options.D: 60 hours

questions.correct_text: 300 hours
questions.explanation: Total capacity = Number of developers x Available hours per day x Number of working days = 5 developers x 6 hours/day x 10 days = 300 ideal hours. Option A (240) incorrectly uses 8 working days. Option C (400) incorrectly uses 8 hours/day. Option D (60) only calculates one developer's capacity. This capacity figure helps the team determine how much work they can realistically commit to during Sprint Planning.

questions.stem: A team is working in a complex environment where requirements emerge through experimentation. The Product Owner wants to understand the impact of a new recommendation algorithm before building the full feature. Which agile approach should the team use FIRST?

options.A: Build the complete feature and measure results after deployment
options.B: Create a Spike to research the algorithm and then build a Minimum Viable Product (MVP) to test it
options.C: Add the feature to the bottom of the Product Backlog until more information is available
options.D: Commission a comprehensive requirements document before development begins

questions.correct_text: Create a Spike to research the algorithm and then build a Minimum Viable Product (MVP) to test it
questions.explanation: In complex environments, the Cynefin-recommended approach is Probe-Sense-Respond. A Spike is a time-boxed research activity that reduces uncertainty, and an MVP allows the team to test assumptions with real users at minimal cost. Option A assumes requirements are understood (not appropriate for complexity). Option C delays learning without gaining knowledge. Option D is a traditional approach that assumes requirements can be fully specified upfront, which contradicts the emergent nature of the work.

questions.stem: An organization is implementing SAFe at the Portfolio level. Which of the following is a key artifact used to align strategy with execution at the portfolio level?

options.A: Sprint Backlog
options.B: Portfolio Kanban
options.C: Sprint Burndown Chart
options.D: Team Velocity Report

questions.correct_text: Portfolio Kanban
questions.explanation: In SAFe, the Portfolio Kanban is used at the portfolio level to visualize and manage the flow of strategic initiatives (Epics) from ideation through implementation. It provides a mechanism for Lean governance, enabling portfolio-level decision-making about investment. Options A, C, and D are all team-level artifacts in Scrum that operate at a much lower level of abstraction than portfolio management.

questions.stem: A Product Owner asks the team to estimate a set of user stories. One developer suggests using Planning Poker. Another proposes affinity estimation. A third recommends t-shirt sizing. Under which circumstance is affinity estimation MOST appropriate?

options.A: When the team has a small backlog of 10 well-defined stories
options.B: When the team needs to quickly estimate a large backlog of 50+ stories at a high level
options.C: When the team requires precise estimates for contractual commitments
options.D: When the team is performing Sprint Planning for a single Sprint

questions.correct_text: When the team needs to quickly estimate a large backlog of 50+ stories at a high level
questions.explanation: Affinity estimation (also called wall estimation) is a rapid, collaborative technique where the team groups stories into relative size categories simultaneously. It is ideal for quickly sizing a large number of items. Planning Poker is thorough but slow for large backlogs. T-shirt sizing is also fast but less structured. For 10 well-defined stories (A), Planning Poker provides more precision. For contractual commitments (C), more detailed estimation is needed. For Sprint Planning (D), Planning Poker or task-level estimation is typical.

questions.stem: A team is using Kanban and notices that their cumulative flow diagram (CFD) shows a widening band in the "Testing" column over the past three weeks. What does this widening band MOST LIKELY indicate?

options.A: Testing throughput is increasing and the team is delivering faster
options.B: A bottleneck is forming in Testing — items are entering faster than they are leaving
options.C: The team has eliminated waste in the Testing process
options.D: The Testing WIP limit is set appropriately

questions.correct_text: A bottleneck is forming in Testing — items are entering faster than they are leaving
questions.explanation: In a Cumulative Flow Diagram, each band represents the number of items in a particular state over time. A widening band indicates that items are accumulating in that state — the arrival rate exceeds the departure rate, creating a bottleneck. This leads to longer cycle times and reduced throughput. A healthy flow shows bands of consistent width. Option A would show a narrowing band. Options C and D contradict the symptom of a widening band.

questions.stem: A Scrum Master is coaching a new team on the purpose of the Sprint Retrospective. A team member asks, "How is the retrospective different from the Sprint Review?" Which response BEST explains the distinction?

options.A: The Sprint Review focuses on the product increment and stakeholder feedback, while the Retrospective focuses on how the team works and process improvements
options.B: The Sprint Review is for the team only, while the Retrospective includes external stakeholders
options.C: The Sprint Review happens at the beginning of the Sprint, while the Retrospective happens at the end
options.D: There is no significant difference — both events can be combined for efficiency

questions.correct_text: The Sprint Review focuses on the product increment and stakeholder feedback, while the Retrospective focuses on how the team works and process improvements
questions.explanation: The Sprint Review is an inspect-and-adapt event for the product — the team demonstrates the Increment and gathers stakeholder feedback to adapt the Product Backlog. The Sprint Retrospective is an inspect-and-adapt event for the process — the team examines how they worked and identifies improvements for future Sprints. Option B reverses the audience (Review includes stakeholders, Retro is team-internal). Option C misstates the timing (both happen at the end). Option D ignores their distinct purposes.

questions.stem: A large enterprise is deciding between SAFe and LeSS for scaling agile across 15 teams. The organization values prescriptive guidance, role definitions, and a structured path for transformation. Which factor MOST favors choosing SAFe over LeSS?

options.A: LeSS requires more roles and processes than SAFe
options.B: SAFe provides more prescriptive guidance, defined roles, and organizational structure for large-scale adoption
options.C: SAFe is designed only for small teams while LeSS is for large organizations
options.D: LeSS does not support more than 8 teams

questions.correct_text: SAFe provides more prescriptive guidance, defined roles, and organizational structure for large-scale adoption
questions.explanation: SAFe is the most prescriptive agile scaling framework, offering detailed role definitions (RTE, Solution Architect, Product Manager), structured events (PI Planning), and a clear implementation roadmap. This suits organizations seeking structured guidance. LeSS is deliberately minimalist, adding as little as possible beyond Scrum. Option A is backwards — SAFe has more roles. Option C is incorrect — SAFe is designed for large organizations. Option D is incorrect — LeSS Huge supports over 8 teams.

questions.stem: A Kanban team has the following throughput data for the past 6 weeks: 8, 10, 7, 9, 11, 9 items completed per week. A stakeholder asks when 30 remaining items will be completed. Using a simple throughput-based forecast, what is the MOST LIKELY delivery time?

options.A: Approximately 2 weeks
options.B: Approximately 3 weeks
options.C: Approximately 4 weeks
options.D: Approximately 5 weeks

questions.correct_text: Approximately 4 weeks
questions.explanation: Average throughput = (8 + 10 + 7 + 9 + 11 + 9) / 6 = 54 / 6 = 9 items per week. Forecasted delivery time = 30 items / 9 items per week = 3.33 weeks, which rounds to approximately 3-4 weeks. Given uncertainty and the need for a realistic forecast, approximately 3.3 weeks is MOST LIKELY to be communicated as "about 4 weeks" to provide a reasonable buffer. Option A is too optimistic. Option B barely covers the mathematical minimum. Option D is overly conservative given the data.

questions.stem: An organization wants to ensure that its agile teams are following governance practices at scale. In SAFe, which event serves as the primary governance checkpoint for the Agile Release Train?

options.A: Daily Scrum
options.B: Sprint Retrospective
options.C: Inspect & Adapt (I&A) workshop
options.D: Sprint Review

questions.correct_text: Inspect & Adapt (I&A) workshop
questions.explanation: In SAFe, the Inspect & Adapt (I&A) event occurs at the end of each Program Increment (PI). It combines a PI System Demo (demonstrating the integrated solution to stakeholders), quantitative and qualitative measurement, and a problem-solving workshop. This serves as the primary governance and improvement event at the ART level. Daily Scrums and Sprint Reviews are team-level events. Sprint Retrospectives focus on team process improvement, not ART-level governance.

questions.stem: A servant leader Scrum Master observes that two developers have a persistent conflict about coding standards. The disagreement is affecting team morale and slowing delivery. What is the MOST appropriate servant leadership response?

options.A: Make a decision about the coding standard and enforce it
options.B: Facilitate a conversation between the two developers to help them reach consensus
options.C: Escalate the issue to the engineering manager for resolution
options.D: Ignore the conflict since self-organizing teams should resolve their own issues

questions.correct_text: Facilitate a conversation between the two developers to help them reach consensus
questions.explanation: Servant leadership involves facilitating resolution rather than dictating solutions or avoiding responsibility. The Scrum Master should create a safe space for the developers to discuss their perspectives and collaboratively agree on coding standards. Option A is command-and-control, not servant leadership. Option C bypasses team self-management. Option D neglects the Scrum Master's responsibility to remove impediments to team effectiveness — persistent conflict is an impediment.

questions.stem: An agile team in the "Ha" stage of Shu-Ha-Ri is MOST LIKELY to:

options.A: Follow every Scrum rule exactly as prescribed in the Scrum Guide
options.B: Adapt practices based on understanding of the underlying principles and their team context
options.C: Create an entirely new framework that departs from established agile methods
options.D: Seek permission from the Scrum Master before making any process changes

questions.correct_text: Adapt practices based on understanding of the underlying principles and their team context
questions.explanation: In the "Ha" (detach/break) stage of Shu-Ha-Ri, practitioners have internalized the fundamentals and can begin to thoughtfully adapt and break from strict rules because they understand the "why" behind the practices. Option A describes "Shu" (follow/obey) — strict rule adherence. Option C describes "Ri" (transcend) — creating new approaches from deep understanding. Option D reflects dependency on authority, which contradicts the autonomy expected at the Ha stage.

questions.stem: A team is evaluating whether to use the Nexus framework for scaling. Which characteristic of Nexus distinguishes it from other scaling frameworks?

options.A: It uses PI Planning events with a Program Board
options.B: It introduces a Nexus Integration Team responsible for ensuring integrated increments across 3-9 Scrum teams
options.C: It replaces Scrum Masters with Release Train Engineers
options.D: It requires teams to choose their own Way of Working (WoW)

questions.correct_text: It introduces a Nexus Integration Team responsible for ensuring integrated increments across 3-9 Scrum teams
questions.explanation: Nexus (developed by Ken Schwaber and Scrum.org) scales Scrum for 3-9 teams working on a single product. Its distinguishing feature is the Nexus Integration Team (NIT), which includes the Product Owner and members from each team, responsible for ensuring that an integrated, working product is produced each Sprint. Option A describes SAFe. Option C describes SAFe. Option D describes Disciplined Agile.

questions.stem: A team has completed 5 Sprints with the following velocity: 22, 18, 25, 20, 25 story points. The Product Backlog contains 100 story points of remaining work. The Product Owner wants to know how many Sprints it will take to complete the remaining work. What is the BEST answer using historical velocity?

options.A: 4 Sprints
options.B: 5 Sprints
options.C: 3 Sprints
options.D: 6 Sprints

questions.correct_text: 5 Sprints
questions.explanation: Average velocity = (22 + 18 + 25 + 20 + 25) / 5 = 110 / 5 = 22 story points per Sprint. Remaining work / Average velocity = 100 / 22 = 4.55 Sprints. Since partial Sprints are not practical, this rounds up to 5 Sprints. Option A (4 Sprints) would require 25 points/Sprint, which only happened twice. Option C is too optimistic. Option D is unnecessarily conservative given the consistent velocity.

questions.stem: A manager transitioning to agile asks the Scrum Master: "If I'm not assigning work, managing the schedule, or tracking individual performance, what is my role?" Which response BEST reflects agile principles?

options.A: Your role is eliminated in agile organizations
options.B: Your role shifts to removing organizational impediments, securing resources, and creating an environment where teams can succeed
options.C: You should become a Product Owner to maintain your authority
options.D: You should focus on detailed project status reporting to executives

questions.correct_text: Your role shifts to removing organizational impediments, securing resources, and creating an environment where teams can succeed
questions.explanation: In agile organizations, management's role transforms from command-and-control to enabling and supporting. This aligns with Agile Manifesto Principle #5: "Build projects around motivated individuals. Give them the environment and support they need, and trust them to get the job done." Option A is incorrect — management roles evolve, not disappear. Option C confuses role transformation with role assignment. Option D reinforces traditional oversight rather than agile servant leadership.

questions.stem: A team practicing Lean software development identifies the following in their value stream map: a feature request takes 45 days from submission to deployment, but only 8 days involve actual development and testing work. The remaining 37 days are spent in approval queues, waiting for environments, and handoffs between teams. According to Lean principles, what should the team focus on to improve delivery speed?

options.A: Hiring more developers to reduce the 8 days of development time
options.B: Eliminating or reducing the 37 days of non-value-adding wait time and handoffs
options.C: Adding more approval checkpoints to ensure quality
options.D: Creating more detailed specifications to reduce rework

questions.correct_text: Eliminating or reducing the 37 days of non-value-adding wait time and handoffs
questions.explanation: Lean thinking focuses on eliminating waste (Muda), and the biggest source of waste in this scenario is the wait time (37 of 45 days, or 82%). Reducing the 8 days of development time would have minimal impact compared to addressing queues, handoffs, and waiting. This is a core Lean principle — optimize the whole value stream, not just the development step. Option A optimizes the wrong bottleneck. Options C and D would likely increase lead time further.

questions.stem: In the Cynefin framework, a team faces a situation where there is no clear relationship between cause and effect, and multiple valid approaches could work. The team runs small experiments, observes the results, and then decides which direction to pursue. Which Cynefin domain is the team operating in?

options.A: Clear (Simple/Obvious)
options.B: Complicated
options.C: Complex
options.D: Chaotic

questions.correct_text: Complex
questions.explanation: The Complex domain in Cynefin is characterized by emergent practices where cause-and-effect relationships are only visible in retrospect. The appropriate approach is Probe-Sense-Respond: run safe-to-fail experiments, observe outcomes, and amplify what works. This describes the team's behavior exactly. Clear uses best practices (known cause-and-effect). Complicated uses good practices (analysable cause-and-effect). Chaotic requires immediate novel action (no perceivable cause-and-effect).

questions.stem: A Scrum team is in their third Sprint. The Product Owner wants to change the Sprint Goal mid-Sprint because a competitor just launched a similar feature. The team has already completed 60% of the planned work. What should the Scrum Master advise?

options.A: Immediately change the Sprint Goal to respond to the competitive threat
options.B: Only the Product Owner has the authority to cancel the Sprint if the Sprint Goal becomes obsolete; discuss whether cancellation is warranted
options.C: Ignore the competitive threat and complete the current Sprint as planned
options.D: Extend the Sprint by one week to accommodate both the original and new goals

questions.correct_text: Only the Product Owner has the authority to cancel the Sprint if the Sprint Goal becomes obsolete; discuss whether cancellation is warranted
questions.explanation: In Scrum, the Sprint Goal provides coherence and focus. If the Sprint Goal becomes obsolete, only the Product Owner has the authority to cancel the Sprint. The Scrum Master should facilitate a conversation about whether the competitive change truly renders the current Sprint Goal obsolete. Option A bypasses the proper process. Option C ignores legitimate market feedback. Option D violates the fixed time-box principle of Sprints.

questions.stem: An organization is implementing SAFe and needs to determine the optimal team structure for an Agile Release Train (ART). According to SAFe guidance, what is the recommended number of teams per ART?

options.A: 2-3 teams
options.B: 5-12 teams
options.C: 15-25 teams
options.D: 25-50 teams

questions.correct_text: 5-12 teams
questions.explanation: SAFe recommends that an Agile Release Train (ART) consist of 5-12 teams (approximately 50-125 people). This size is large enough to deliver significant value independently but small enough to maintain effective communication and coordination during PI Planning. Option A is too small for an ART. Options C and D exceed the recommended ART size and would typically require a Solution Train or multiple ARTs.

questions.stem: A team is discussing the Agile Manifesto value "Customer collaboration over contract negotiation." A stakeholder argues this means contracts are unnecessary in agile projects. What is the BEST response?

options.A: Correct — agile projects should operate without formal contracts
options.B: Contracts are still valuable, but the relationship should be collaborative rather than adversarial, with contracts that support change rather than resist it
options.C: Contracts should only define penalties for non-delivery
options.D: Contracts are only needed for fixed-price projects, not agile ones

questions.correct_text: Contracts are still valuable, but the relationship should be collaborative rather than adversarial, with contracts that support change rather than resist it
questions.explanation: The Agile Manifesto states there is value in items on the right side (including contract negotiation) — it simply values the left side more. Agile-friendly contracts (such as time-and-materials, incremental delivery, or target-cost contracts) support collaboration and change. Option A misinterprets the Manifesto. Option C creates an adversarial rather than collaborative relationship. Option D incorrectly limits the applicability of contracts.

questions.stem: A development team currently using Scrum has the following situation: their work items are highly variable in size, they receive urgent production support requests daily, and stakeholders want continuous delivery rather than Sprint-based releases. The team is considering switching frameworks. Which transition would BEST address their needs?

options.A: Switch from Scrum to Waterfall for better predictability
options.B: Adopt Scrumban — combining Scrum's structure with Kanban's continuous flow and WIP limits
options.C: Add more Scrum ceremonies to increase coordination
options.D: Implement SAFe to handle the complexity

questions.correct_text: Adopt Scrumban — combining Scrum's structure with Kanban's continuous flow and WIP limits
questions.explanation: Scrumban combines elements of both Scrum and Kanban, making it ideal for teams that need the structure of Scrum's roles and events but also require the flexibility of Kanban's continuous flow for handling variable work and urgent requests. It uses WIP limits, pull-based systems, and can support continuous delivery. Option A moves away from agility. Option C adds overhead without addressing flow issues. Option D is a scaling framework not suited to a single-team flow problem.

questions.stem: A Scrum Master is explaining the concept of "Inspect and Adapt" to new team members. Which of the following BEST represents the three pillars of Scrum's empirical process control?

options.A: Plan, Do, Check
options.B: Transparency, Inspection, Adaptation
options.C: Vision, Strategy, Execution
options.D: Backlog, Sprint, Increment

questions.correct_text: Transparency, Inspection, Adaptation
questions.explanation: Scrum is founded on empiricism, which asserts that knowledge comes from experience and making decisions based on what is observed. The three pillars of empirical process control are Transparency (the process must be visible), Inspection (Scrum artifacts and progress must be inspected frequently), and Adaptation (if inspection reveals deviation, the process must be adjusted). Option A describes the PDCA cycle. Options C and D describe different concepts entirely.

questions.stem: During a SAFe PI Planning event, a team identifies a risk that they might not be able to deliver a critical feature due to a dependency on an external vendor. The vendor has not confirmed their delivery date. How should this be handled in PI Planning?

options.A: Remove the feature from the PI plan entirely
options.B: Record it as a program risk on the ROAM board and classify it appropriately
options.C: Assign the risk to the vendor and move on
options.D: Ignore it since external dependencies are not part of PI Planning

questions.correct_text: Record it as a program risk on the ROAM board and classify it appropriately
questions.explanation: In SAFe PI Planning, teams identify risks, which are captured and categorized on a ROAM board: Resolved, Owned, Accepted, or Mitigated. An external vendor dependency with an unconfirmed date is a significant program-level risk that should be made visible and managed. Option A is premature without risk assessment. Option C does not ensure the ART manages the risk. Option D ignores a real threat to PI objectives.

questions.stem: A Scrum team has been together for a year and is consistently delivering high-quality increments. The team proposes replacing the daily 15-minute Scrum with an asynchronous chat update and meeting only when someone raises a blocker. According to agile principles, what is the BEST assessment of this proposal?

options.A: This violates Scrum and should be rejected — the Daily Scrum must always be a synchronous meeting
options.B: This could be appropriate for a mature team that understands the Daily Scrum's purpose and can maintain its intent through alternative means
options.C: This should be escalated to the Agile Coach for a decision
options.D: This is always wrong because it reduces face-to-face communication

questions.correct_text: This could be appropriate for a mature team that understands the Daily Scrum's purpose and can maintain its intent through alternative means
questions.explanation: A team in the "Ha" or "Ri" stage of Shu-Ha-Ri may adapt practices while preserving their intent. If the mature team understands that the Daily Scrum's purpose is coordination and impediment identification, and they can achieve this asynchronously, the adaptation may be valid. The key is whether the underlying principle is maintained. Option A applies rigid rules regardless of context. Option C abdicates team self-management. Option D ignores that the principle is about effective communication, not a specific format.

questions.stem: A Product Owner is unsure which of the twelve Agile Manifesto principles addresses the relationship between the business side and the technical side of the project. Which principle states that business people and developers must work together daily?

options.A: Principle #1: Our highest priority is to satisfy the customer through early and continuous delivery of valuable software
options.B: Principle #4: Business people and developers must work together daily throughout the project
options.C: Principle #6: The most efficient and effective method of conveying information is face-to-face conversation
options.D: Principle #11: The best architectures, requirements, and designs emerge from self-organizing teams

questions.correct_text: Principle #4: Business people and developers must work together daily throughout the project
questions.explanation: Principle #4 specifically mandates daily collaboration between business stakeholders and the development team. This principle underpins the Product Owner role in Scrum, which serves as the bridge between business needs and technical delivery. Option A focuses on customer satisfaction through delivery. Option C addresses communication method. Option D addresses team autonomy in technical decisions.

questions.stem: An organization has three Scrum teams working on the same product. They are experiencing integration issues at the end of every Sprint, with each team's code frequently breaking other teams' work. Which practice would MOST effectively address this problem?

options.A: Assign one team to do all integration testing at the end of each Sprint
options.B: Implement continuous integration with automated testing and a shared Definition of Done that includes integration
options.C: Have each team work on a separate branch and merge only at release time
options.D: Add a hardening Sprint after every three regular Sprints

questions.correct_text: Implement continuous integration with automated testing and a shared Definition of Done that includes integration
questions.explanation: Continuous integration (CI), an XP practice, ensures that code is merged and tested frequently (ideally multiple times per day), catching integration issues early before they compound. A shared Definition of Done that requires integration testing ensures all teams maintain the same quality bar. Option A delays integration discovery. Option C (branch-based development) delays integration even further. Option D (hardening Sprints) is an anti-pattern that indicates the Definition of Done is insufficient.

questions.stem: A product owner discovers that a key stakeholder has been providing conflicting requirements directly to two different development team members, bypassing the product backlog entirely. The team has already started work on features that contradict the current sprint goal. The Scrum Master learns of this during the daily standup when both developers describe work that is mutually exclusive. What should the Scrum Master do FIRST?

options.A: Immediately cancel the sprint and begin replanning with corrected requirements
options.B: Facilitate a conversation between the product owner and the stakeholder to align on priorities, then work with the team to assess the impact on the current sprint
options.C: Instruct both developers to stop all work until the product owner resolves the conflict independently
options.D: Escalate the stakeholder behaviour to the project sponsor and document the interference

questions.correct_text: Facilitate a conversation between the product owner and the stakeholder to align on priorities, then work with the team to assess the impact on the current sprint
questions.explanation:
The Scrum Master's role is to facilitate and remove impediments, not to dictate solutions or escalate prematurely. Bringing the product owner and stakeholder together addresses the root cause — misaligned communication — while assessing sprint impact respects the team's current commitments. Cancelling the sprint (A) is premature before understanding the full scope. Stopping all work (C) is overly disruptive. Escalation (D) bypasses collaborative resolution, violating agile principles of direct communication.
*Domains Tested:* Domain III (Stakeholder Engagement) + Domain IV (Team Performance)

questions.stem: An agile team has been delivering consistently for six sprints with a stable velocity of 40 story points. The organisation announces a major regulatory change that will take effect in 90 days, affecting 60% of the product backlog. The product owner wants to reprioritise the entire backlog immediately, but the team is mid-sprint with committed work that does not relate to the regulatory change. Three key stakeholders disagree on which regulatory items should be addressed first. What should the team do FIRST?

options.A: Complete the current sprint as planned, then hold an emergency backlog refinement session with all stakeholders before the next sprint planning
options.B: Terminate the current sprint immediately and begin a new sprint focused entirely on regulatory items
options.C: Ask the product owner to unilaterally decide the regulatory priorities and communicate them to the team
options.D: Split the team into two sub-teams — one to finish the current sprint and one to begin regulatory work immediately

questions.correct_text: Complete the current sprint as planned, then hold an emergency backlog refinement session with all stakeholders before the next sprint planning
questions.explanation:
Agile planning respects sprint boundaries while remaining adaptive to change. Completing the current sprint preserves the team's commitment and rhythm, while the refinement session ensures stakeholder alignment before pivoting. Terminating mid-sprint (B) undermines sprint integrity without evidence that the current work is valueless. Unilateral decisions (C) bypass stakeholder collaboration. Splitting the team (D) fragments capacity and introduces coordination overhead without proper planning.
*Domains Tested:* Domain V (Adaptive Planning) + Domain III (Stakeholder Engagement) + Domain II (Value-Driven Delivery)

questions.stem: During a sprint review, a stakeholder expresses frustration that the delivered increment does not match their expectations, despite the features meeting all documented acceptance criteria. The product owner confirms the criteria were met. The team feels demoralised because they believe they delivered exactly what was asked. The stakeholder insists on immediate rework. What is the BEST course of action?

options.A: Agree to the rework and add it to the next sprint backlog to maintain stakeholder satisfaction
options.B: Show the stakeholder the acceptance criteria documentation and explain that the work meets the agreed standards
options.C: Facilitate a deeper conversation to uncover the gap between written criteria and the stakeholder's mental model, then collaboratively determine whether adjustments belong in the backlog
options.D: Suggest the stakeholder work more closely with the product owner on writing clearer acceptance criteria in the future

questions.correct_text: Facilitate a deeper conversation to uncover the gap between written criteria and the stakeholder's mental model, then collaboratively determine whether adjustments belong in the backlog
questions.explanation:
The root issue is a gap between documented criteria and unstated expectations — a common problem in stakeholder engagement. Simply showing documentation (B) is defensive and does not resolve the disconnect. Automatically agreeing to rework (A) sets a precedent that bypasses the backlog prioritisation process. Deflecting to future improvements (D) does not address the current frustration. Facilitating understanding respects both the team's work and the stakeholder's needs, and channels any changes through proper backlog management.
*Domains Tested:* Domain III (Stakeholder Engagement) + Domain II (Value-Driven Delivery)

questions.stem: A self-organising team of seven developers has been working together for four months. Recently, two senior developers have begun dominating all technical decisions, and the three junior members have stopped contributing during planning sessions. The Scrum Master notices that the team's defect rate has increased by 30% over the last two sprints, and retrospective action items are no longer being completed. What is the MOST LIKELY root cause, and what should the Scrum Master address FIRST?

options.A: The increased defect rate is a quality problem — introduce mandatory code reviews and automated testing gates
options.B: The retrospective process is broken — change the retrospective format to re-engage the team
options.C: The team's self-organisation has degraded into a power imbalance — facilitate a conversation about team dynamics and decision-making practices
options.D: The junior developers need additional training to contribute effectively to technical discussions

questions.correct_text: The team's self-organisation has degraded into a power imbalance — facilitate a conversation about team dynamics and decision-making practices
questions.explanation:
The defect increase and abandoned retrospective actions are symptoms, not root causes. The underlying issue is a breakdown in self-organisation where two members dominate and others disengage. This reduces collective ownership and accountability. Code reviews (A) treat the symptom. Changing the retrospective format (B) may help engagement but does not address the power dynamic driving disengagement. Training juniors (D) assumes they lack skill rather than psychological safety. Addressing the team dynamic restores the collaborative foundation that supports quality and continuous improvement.
*Domains Tested:* Domain IV (Team Performance) + Domain I (Agile Principles & Mindset) + Domain VII (Continuous Improvement)

questions.stem: A distributed agile team across three time zones has a product owner located in the same city as only one of the three sub-teams. The other two sub-teams report feeling disconnected from product decisions and have started building features based on their own interpretations of user stories. The team's cycle time has increased from 3 days to 8 days over the past month. What should the Scrum Master do FIRST?

options.A: Request that the product owner relocate to a neutral time zone or rotate physical presence across all locations
options.B: Establish asynchronous communication protocols and recorded product backlog refinement sessions accessible to all sub-teams, supplemented by rotating synchronous sessions
options.C: Consolidate all team members into a single location to restore face-to-face communication
options.D: Assign a proxy product owner to each remote sub-team to ensure consistent interpretation of requirements

questions.correct_text: Establish asynchronous communication protocols and recorded product backlog refinement sessions accessible to all sub-teams, supplemented by rotating synchronous sessions
questions.explanation:
The core problem is information asymmetry caused by co-location bias. The sub-team near the product owner has better access to context, creating an uneven understanding of requirements. Relocation (A) is impractical and addresses proximity rather than communication. Consolidation (C) ignores the distributed reality. Proxy product owners (D) introduce translation layers that can further distort requirements. Asynchronous protocols with recorded sessions equalise access to product information while rotating synchronous touchpoints maintain human connection across time zones.
*Domains Tested:* Domain III (Stakeholder Engagement) + Domain IV (Team Performance)

questions.stem: An agile coach is working with an organisation that has recently transitioned from waterfall to Scrum. The teams are following Scrum ceremonies, but managers continue to assign individual tasks to team members and measure individual utilisation rates. Team members report feeling caught between their managers' expectations and the Scrum framework. Velocity has been flat for eight sprints despite the teams' growing familiarity with the domain. What is the BEST approach for the agile coach?

options.A: Coach the managers on servant leadership principles and the impact of individual task assignment on self-organisation and team velocity
options.B: Recommend that the organisation remove all management layers and let the teams be fully autonomous
options.C: Focus on the teams and help them push back on management interference during sprint planning
options.D: Propose a hybrid approach where managers assign tasks during sprint planning and the team self-organises during execution

questions.correct_text: Coach the managers on servant leadership principles and the impact of individual task assignment on self-organisation and team velocity
questions.explanation:
The organisation is experiencing a common transformation anti-pattern: adopting ceremonies without adopting mindset. Managers measuring utilisation and assigning tasks directly undermines self-organisation — a core agile principle. Removing management (B) is extreme and impractical. Having teams push back (C) creates adversarial dynamics. A hybrid approach (D) institutionalises the dysfunction. Coaching managers addresses the systemic root cause and builds organisational understanding of why self-organisation drives better outcomes.
*Domains Tested:* Domain I (Agile Principles & Mindset) + Domain IV (Team Performance)

questions.stem: A team has been practising Kanban for six months. Their WIP limits are set at 5 for development and 3 for testing. The team notices that items frequently queue between development and testing, with an average wait time of 2.5 days. Meanwhile, the testing column is rarely at its WIP limit — it averages 1.5 items. The development team argues for increasing their WIP limit to 7, citing that they finish work faster than testers can pull it. What is the BEST response?

options.A: Increase the development WIP limit to 7 as requested, since development capacity exceeds testing capacity
options.B: Decrease the development WIP limit to 3 or 4 to reduce the queue between development and testing, and explore ways to increase testing throughput
options.C: Keep current WIP limits but add a buffer column between development and testing with its own WIP limit
options.D: Cross-train developers to perform testing, eliminating the bottleneck entirely

questions.correct_text: Decrease the development WIP limit to 3 or 4 to reduce the queue between development and testing, and explore ways to increase testing throughput
questions.explanation:
The queue between columns indicates a flow problem. Increasing development WIP (A) would worsen the bottleneck by pushing more items into the queue. A buffer column (C) makes the queue visible but does not resolve it. Cross-training (D) is a long-term improvement but does not address the immediate WIP imbalance. Reducing development WIP limits the inflow to match testing capacity, reducing wait time. Combined with efforts to improve testing throughput, this addresses both the constraint and the system flow — core principles of Lean and value-driven delivery.
*Domains Tested:* Domain II (Value-Driven Delivery) + Domain VI (Problem Detection & Resolution)

questions.stem: During a sprint retrospective, the team identifies that they consistently underestimate complex user stories, leading to incomplete work at sprint end. The team's velocity chart shows a pattern of high commitment (50 points) followed by actual delivery of 35-38 points for the last four sprints. The product owner is frustrated because release planning is unreliable. The team suggests using only T-shirt sizing instead of story points. What should the Scrum Master recommend?

options.A: Adopt T-shirt sizing as the team suggests, since estimation is a team decision and their buy-in matters most
options.B: Investigate the root cause of the estimation gap — determine whether the issue is poor decomposition, hidden complexity, or optimism bias — before changing the estimation technique
options.C: Use the actual velocity of 35-38 points for future sprint planning and stop trying to fix the estimation gap
options.D: Bring in an external estimation expert to calibrate the team's story point scale

questions.correct_text: Investigate the root cause of the estimation gap — determine whether the issue is poor decomposition, hidden complexity, or optimism bias — before changing the estimation technique
questions.explanation:
Switching estimation techniques (A) without understanding why the current approach fails risks carrying the same problems into a new format. Using actual velocity (C) accepts the symptom without addressing the underlying cause, and does not help the team improve. An external expert (D) undermines team ownership of their process. The gap between commitment and delivery could stem from multiple causes — each requiring different interventions. Root cause analysis before changing tools respects both continuous improvement principles and adaptive planning discipline.
*Domains Tested:* Domain V (Adaptive Planning) + Domain VII (Continuous Improvement)

questions.stem: An agile team is delivering a healthcare application with strict regulatory requirements. The product owner has prioritised a set of user-facing features for the next release, but the team's tech lead warns that the current architecture will not pass an upcoming security audit unless significant refactoring is completed. The refactoring work has no direct user value and will consume approximately two full sprints. The release date is fixed at five sprints away. Stakeholders are expecting all prioritised features by the release date. What should the team do?

options.A: Deliver the user-facing features first and address the refactoring after the release, accepting the audit risk
options.B: Work with the product owner to make the refactoring visible in the backlog, communicate the trade-off to stakeholders, and collaboratively re-plan the release scope
options.C: Have the tech lead and one developer work on refactoring in parallel while the rest of the team delivers features
options.D: Request a release date extension from stakeholders to accommodate both the features and the refactoring

questions.correct_text: Work with the product owner to make the refactoring visible in the backlog, communicate the trade-off to stakeholders, and collaboratively re-plan the release scope
questions.explanation:
In a regulated environment, ignoring audit requirements (A) creates unacceptable compliance risk. Parallel work streams (C) fragment the team and may not produce a coherent architecture. Requesting an extension (D) may not be feasible with a fixed release and bypasses the prioritisation conversation. Making the technical debt visible and engaging stakeholders in scope trade-offs is the agile approach — it respects transparency, stakeholder collaboration, and value-driven delivery by letting informed parties make informed decisions about scope versus risk.
*Domains Tested:* Domain II (Value-Driven Delivery) + Domain III (Stakeholder Engagement) + Domain V (Adaptive Planning)

questions.stem: A team practising SAFe (Scaled Agile Framework) is participating in a PI (Program Increment) planning event. During planning, they discover that a critical dependency on another team's deliverable will not be available until the third sprint of the PI, but their feature requires it in the first sprint. The other team's Scrum Master says their backlog is already committed and they cannot reprioritise. The RTE (Release Train Engineer) suggests the dependent team simply work overtime to deliver earlier. What is the BEST course of action?

options.A: Accept the RTE's suggestion and have the dependent team work overtime to meet the earlier deadline
options.B: Negotiate with both teams and the product management group to find an alternative sequencing that respects both teams' capacity while minimising the delay to the dependent feature
options.C: Remove the dependency by having the requesting team build the needed component themselves
options.D: Escalate to senior leadership to force the dependent team to reprioritise

questions.correct_text: Negotiate with both teams and the product management group to find an alternative sequencing that respects both teams' capacity while minimising the delay to the dependent feature
questions.explanation:
Overtime (A) is unsustainable and violates the agile principle of maintaining a sustainable pace. Building the component independently (C) may duplicate effort and create integration problems. Escalation (D) undermines team autonomy and collaborative problem-solving. Negotiating alternative sequencing across teams and product management respects both teams' autonomy and capacity while seeking a system-level optimisation — a core principle of agile at scale. This approach also strengthens cross-team collaboration for future PIs.
*Domains Tested:* Domain I (Agile Principles & Mindset) + Domain V (Adaptive Planning) + Domain III (Stakeholder Engagement)

questions.stem: A Scrum team has completed 12 sprints and is preparing for a major product release. During the release sprint, the QA lead reports that 15% of all user stories delivered across the last four sprints have escaped defects discovered during final regression testing. The product owner wants to release on schedule despite the defects. The development team wants to delay the release to fix all defects. The Scrum Master must mediate. What should the Scrum Master do?

options.A: Support the product owner's decision to release on schedule since the product owner owns release decisions
options.B: Support the development team's position to delay, since releasing known defects violates the Definition of Done
options.C: Facilitate a risk-based discussion between the product owner, team, and stakeholders to categorise defects by severity and collaboratively decide which must be fixed before release and which can be deferred
options.D: Propose releasing with the defects but immediately beginning a stabilisation sprint to fix all issues post-release

questions.correct_text: Facilitate a risk-based discussion between the product owner, team, and stakeholders to categorise defects by severity and collaboratively decide which must be fixed before release and which can be deferred
questions.explanation:
The Scrum Master's role is to facilitate, not to side with either party. Blindly supporting the product owner (A) or the team (B) ignores the legitimate concerns of the other side. A post-release stabilisation sprint (D) assumes the defects are acceptable to ship — a business decision that should not be made unilaterally. A risk-based, collaborative discussion respects both value delivery (the release has business value) and quality (some defects may be release-blocking). This approach exemplifies servant leadership and transparent decision-making.
*Domains Tested:* Domain II (Value-Driven Delivery) + Domain VI (Problem Detection & Resolution) + Domain III (Stakeholder Engagement)

questions.stem: An agile team has been using a Definition of Done (DoD) that includes unit testing, code review, and basic functional testing. After several releases, production incidents have increased, and the operations team reports that most issues relate to integration failures and performance degradation under load. The team's retrospective identifies that integration and performance testing are not part of the current DoD. The product owner argues that adding these will slow velocity by 20-30%. What should the team do?

options.A: Keep the current DoD and add integration and performance testing as separate backlog items when time permits
options.B: Expand the DoD to include integration and performance testing, accept the velocity reduction, and communicate the impact to stakeholders with an explanation of the long-term quality benefits
options.C: Create a separate "hardening sprint" every fourth sprint dedicated to integration and performance testing
options.D: Hire additional QA specialists to handle integration and performance testing without impacting the team's velocity

questions.correct_text: Expand the DoD to include integration and performance testing, accept the velocity reduction, and communicate the impact to stakeholders with an explanation of the long-term quality benefits
questions.explanation:
The DoD should reflect what "done" truly means for the product to be releasable. Treating testing as separate backlog items (A) makes quality optional and subject to deprioritisation. Hardening sprints (C) create a mini-waterfall pattern and delay defect discovery. Hiring QA specialists (D) separates quality from the team, undermining collective ownership. Accepting the velocity reduction is honest — the previous velocity was artificially inflated by excluding necessary work. Transparent communication about why velocity decreases while quality increases builds stakeholder trust.
*Domains Tested:* Domain VII (Continuous Improvement) + Domain II (Value-Driven Delivery) + Domain I (Agile Principles & Mindset)

questions.stem: A newly formed agile team is in their third sprint. During the daily standup, a developer mentions they have been blocked for two days waiting for database access credentials from the IT security team.
