questions.explanation: The Theory of Constraints (Goldratt) prescribes five steps: (1) Identify the constraint, (2) Exploit it (maximize throughput without major investment), (3) Subordinate everything else to it, (4) Elevate it (invest to increase capacity), (5) Repeat. Before automating (elevating), the team should first exploit — perhaps by streamlining test cases, cross-training testers, or reducing batch sizes.

questions.stem: A team practices Kaizen. In the context of agile software development, what does Kaizen MOST closely mean?

options.A: A one-time radical process overhaul
options.B: Continuous, incremental improvement in all aspects of the process
options.C: A specific improvement event lasting one week
options.D: Eliminating all processes and starting fresh

questions.correct_text: Continuous, incremental improvement in all aspects of the process
questions.explanation: Kaizen (Japanese for "change for better") is a philosophy of continuous, small, incremental improvements. In agile, it manifests through retrospectives, daily process adjustments, and a culture where everyone contributes improvement ideas. While Kaizen events (blitzes) are focused improvement periods, the broader concept is an ongoing mindset of constant betterment embedded in daily work.

questions.stem: A team uses Test-Driven Development (TDD). A developer writes a failing test before writing any production code. What is the correct TDD cycle?

options.A: Write code → Write test → Refactor
options.B: Write test (Red) → Write minimum code to pass (Green) → Refactor
options.C: Write test → Write documentation → Write code
options.D: Write code → Test → Fix bugs → Refactor

questions.correct_text: Write test (Red) → Write minimum code to pass (Green) → Refactor
questions.explanation: TDD follows the Red-Green-Refactor cycle: Red (write a failing test), Green (write the minimum code to make the test pass), Refactor (improve the code structure without changing behavior). This approach ensures all code has test coverage, promotes simple design, and provides a safety net for refactoring. The test drives the design of the code, not the other way around.

questions.stem: A development team has been refactoring their codebase to improve maintainability. A stakeholder questions why the team is spending time on work that doesn't deliver new features. How should the team explain the value of refactoring?

options.A: "Refactoring is optional and we can stop if you prefer"
options.B: "Refactoring improves code structure without changing behavior, making future feature delivery faster and reducing defect rates"
options.C: "Refactoring is required by our development methodology"
options.D: "Refactoring adds new functionality that users will appreciate"

questions.correct_text: "Refactoring improves code structure without changing behavior, making future feature delivery faster and reducing defect rates"
questions.explanation: Refactoring is the process of improving code structure without changing external behavior. It reduces technical debt, makes the codebase easier to understand and modify, and reduces defect rates. The business value is that future features will be delivered faster and with fewer bugs. It's an investment in sustainable delivery pace — neglecting it leads to ever-increasing development costs.

questions.stem: An organization establishes a group where Scrum Masters from different teams meet biweekly to share practices, discuss challenges, and learn from each other. What is this group called?

options.A: Scrum of Scrums
options.B: Community of Practice
options.C: Product Advisory Board
options.D: Agile Release Train

questions.correct_text: Community of Practice
questions.explanation: A Community of Practice (CoP) is a group of people who share a common interest or role and meet regularly to share knowledge, discuss challenges, and develop their craft. CoPs are voluntary, cross-team, and focused on learning and improvement rather than delivery coordination. A Scrum of Scrums coordinates delivery across teams, while a CoP builds capability across the organization.

questions.stem: A team conducts a retrospective using the "Sailboat" format. They identify an anchor (something slowing them down): "Our automated test suite takes 45 minutes to run, discouraging developers from running tests frequently." Using continuous improvement principles, what is the MOST appropriate improvement action?

options.A: Tell developers to run the full test suite less frequently
options.B: Investigate and implement strategies to reduce test execution time (parallel execution, test optimization, selective test runs) and measure the improvement
options.C: Remove automated tests to speed up the process
options.D: Add more developers to run tests on different machines

questions.correct_text: Investigate and implement strategies to reduce test execution time (parallel execution, test optimization, selective test runs) and measure the improvement
questions.explanation: This is a classic continuous improvement opportunity. The team should apply the scientific method: hypothesis (faster tests = more frequent testing = fewer defects), experiment (parallelization, test refactoring, selective runs), measure (execution time, test frequency, defect rates), and iterate. Removing tests or avoiding them undermines quality. The goal is to make quality practices easy and fast.

questions.stem:
An organisation has been running SAFe for two years. During a PI Planning event, three Agile Release Trains (ARTs) identify 47 cross-ART dependencies. The Release Train Engineer (RTE) proposes adding a dedicated "dependency management team" to track and resolve these dependencies between PIs. An experienced SAFe Program Consultant (SPC) disagrees with this approach.

Why would the SPC MOST likely disagree?

options.A: Dependencies should be tracked in Jira, not by a dedicated team
options.B: Adding a dependency management team treats the symptom (dependency volume) rather than the root cause (architectural coupling and insufficient team autonomy) — SAFe's principle of decentralising decision-making and building architectural runway should be used to reduce dependencies, not manage them
options.C: The RTE should manage all dependencies personally as part of their role
options.D: 47 dependencies is within acceptable range for three ARTs and does not require intervention

questions.correct_text: Adding a dependency management team treats the symptom (dependency volume) rather than the root cause (architectural coupling and insufficient team autonomy) — SAFe's principle of decentralising decision-making and building architectural runway should be used to reduce dependencies, not manage them
questions.explanation: SAFe Lean-Agile Principle #9 is "Decentralize decision-making." High dependency counts signal tight architectural coupling between ARTs, meaning teams cannot deliver value independently. The correct SAFe response is to invest in architectural runway (enabler work that reduces coupling), restructure teams around value streams to minimise hand-offs, and empower teams to resolve dependencies directly rather than through a centralised coordinator. A dependency management team adds bureaucracy without addressing why dependencies exist. Option A focuses on tooling rather than the structural issue. Option C overloads the RTE role. Option D ignores a significant coordination risk.

questions.stem:
A Scrum Master is coaching a team that has adopted all XP engineering practices: TDD, pair programming, continuous integration, collective code ownership, and refactoring. Despite this, their defect rate remains high. Analysis reveals that the team writes unit tests after code (not before), pairs rotate every 2 hours (fragmenting context), and CI builds run nightly rather than on every commit.

What is the CORE issue?

options.A: XP practices are not suitable for this team's technology stack
options.B: The team is performing the practices mechanically without understanding the underlying principles — TDD requires writing tests first (Red-Green-Refactor), pairing should be sustained for meaningful collaboration, and CI must provide immediate feedback on every commit
options.C: The team needs to add additional practices like ATDD and BDD
options.D: The Scrum Master should enforce stricter adherence to practice rules through daily audits

questions.correct_text: The team is performing the practices mechanically without understanding the underlying principles — TDD requires writing tests first (Red-Green-Refactor), pairing should be sustained for meaningful collaboration, and CI must provide immediate feedback on every commit
questions.explanation: This parallels the "doing Agile vs. being Agile" distinction applied to engineering practices. TDD's Red-Green-Refactor cycle specifically requires writing the test first (Red), then writing minimal code to pass (Green), then refactoring. Writing tests after code is "test-after development" and misses TDD's design benefit. CI's value is immediate feedback — nightly builds delay error detection by hours. Pair programming works through sustained shared context, not brief rotations. The team has adopted the labels but not the substance. Option A blames the practices rather than the execution. Option C adds complexity before fixing fundamentals. Option D imposes command-and-control which contradicts Agile's self-organisation principle.

questions.stem:
A company's board of directors mandates that all projects must have fixed scope, fixed budget, and fixed deadline — the "iron triangle" locked on all three sides. The CTO, an Agile advocate, must respond.

Which response BEST reflects Agile thinking while addressing the board's legitimate governance concerns?

options.A: Refuse the mandate — Agile cannot work with fixed constraints
options.B: Accept the mandate and use Waterfall for all projects
options.C: Propose fixing budget and deadline while managing scope through a prioritised backlog with MoSCoW categories, guaranteeing delivery of "Must Have" items within the constraints and treating "Should/Could/Won't" as flexible — this gives the board cost and time certainty while preserving Agile's scope flexibility
options.D: Fix scope and budget but negotiate flexible deadlines

questions.correct_text: Propose fixing budget and deadline while managing scope through a prioritised backlog with MoSCoW categories, guaranteeing delivery of "Must Have" items within the constraints and treating "Should/Could/Won't" as flexible — this gives the board cost and time certainty while preserving Agile's scope flexibility
questions.explanation: Agile does not require that all constraints be flexible — it requires that at least one be variable. The DSDM/AgilePM approach explicitly fixes time and cost while varying scope through MoSCoW prioritisation. The board's need for budget and deadline certainty is legitimate governance. By guaranteeing "Must Have" delivery (which should represent ~60% of scope) and treating lower-priority items as flexible, the CTO satisfies governance requirements while maintaining Agile's ability to adapt. This is the Graduated Fixed Price contract model adapted to internal governance. Option A is unnecessarily adversarial. Option B abandons Agile entirely. Option D is often impractical for budget-constrained organisations.

questions.stem:
A Lean-Agile coach is assessing an organisation using the Disciplined Agile (DA) framework. She observes that every team uses identical 2-week Scrum sprints, the same Definition of Done, and the same retrospective format — regardless of whether the team does new product development, maintenance, or data science work.

Which DA principle does this MOST directly violate?

options.A: Enterprise Awareness
options.B: Choice Is Good — teams should choose their own Way of Working (WoW) based on their context
options.C: Optimise Flow
options.D: Delight Customers

questions.correct_text: Choice Is Good — teams should choose their own Way of Working (WoW) based on their context
questions.explanation: Disciplined Agile's core differentiator is its "Choice Is Good" principle and the concept of process decision points — teams select their Way of Working (WoW) based on context factors including team size, skills, culture, domain complexity, and work type. A maintenance team may benefit from Kanban's continuous flow rather than sprint boundaries. A data science team may need longer iterations due to experimental cycles. Mandating identical processes for all teams regardless of context directly contradicts DA's philosophy. Option A (Enterprise Awareness) is about understanding organisational context, not team-level process choices. Options C and D are DA principles but are not the ones most directly violated by this scenario.

questions.stem:
During a portfolio review, an executive asks: "Our competitors are releasing features monthly. We release quarterly. How do we catch up?" The Agile transformation lead considers three approaches: (1) Add more developers to each team, (2) Reduce sprint length from 4 weeks to 2 weeks, (3) Identify and eliminate organisational impediments that create wait times between teams.

Which approach is MOST aligned with Lean thinking?

options.A: Approach 1 — more capacity means more output
options.B: Approach 2 — shorter sprints mean faster delivery
options.C: Approach 3 — Lean focuses on eliminating waste (muda), and wait times between teams represent the waste of "waiting" — addressing flow efficiency (ratio of value-adding time to total lead time) will have a greater impact than adding capacity or shortening iterations
options.D: All three approaches should be implemented simultaneously

questions.correct_text: Approach 3 — Lean focuses on eliminating waste (muda), and wait times between teams represent the waste of "waiting" — addressing flow efficiency (ratio of value-adding time to total lead time) will have a greater impact than adding capacity or shortening iterations
questions.explanation: Lean thinking identifies 7 wastes (muda), with "waiting" being one of the most common in knowledge work. Flow efficiency measures the percentage of total lead time spent on value-adding work versus waiting. In most organisations, flow efficiency is 15-35%, meaning 65-85% of lead time is wait time. Addressing these systemic delays (handoffs, approvals, queues, shared services) dramatically reduces lead time without adding resources. Approach 1 risks Brooks's Law (adding people to a late project makes it later) and increases coordination overhead. Approach 2 is tactical but does not address root causes — the team may deliver faster within sprints but wait the same time between them. Option D ignores the principle of addressing root causes first.

questions.stem:
An organisation is debating between adopting LeSS (Large-Scale Scrum) and Nexus for their 6-team product development group building a single platform. Both frameworks support multi-team Scrum, but they differ in key areas.

Which statement MOST accurately distinguishes between LeSS and Nexus for this scenario?

options.A: LeSS is for 2-8 teams and emphasises descaling (removing unnecessary organisational complexity), a single Product Owner, a single Product Backlog, and a shared Sprint — while Nexus adds a Nexus Integration Team responsible for integration and a Nexus Sprint Backlog to manage cross-team dependencies
options.B: LeSS requires SAFe-style PI planning while Nexus does not
options.C: Nexus supports more teams than LeSS
options.D: LeSS and Nexus are essentially identical and the choice does not matter

questions.correct_text: LeSS is for 2-8 teams and emphasises descaling (removing unnecessary organisational complexity), a single Product Owner, a single Product Backlog, and a shared Sprint — while Nexus adds a Nexus Integration Team responsible for integration and a Nexus Sprint Backlog to manage cross-team dependencies
questions.explanation: LeSS (by Craig Larman and Bas Vodde) emphasises simplicity and descaling — it argues that most scaling complexity is unnecessary organisational overhead and should be removed rather than managed. LeSS uses a single PO, single backlog, shared sprint, and joint Sprint Review. LeSS Huge extends to 8+ teams. Nexus (by Ken Schwaber, co-creator of Scrum) adds the Nexus Integration Team (NIT) as a coordination layer and introduces the Nexus Sprint Backlog and Nexus Daily Scrum as integration-focused events. For 6 teams, both are viable, but LeSS favours organisational simplification while Nexus favours structured integration management. Option B is incorrect — LeSS does not use PI Planning. Option C is incorrect — LeSS Huge scales beyond Nexus. Option D ignores meaningful framework differences.

questions.stem:
A Scrum team's velocity over the last 8 sprints is: 28, 30, 26, 32, 29, 31, 27, 30. Management asks the Scrum Master to "increase velocity by 20%" in the next quarter. The Scrum Master is uncomfortable with this request.

What is the PRIMARY reason the Scrum Master should push back?

options.A: Velocity cannot be increased — it is a fixed measure
options.B: Velocity is a planning and forecasting tool for the team, not a performance or productivity metric — treating it as a target incentivises gaming behaviours such as inflating story points, reducing quality, or avoiding difficult stories, which undermines the integrity of the planning process
options.C: 20% increase is unrealistic; 10% would be acceptable
options.D: Velocity should only be discussed during retrospectives, not with management

questions.correct_text: Velocity is a planning and forecasting tool for the team, not a performance or productivity metric — treating it as a target incentivises gaming behaviours such as inflating story points, reducing quality, or avoiding difficult stories, which undermines the integrity of the planning process
questions.explanation: Velocity measures a team's historical delivery rate for forecasting purposes. When management treats velocity as a performance target, Goodhart's Law applies: "When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure." Teams will inflate story point estimates (point inflation), reduce testing time to close more stories (quality erosion), avoid complex stories that carry risk (cherry-picking), and split stories into trivially small items. The Scrum Master should educate management that outcome-based metrics (customer satisfaction, cycle time, defect rates, business value delivered) are better indicators of team performance. Option A is factually incorrect — velocity can change. Option C negotiates the wrong thing — no velocity target is appropriate. Option D restricts legitimate conversations about delivery.

questions.stem:
A mature Agile organisation is considering moving beyond Scrum and Kanban. The head of engineering asks an Agile coach about Crystal, specifically Crystal Clear for their small, co-located teams. The coach explains that Crystal differs fundamentally from Scrum in its approach.

What is the MOST accurate characterisation of Crystal's philosophical difference from Scrum?

options.A: Crystal prescribes fewer ceremonies than Scrum
options.B: Crystal prioritises people and communication over process, using a "reflective improvement" cycle — it prescribes properties that projects must have (frequent delivery, reflective improvement, osmotic communication, personal safety, focus, access to expert users) rather than prescribing specific practices, allowing teams to choose practices that achieve these properties
options.C: Crystal does not support iterations
options.D: Crystal is only for teams of 6 or fewer

questions.correct_text: Crystal prioritises people and communication over process, using a "reflective improvement" cycle — it prescribes properties that projects must have (frequent delivery, reflective improvement, osmotic communication, personal safety, focus, access to expert users) rather than prescribing specific practices, allowing teams to choose practices that achieve these properties
questions.explanation: Alistair Cockburn's Crystal family of methodologies differs from Scrum by prescribing required project properties rather than specific practices. Crystal Clear (for teams of ≤8) requires 7 properties: frequent delivery, reflective improvement, osmotic communication, personal safety, focus, easy access to expert users, and technical environment with automated testing/CI. Teams select their own practices to achieve these properties, making Crystal more flexible than Scrum's prescribed events and roles. Crystal variants (Clear, Yellow, Orange, Red) scale by team size and project criticality. Option A oversimplifies the difference. Option C is incorrect — Crystal supports iterative delivery. Option D confuses Crystal Clear (≤8) with the broader Crystal family.

questions.stem:
During an Agile transformation, the HR department maintains individual performance reviews based on personal KPIs. Developers are evaluated on lines of code written, testers on bugs found, and business analysts on requirements documents produced. An Agile coach identifies this as a significant transformation impediment.

Why is this performance system MOST problematic from an Agile perspective?

options.A: Individual KPIs are always inappropriate in any context
options.B: These specific metrics incentivise individual optimisation at the expense of team outcomes — developers write more code (even unnecessary code), testers find more bugs (rather than preventing them), and BAs produce more documents (rather than collaborating directly) — this undermines the Agile principle that self-organising cross-functional teams collectively own quality and outcomes
options.C: Performance reviews should be eliminated entirely in Agile organisations
options.D: The metrics are fine but should be reviewed quarterly instead of annually

questions.correct_text: These specific metrics incentivise individual optimisation at the expense of team outcomes — developers write more code (even unnecessary code), testers find more bugs (rather than preventing them), and BAs produce more documents (rather than collaborating directly) — this undermines the Agile principle that self-organising cross-functional teams collectively own quality and outcomes
questions.explanation: These metrics create perverse incentives that directly conflict with Agile values. Lines of code incentivises code bloat rather than elegant solutions (violating YAGNI and simplicity). Bugs found incentivises testers to find defects rather than prevent them through collaboration (undermining shift-left quality). Documents produced incentivises documentation over conversation (contradicting Manifesto value 1). Agile teams should be measured on team-level outcomes: working software delivered, customer satisfaction, cycle time, and quality metrics that the whole team owns. Option A is too absolute — some individual metrics can complement team metrics. Option C is extreme — reviews can be restructured around team contributions and growth. Option D changes frequency but not the fundamental measurement problem.

questions.stem:
A team is using Scrum@Scale across 25 teams. The Executive Action Team (EAT) is responsible for organisational impediment removal, and the Executive MetaScrum (EMS) manages the portfolio backlog and strategic alignment. A recurring problem is that the EAT takes 3-4 weeks to resolve impediments escalated from team-level Scrum Masters.

What does this delay MOST likely indicate?

options.A: The EAT needs more members
options.B: The EAT is not empowered with sufficient organisational authority to remove impediments quickly, or the impediments being escalated are symptoms of deeper structural problems that require organisational redesign rather than tactical fixes
options.C: Teams should stop escalating impediments and resolve everything locally
options.D: Scrum@Scale is not the right framework and SAFe should be adopted instead

questions.correct_text: The EAT is not empowered with sufficient organisational authority to remove impediments quickly, or the impediments being escalated are symptoms of deeper structural problems that require organisational redesign rather than tactical fixes
questions.explanation: In Jeff Sutherland's Scrum@Scale, the EAT must be empowered executives who can make rapid organisational decisions. A 3-4 week resolution time suggests either the EAT lacks decision-making authority (perhaps requiring additional approvals), or the impediments are structural (e.g., shared services bottlenecks, organisational silos, policy constraints) that cannot be resolved with tactical fixes. The Scrum@Scale framework explicitly states that the EAT must "set the minimum viable bureaucracy." Option A assumes the problem is capacity when it may be authority. Option C ignores that some impediments genuinely require executive intervention. Option D changes frameworks without diagnosing the root cause.

questions.stem:
An Agile coach uses the Cynefin framework during a strategy session. A product initiative involves building a recommendation engine using machine learning — a domain where the team has no prior experience and the market impact is uncertain. The coach categorises this as a "Complex" domain.

Which approach should the coach recommend?

options.A: Hire experts and follow best practices from similar implementations
options.B: Create a detailed project plan with milestones and deliverables before starting
options.C: Design safe-to-fail probes — small, cheap experiments that test hypotheses about the ML approach and market response — then sense the results and respond by amplifying what works and dampening what does not
options.D: Outsource the entire initiative to a specialised ML vendor

questions.correct_text: Design safe-to-fail probes — small, cheap experiments that test hypotheses about the ML approach and market response — then sense the results and respond by amplifying what works and dampening what does not
questions.explanation: In Cynefin's Complex domain, cause and effect can only be understood in retrospect. The appropriate management approach is Probe-Sense-Respond: design safe-to-fail experiments, observe outcomes, and adapt. This is fundamentally different from the Complicated domain's Sense-Analyse-Respond (option A), which relies on expert analysis and best practices. ML with no prior experience in an uncertain market is genuinely complex — there are no best practices to follow because the team must discover what works. Safe-to-fail probes might include: building a minimal ML model on a subset of data, testing with a small user cohort, measuring engagement, and iterating. Option B applies Simple/Obvious domain thinking. Option D transfers risk but does not address internal learning.

questions.stem:
A newly formed Agile team includes members from five different countries, working across three continents. The Scrum Master observes that team members from some cultures are reluctant to challenge the ideas of more senior colleagues, even when they disagree. In contrast, members from other cultures openly debate and push back.

Which concept MOST directly helps the Scrum Master understand and address this dynamic?

options.A: Tuckman's Storming stage — this is normal conflict
options.B: Hofstede's Cultural Dimensions (particularly Power Distance) — cultures with high power distance expect hierarchy and deference to authority, while low power distance cultures encourage egalitarian debate; the Scrum Master must create structural mechanisms (anonymous idea submission, round-robin input, written pre-work) that enable all voices regardless of cultural norms
options.C: The team needs to adopt English as a common language
options.D: Clark's 4 Stages of Psychological Safety — move to Challenger Safety

questions.correct_text: Hofstede's Cultural Dimensions (particularly Power Distance) — cultures with high power distance expect hierarchy and deference to authority, while low power distance cultures encourage egalitarian debate; the Scrum Master must create structural mechanisms (anonymous idea submission, round-robin input, written pre-work) that enable all voices regardless of cultural norms
questions.explanation: Hofstede's Power Distance Index (PDI) measures the degree to which less powerful members of organisations accept and expect power to be distributed unequally. High PDI cultures (e.g., many East Asian, South Asian, and Latin American countries) may consider it inappropriate to challenge seniors publicly. Low PDI cultures (e.g., Scandinavian, Dutch, Australian) encourage flat hierarchies and open debate. The Scrum Master must recognise this is a cultural difference, not a deficiency, and create structural mechanisms that work across cultural norms. Anonymous dot-voting, written input before group discussion, and structured turn-taking ensure that all perspectives are heard. Option A misidentifies the cause. Option C addresses language, not power dynamics. Option D is relevant but does not identify the cultural root cause.

questions.stem:
A Scrum team has been told by their organisation to adopt "Wagile" — running Waterfall phases (requirements, design, build, test) in sequential order but calling each phase a "sprint." The Scrum Master recognises this as a common anti-pattern.

What is the FUNDAMENTAL problem with this "Wagile" approach?

options.A: Sprint names should reflect the Scrum Guide terminology
options.B: Each sprint must produce a potentially shippable increment — sequential phases that defer integration and testing to later "sprints" eliminate the empirical feedback loops (inspect and adapt) that make Agile effective, because working software is not validated until the end
options.C: The sprints should be the same length
options.D: The team should use Kanban instead if they want sequential flow

questions.correct_text: Each sprint must produce a potentially shippable increment — sequential phases that defer integration and testing to later "sprints" eliminate the empirical feedback loops (inspect and adapt) that make Agile effective, because working software is not validated until the end
questions.explanation: "Wagile" or "Water-Scrum-Fall" is an anti-pattern where Waterfall thinking is disguised as Agile by renaming phases as sprints. The fundamental violation is Agile Principle 7: "Working software is the primary measure of progress." If Sprint 1 produces only requirements, Sprint 2 only design, etc., there is no working software until the later sprints. This eliminates the empirical feedback loop that is Scrum's primary value — the ability to inspect a working increment and adapt. The team cannot learn from real user feedback, cannot detect integration problems early, and cannot adjust scope based on emerging knowledge. Each sprint must be cross-functional and produce a done increment.

questions.stem:
An Agile coach is explaining servant leadership to a group of traditional managers. One manager asks: "If I am a servant leader, does that mean I have no authority and just do whatever the team wants?"

Which response MOST accurately describes servant leadership in an Agile context?

options.A: Yes — servant leaders defer all decisions to the team
options.B: Servant leadership means the leader's primary purpose is enabling the team's success by removing impediments, providing resources, shielding from distractions, and coaching growth — the leader retains authority over organisational decisions, strategic direction, and boundary setting while empowering the team to make tactical and technical decisions within those boundaries
options.C: Servant leadership only applies to Scrum Masters, not managers
options.D: Servant leadership means leading by example through personal technical contribution

questions.correct_text: Servant leadership means the leader's primary purpose is enabling the team's success by removing impediments, providing resources, shielding from distractions, and coaching growth — the leader retains authority over organisational decisions, strategic direction, and boundary setting while empowering the team to make tactical and technical decisions within those boundaries
questions.explanation: Robert Greenleaf's servant leadership concept, adopted by Agile, does not eliminate authority — it redirects it. The servant leader asks "How can I help this team succeed?" rather than "How do I control this team's work?" Authority over strategy, organisational boundaries, and resource allocation remains with management. Empowerment over how work is done, technical decisions, and process improvements is delegated to the team. The Scrum Master models servant leadership by removing impediments, facilitating events, and coaching — not by making product or technical decisions. Option A confuses empowerment with abdication. Option C is too narrow. Option D describes technical leadership, not servant leadership.

questions.stem:
A large insurance company is considering Agile adoption but is concerned about regulatory compliance. Their chief compliance officer states: "Agile means no documentation. Our regulators require extensive audit trails. Therefore, Agile is incompatible with our industry."

What is the FLAW in the compliance officer's reasoning?

options.A: The insurance industry is exempt from documentation requirements when using Agile
options.B: The Agile Manifesto states "Working software OVER comprehensive documentation" — it values working software MORE, but explicitly acknowledges documentation has value; Agile teams in regulated industries document what is necessary for compliance while eliminating documentation that adds no value — the key is producing documentation incrementally alongside working software, not eliminating it
options.C: Agile teams should create all documentation at the end of the project
options.D: A separate documentation team should handle compliance requirements

questions.correct_text: The Agile Manifesto states "Working software OVER comprehensive documentation" — it values working software MORE, but explicitly acknowledges documentation has value; Agile teams in regulated industries document what is necessary for compliance while eliminating documentation that adds no value — the key is producing documentation incrementally alongside working software, not eliminating it
questions.explanation: This is the most common misinterpretation of the Agile Manifesto. The Manifesto states: "That is, while there is value in the items on the right, we value the items on the left more." Documentation is explicitly valued — it is not rejected. In regulated industries (finance, healthcare, pharmaceuticals, defence), Agile teams maintain compliance documentation as part of their Definition of Done for each increment. This is actually more effective than Waterfall's approach of producing all documentation at the end, because incremental documentation stays current and is reviewed regularly. DSDM/AgilePM explicitly includes documentation as a deliverable. Option A is factually incorrect. Option C defers documentation like Waterfall. Option D creates a silo that contradicts Agile's cross-functional team principle.

questions.stem:
An organisation uses the Spotify model. Squads are organised into Tribes by business area, and Chapters connect people with similar skills across Squads (e.g., all backend developers). A Guild for "Testing Best Practices" has been created as a voluntary community of interest. After six months, the Guild has not produced any tangible outcomes — meetings are poorly attended and there is no clear agenda.

What is the MOST likely reason for the Guild's failure?

options.A: Guilds should be mandatory, not voluntary
options.B: The Guild lacks a clear purpose, dedicated facilitation, and tangible objectives — communities of practice require a passionate coordinator, a defined problem to solve, regular cadence, and visible outputs to sustain engagement; without these, voluntary communities dissolve due to competing priorities
options.C: The Spotify model is inherently flawed
options.D: Testing should be handled by a centralised QA team, not a Guild

questions.correct_text: The Guild lacks a clear purpose, dedicated facilitation, and tangible objectives — communities of practice require a passionate coordinator, a defined problem to solve, regular cadence, and visible outputs to sustain engagement; without these, voluntary communities dissolve due to competing priorities
questions.explanation: Etienne Wenger's Communities of Practice research shows that successful communities require: a domain (shared area of interest), a community (engaged membership), and a practice (shared resources and artifacts). Guilds in the Spotify model function as Communities of Practice and need active cultivation. A passionate coordinator (not necessarily a manager) who sets agendas, invites speakers, captures decisions, and creates artifacts is essential. Without clear objectives (e.g., "create a testing standards document" or "reduce defect leakage by 30%"), the Guild has no rallying purpose. Option A contradicts the voluntary, self-organising nature that makes Guilds effective. Option C blames the model rather than the implementation. Option D centralises a capability that should be distributed.

questions.stem:
During an Agile assessment, a consultant discovers that a Scrum team has modified Scrum significantly: they hold sprint planning every other sprint, skip the daily standup on Mondays and Fridays, and combine the sprint review and retrospective into a single meeting. The team claims these modifications make them more efficient.

Using the Shu-Ha-Ri model, how should the consultant evaluate these modifications?

options.A: All modifications are unacceptable — Scrum must be followed as prescribed in the Scrum Guide
options.B: The consultant should determine whether the team is in "Shu" (beginner, should follow rules) or "Ha" (experienced, deliberately breaking rules based on understanding) — if the team has less than 6 months of Scrum experience, these modifications likely reflect avoidance of discipline rather than informed adaptation; if the team has extensive experience and can articulate why each modification improves outcomes, they may be in legitimate Ha-stage evolution
options.C: All modifications are acceptable because Agile values flexibility
options.D: The modifications should be reversed for one sprint to test whether the original Scrum events are better

questions.correct_text: The consultant should determine whether the team is in "Shu" (beginner, should follow rules) or "Ha" (experienced, deliberately breaking rules based on understanding) — if the team has less than 6 months of Scrum experience, these modifications likely reflect avoidance of discipline rather than informed adaptation; if the team has extensive experience and can articulate why each modification improves outcomes, they may be in legitimate Ha-stage evolution
questions.explanation: Shu-Ha-Ri is the key evaluation lens. In Shu (typically the first 6-12 months), teams should follow Scrum as prescribed because they do not yet understand why each element exists. Skipping standups or combining review/retro in Shu likely means the team is avoiding discomfort rather than optimising. In Ha (after demonstrating mastery), deliberate modifications based on observed outcomes are healthy evolution. The critical test is: can the team articulate the principle behind each change and demonstrate that outcomes improved? If yes, it is Ha. If the answer is "we just find it more convenient," it is likely premature optimisation. Option A denies Agile's evolutionary nature. Option C ignores the risk of undisciplined modification. Option D is a reasonable experiment but does not provide the analytical framework.

questions.stem:
A programme manager is comparing Scrum@Scale and SAFe for a 50-team transformation. She asks an Agile coach: "What is the single biggest philosophical difference between these two frameworks?"

Which answer is MOST accurate?

options.A: SAFe is for large organisations; Scrum@Scale is for small ones
options.B: SAFe prescribes a comprehensive, structured operating model with defined roles, events, and artifacts at team, programme, large solution, and portfolio levels — Scrum@Scale takes a "minimal viable bureaucracy" approach, scaling Scrum's empirical framework organically through a network of Scrum teams with the EAT and EMS as the primary coordination mechanisms, deliberately avoiding prescriptive structure
options.C: SAFe uses Kanban; Scrum@Scale does not
options.D: Scrum@Scale requires certified coaches; SAFe does not

questions.correct_text: SAFe prescribes a comprehensive, structured operating model with defined roles, events, and artifacts at team, programme, large solution, and portfolio levels — Scrum@Scale takes a "minimal viable bureaucracy" approach, scaling Scrum's empirical framework organically through a network of Scrum teams with the EAT and EMS as the primary coordination mechanisms, deliberately avoiding prescriptive structure
questions.explanation: The fundamental philosophical difference is prescriptive vs. emergent. SAFe (Dean Leffingwell) provides a detailed, comprehensive operating model with explicit configurations (Essential, Large Solution, Portfolio, Full). It defines roles (RTE, Solution Architect, Epic Owner), events (PI Planning, System Demo, I&A), and artifacts (PI Objectives, Solution Kanban, Strategic Themes) at multiple levels. Scrum@Scale (Jeff Sutherland) takes the opposite approach — it provides minimal structure (Scale-Free Architecture) and expects the organisation to evolve its own scaling approach through empirical process control, guided by the EAT and EMS. Neither approach is inherently superior; the choice depends on organisational culture. Option A is incorrect — both can handle large-scale. Options C and D are factually wrong.

questions.stem:
An Agile team is working in a Cynefin "Complicated" domain — building a payment processing integration with well-understood requirements but complex technical implementation. The team has access to subject matter experts in payment systems.

Which management approach is MOST appropriate for this domain?

options.A: Probe-Sense-Respond — run experiments to discover what works
options.B: Sense-Analyse-Respond — analyse the situation, apply expert knowledge and good practices (not "best" practices, as multiple valid approaches exist), and implement a solution informed by the SMEs' experience
options.C: Act-Sense-Respond — take immediate action to stabilise
options.D: Sense-Categorise-Respond — apply established best practices

questions.correct_text: Sense-Analyse-Respond — analyse the situation, apply expert knowledge and good practices (not "best" practices, as multiple valid approaches exist), and implement a solution informed by the SMEs' experience
questions.explanation: Cynefin's Complicated domain is characterised by knowable cause-and-effect relationships that require expert analysis to understand. The approach is Sense-Analyse-Respond: gather information, apply expert analysis, and implement. Importantly, Snowden distinguishes between "good practices" (Complicated) and "best practices" (Obvious/Clear). In the Complicated domain, multiple valid approaches exist — SMEs can evaluate and recommend the most suitable one. Payment integration with known requirements but complex implementation fits this domain well. Option A is for the Complex domain (unknown cause-and-effect). Option C is for the Chaotic domain (no cause-and-effect, stabilise first). Option D describes the Obvious/Clear domain where a single best practice exists.

questions.stem: A PO calculates WSJF for Story A: Business Value = 8, Time Criticality = 5, Risk Reduction = 3, Job Size = 2. What is the WSJF score?
questions.explanation: WSJF = Cost of Delay / Job Size. CoD = 8+5+3 = 16. WSJF = 16/2 = 8.0.

questions.stem: A fintech startup's MVP includes: account creation, balance viewing, transfers, bill pay, portfolio management, crypto, and budgeting tools. What is wrong?

options.A: Too technical
options.B: This is a full product, not an MVP — an MVP tests the core value hypothesis with minimum features and generates validated learning
options.C: Needs security features
options.D: All features should be simplified versions

questions.correct_text: This is a full product, not an MVP — an MVP tests the core value hypothesis with minimum features and generates validated learning
questions.explanation: Eric Ries's MVP is about validated learning. Seven major features is a full banking app. A genuine MVP identifies the riskiest assumption and builds the minimum to test it.

questions.stem: MoSCoW backlog: Must Have = 800 points, Should = 300, Could = 150, Won't = 50. Capacity = 600 points. What is the critical risk?

options.A: Too many Won't Have stories
options.B: Must Haves (800 pts) exceed total capacity (600 pts) — MoSCoW requires Must Haves ≤60% of effort; at 133% capacity, even mandatory items cannot all be delivered
options.C: Not enough Could Have
options.D: Velocity too low

questions.correct_text: Must Haves (800 pts) exceed total capacity (600 pts) — MoSCoW requires Must Haves ≤60% of effort; at 133% capacity, even mandatory items cannot all be delivered
questions.explanation: DSDM recommends Must Haves ≤60% for contingency buffer. Here Must Haves alone require 133% of capacity. PO must reclassify or reduce scope.

questions.stem: Agile EVM at Sprint 3 (50% complete): BAC=$240K, PV=$120K, EV=$96K, AC=$108K. Calculate CPI and SPI.
questions.explanation: CPI = EV/AC = 96K/108K = 0.89 (over budget). SPI = EV/PV = 96K/120K = 0.80 (behind schedule).

questions.stem: From Q23: BAC=$240K, CPI=0.89. Calculate EAC (Estimate at Completion).
questions.explanation: EAC = BAC/CPI = $240K/0.89 = $269,663. Project will cost ~$30K over budget if cost performance continues.

questions.stem: Feature A: high satisfaction present, not missed absent. Feature B: dissatisfaction absent, neutral present. Kano classification?

options.A: A = Must-Be, B = Attractive
options.B: A = Attractive (Delighter), B = Must-Be (Basic)
options.C: Both Performance
options.D: A = Must-Be, B = Performance

questions.correct_text: A = Attractive (Delighter), B = Must-Be (Basic)
questions.explanation: Kano: Must-Be = dissatisfaction absent, neutral present. Attractive = delight present, not missed absent. Feature A = Attractive, Feature B = Must-Be.

questions.stem: Team's DoD includes deployment to staging. PO wants "deployed to production" but a 2-week CAB blocks it. Recommendation?

options.A: Accept current DoD
options.B: Streamline the CAB through automated compliance and pre-approved deployment pipelines — the staging-to-production gap is undone work creating risk
options.C: Remove deployment from DoD
options.D: Extend sprint length

questions.correct_text: Streamline the CAB through automated compliance and pre-approved deployment pipelines — the staging-to-production gap is undone work creating risk
questions.explanation: The Scrum Guide requires potentially releasable increments. The Scrum Master should address the organisational impediment by proposing automated checks and risk-based approvals.

questions.stem: A team does Jeff Patton story mapping. How to identify the MVP boundary?

options.A: Top 20 stories by value
options.B: Draw a horizontal line — stories above form the "walking skeleton" (thin end-to-end slice across all activities); stories below add depth in later releases
options.C: Build backend first
options.D: Stakeholder voting

questions.correct_text: Draw a horizontal line — stories above form the "walking skeleton" (thin end-to-end slice across all activities); stories below add depth in later releases
questions.explanation: Story mapping's walking skeleton ensures the MVP is a complete user journey, not just high-value stories clustered in one area.

questions.stem: User story: "As an admin, I want to manage users so the system is organised." Problems?

options.A: Missing acceptance criteria and vague value statement — "manage users" is too broad, "system is organised" lacks genuine business value
options.B: Too long
options.C: Wrong author
options.D: Needs estimate first

questions.correct_text: Missing acceptance criteria and vague value statement — "manage users" is too broad, "system is organised" lacks genuine business value
questions.explanation: Missing Confirmation (Three C's) and violates INVEST — not Valuable (vague benefit), not Small/Estimable ("manage users" is an epic).

questions.stem: Stakeholder asks for "business value delivered" not just features. Best metrics?

options.A: Velocity and story points
options.B: Outcome-based: user adoption rate, business KPI impact, support ticket reduction, NPS — these measure value created, not software produced
options.C: Lines of code and defects
options.D: Burndown chart

questions.correct_text: Outcome-based: user adoption rate, business KPI impact, support ticket reduction, NPS — these measure value created, not software produced
questions.explanation: Output metrics (velocity) measure production. Outcome metrics (adoption, KPI impact) measure whether what was built was actually valuable.

options.D: All equal

questions.explanation: X = $140K. Y = $85K. Z = $100K. Feature X has highest risk-adjusted value despite Z having highest upside.

questions.stem: Risk-Value Quadrant: correct order for addressing quadrants?

options.A: High Value/Low Risk → High Value/High Risk → Low Value/Low Risk → Low Value/High Risk
options.B: High Value/High Risk first
options.C: Low Risk first regardless of value
options.D: High Value/High Risk then any order

questions.correct_text: High Value/Low Risk → High Value/High Risk → Low Value/Low Risk → Low Value/High Risk
questions.explanation: Quick wins first (HV/LR), then high-value risky items with mitigation, fill with LV/LR, avoid LV/HR.

questions.stem: Canary release (10% of users): +15% engagement but +8% error rate. Action?

options.A: Roll back
options.B: Roll forward to 100%
options.C: Investigate error source, fix it, then gradually expand — engagement validates value, errors are fixable
options.D: Ignore metrics

questions.correct_text: Investigate error source, fix it, then gradually expand — engagement validates value, errors are fixable
questions.explanation: Mixed signals require investigation. Fix errors in the 10% cohort, verify, then expand. Embodies Build-Measure-Learn with risk management.

questions.stem: Planning poker estimates: 3, 5, 5, 8, 21. What should the SM do FIRST?

options.A: Average to 8
options.B: Ask outliers (3 and 21) to explain reasoning, then re-estimate — wide spread indicates different scope understanding
options.C: Use highest estimate
options.D: Use senior developer's estimate

questions.correct_text: Ask outliers (3 and 21) to explain reasoning, then re-estimate — wide spread indicates different scope understanding
questions.explanation: Planning poker's value is conversation. A 7x range signals different assumptions — the discussion is more valuable than the number.

questions.stem: Well-understood requirements but uncertain integration complexity. Fixed Price vs. Target Cost contract?

options.A: Fixed Price
options.B: Target Cost with gain/pain sharing — aligns incentives through 50/50 savings/overrun sharing, encouraging collaboration over adversarial scope disputes
options.C: T&M no cap
options.D: Fixed Price + change requests

questions.correct_text: Target Cost with gain/pain sharing — aligns incentives through 50/50 savings/overrun sharing, encouraging collaboration over adversarial scope disputes
questions.explanation: Target Cost aligns incentives: vendor benefits from efficiency, shares risk. Fixed Price creates adversarial dynamics. This is the Graduated Fixed Price variant.

questions.stem: CFD: "In Progress" band widens for 3 sprints, "Done" band flat. What does this mean?

options.A: High productivity
options.B: WIP accumulating — work enters faster than it completes; by Little's Law, increasing WIP with constant throughput increases lead time; tighten WIP limits
options.C: Need more developers
options.D: Wrong metrics

questions.correct_text: WIP accumulating — work enters faster than it completes; by Little's Law, increasing WIP with constant throughput increases lead time; tighten WIP limits
questions.explanation: Widening In Progress with flat Done = WIP accumulation. Little's Law: Lead Time = WIP/Throughput. Solution: WIP limits.

questions.stem: Monopoly Money: Feature M gets $180/500 (36%), next feature gets $60. PO's conclusion?

options.A: Give M 36% of budget
options.B: M is highest priority but investigate whether consensus reflects value or anchoring — validate with market data before committing
options.C: Invalid exercise
options.D: Equal investment

questions.correct_text: M is highest priority but investigate whether consensus reflects value or anchoring — validate with market data before committing
questions.explanation: Reveals perceived value, not objective value. Check for HIPPO effect. Triangulate with analytics and customer research.

questions.stem: Epic: "comprehensive reporting system." No acceptance criteria, no subtasks. First refinement step?

options.A: T-shirt size as-is
options.B: Decompose into smaller stories using splitting patterns (by role, report type, data source) with INVEST criteria
options.C: Return to PO
options.D: Schedule separate meeting

questions.correct_text: Decompose into smaller stories using splitting patterns (by role, report type, data source) with INVEST criteria
questions.explanation: Large vague epics must be decomposed before estimation using story splitting patterns.

questions.stem: 20-day lead time, 3 days value-adding work, 17 days waiting. Flow efficiency and best improvement?

options.A: 85%; fine
options.B: 15%; address testing queue (5d) and deployment approval (5d) first — eliminates 10 of 17 waste days
options.C: 15%; hire more devs
options.D: 50%; fix requirements

questions.correct_text: 15%; address testing queue (5d) and deployment approval (5d) first — eliminates 10 of 17 waste days
questions.explanation: Flow efficiency = 3/20 = 15%. Reducing value work 3→1 day saves only 2 days. Eliminating largest wait states saves 10 days — 5x more impactful.

questions.stem: BDD "Then" step: "Then the system processes the authentication request." Problem?

options.A: Too short
options.B: Describes internal system behaviour, not observable outcome — should be "Then the user sees their dashboard"
options.C: Should not test login
options.D: Format wrong

questions.correct_text: Describes internal system behaviour, not observable outcome — should be "Then the user sees their dashboard"
questions.explanation: BDD expresses observable business outcomes. "System processes request" is an implementation detail invisible to users.

questions.stem: Four equal-effort features. CoD: P=$50K/wk now, Q=$20K/wk now, R=$5K/wk perpetual, S=$0 now but $80K/wk in 8 weeks. Best sequence?

options.A: S → P → Q → R
options.B: P → Q → S → R — highest current CoD first; S times perfectly as P+Q takes 8 weeks
options.C: R → P → Q → S
options.D: P → S → Q → R

questions.correct_text: P → Q → S → R — highest current CoD first; S times perfectly as P+Q takes 8 weeks
questions.explanation: Reinertsen's urgency profiles: P=Urgent, Q=Urgent, S=Fixed Date, R=Intangible. P→Q takes 8 weeks, timing S start perfectly before its CoD activates.

questions.stem: Team delivers bi-weekly but org releases quarterly. Unreleased features accumulate. Lean waste category?

options.A: Overproduction
options.B: Inventory — completed but unconsumed features tie up investment without delivering value; batch size too large
options.C: Defects
options.D: Over-processing

questions.correct_text: Inventory — completed but unconsumed features tie up investment without delivering value; batch size too large
questions.explanation: Completed but unreleased = inventory waste. No value realised, delayed feedback, increased release risk.

questions.stem: Distinguish MVP from MMF.

options.A: Same concept
options.B: MVP = minimum to test hypothesis (learning tool, may not be marketable); MMF = smallest releasable unit delivering market value (delivery tool, must be complete)
options.C: MMF always larger
options.D: MVP for startups, MMF for enterprises

questions.correct_text: MVP = minimum to test hypothesis (learning tool, may not be marketable); MMF = smallest releasable unit delivering market value (delivery tool, must be complete)
questions.explanation: MVP (Ries) = validated learning. MMF (Denne & Cleland-Huang) = smallest functional releasable unit. Different purposes.

questions.stem: 40% of built features are rarely used. PO prioritises by stakeholder requests. Which concept applies?

options.A: Kaizen
options.B: Validated Learning — Build-Measure-Learn requires measuring outcomes; unused features = overproduction waste; adopt evidence-based prioritisation
options.C: Poka-Yoke
options.D: Mura

questions.correct_text: Validated Learning — Build-Measure-Learn requires measuring outcomes; unused features = overproduction waste; adopt evidence-based prioritisation
questions.explanation: 40% unused = 40% wasted capacity. Shift from opinion-driven to evidence-driven development using analytics and A/B testing.

questions.stem: Salience Model: A regulator has high power, high legitimacy, low urgency (audit in 8 months). Classification and engagement?

options.A: Definitive — engage constantly
options.B: Dominant stakeholder — power + legitimacy without urgency; engage proactively through quarterly compliance reviews rather than reactive crisis management
options.C: Latent — minimal engagement
options.D: Demanding — manage expectations

questions.correct_text: Dominant stakeholder — power + legitimacy without urgency; engage proactively through quarterly compliance reviews rather than reactive crisis management
questions.explanation: Mitchell's Salience Model: 2 attributes = Expectant. Power + Legitimacy = Dominant. Proactive engagement prevents surprises when urgency spikes near audit.

questions.stem: A VP demands 3 new features mid-sprint during their first sprint review attendance. Sprint backlog is committed. Best response?

options.A: Add the features
options.B: Acknowledge input, explain sprint commitment, add to product backlog for next sprint planning, schedule a meeting to understand priorities — respects both sprint integrity and stakeholder relationship
options.C: Tell the VP they should have attended earlier
options.D: Escalate to Scrum Master

questions.correct_text: Acknowledge input, explain sprint commitment, add to product backlog for next sprint planning, schedule a meeting to understand priorities — respects both sprint integrity and stakeholder relationship
questions.explanation: Balance sprint commitment with stakeholder relationship. Acknowledge, educate on process, capture request, offer path forward.

questions.stem: A team member argues personas are fictional and useless. Strongest argument FOR personas?

options.A: Required by Agile methodology
options.B: Personas synthesise real user research into memorable representations that help teams make consistent design decisions — they prevent designing for abstract "users" and force consideration of specific contexts
options.C: Replace direct user research
options.D: Only useful for marketing

questions.correct_text: Personas synthesise real user research into memorable representations that help teams make consistent design decisions — they prevent designing for abstract "users" and force consideration of specific contexts
questions.explanation: Alan Cooper's personas are data-driven archetypes enabling shared understanding, decision filtering, empathy, and scope control.

questions.stem: Head of Sales wants feature for quick demos; Head of Operations wants it for daily workflow. Contradictory. PO's FIRST action?

options.A: Choose Operations
options.B: Facilitate joint meeting to understand underlying needs, identify if both can be met in one design, if not, use prioritisation framework with sponsor for current release
options.C: Build two versions
options.D: Escalate to C-level immediately

questions.correct_text: Facilitate joint meeting to understand underlying needs, identify if both can be met in one design, if not, use prioritisation framework with sponsor for current release
questions.explanation: Contradictions often stem from different interpretations. Explore whether they are reconcilable before escalating or choosing.

questions.stem: "Three Amigos" technique: which three perspectives, and why?

options.A: PO, SM, Tech Lead
options.B: Developer, Tester, PO/BA — business value lens, implementation lens, and verification/edge case lens before development begins
options.C: Architect, DBA, DevOps
options.D: UX, Frontend, Backend

questions.correct_text: Developer, Tester, PO/BA — business value lens, implementation lens, and verification/edge case lens before development begins
questions.explanation: Three Amigos (from BDD) ensures requirements are understood from business, development, and testing perspectives, catching ambiguities before coding.

questions.stem: Power/Interest grid: End users have high interest (daily use) but low power (no funding influence). Engagement strategy?

options.A: Manage closely
options.B: Keep informed — valuable feedback source but not decision-makers; provide regular demos and feedback channels
options.C: Monitor only
options.D: Keep satisfied

questions.correct_text: Keep informed — valuable feedback source but not decision-makers; provide regular demos and feedback channels
questions.explanation: Low Power/High Interest = Keep Informed. Valuable for usability feedback without overwhelming with governance decisions.

questions.stem: Sailboat retrospective format — how does it work?

options.A: Discuss what is sailing well
options.B: Wind (propels forward), anchors (holds back), rocks (risks ahead), island (goal) — externalises problems onto metaphor rather than blaming individuals
options.C: Vote on top 3 issues
options.D: Assign blame

questions.correct_text: Wind (propels forward), anchors (holds back), rocks (risks ahead), island (goal) — externalises problems onto metaphor rather than blaming individuals
questions.explanation: Visual metaphor enables depersonalised, balanced, forward-looking discussion. Safer for discussing sensitive stakeholder issues.

questions.stem: Stakeholders across 3 continents, no synchronous overlap. Best distributed elicitation strategy?

options.A: Record workshops and email them
options.B: Layered approach: async pre-work (written drafts, videos), rotating synchronous sessions, then async review — ensures every stakeholder can contribute meaningfully
options.C: Hold in HQ time zone
options.D: Local POs per region

questions.correct_text: Layered approach: async pre-work (written drafts, videos), rotating synchronous sessions, then async review — ensures every stakeholder can contribute meaningfully
questions.explanation: Layered approach respects time zones while maintaining collaboration. Async pre-work reduces sync time, rotating sessions distribute burden equitably.

questions.stem: Impact Mapping: Goal = "Increase revenue 15%." What is the correct next step?

options.A: List features
options.B: Identify actors (who can produce the desired effect?) — existing customers, new segments, sales team, competitors; then define impacts (behaviour changes) before mapping deliverables
options.C: Define timeline
options.D: Calculate ROI per feature

questions.correct_text: Identify actors (who can produce the desired effect?) — existing customers, new segments, sales team, competitors; then define impacts (behaviour changes) before mapping deliverables
questions.explanation: Impact Mapping's WHY-WHO-HOW-WHAT prevents feature-first thinking. Features are the last thing defined, grounded in strategic actor analysis.

questions.stem: CEO says "We need AI search by next month" in a hallway. PO's response?

options.A: Add to top of backlog immediately
options.B: Follow up to understand business need, validate against vision, estimate effort, present trade-off analysis — "If we build this, we defer X and Y"
options.C: Ignore hallway conversations
options.D: Tell CEO to submit formal request

questions.correct_text: Follow up to understand business need, validate against vision, estimate effort, present trade-off analysis — "If we build this, we defer X and Y"
questions.explanation: Avoid HIPPO effect. Validate need, assess fit, estimate impact, present informed options. Respects CEO authority while exercising PO judgement.

questions.stem: Specification by Example for a discount feature. Which acceptance criteria style fits?

options.A: "Calculate discounts correctly"
options.B: Concrete: "Given €100 cart + 15% code SAVE15, when applied, then total = €85" — specific examples eliminate ambiguity and serve as automated tests
options.C: "Work as per business rules document"
options.D: "Pass QA review"

questions.correct_text: Concrete: "Given €100 cart + 15% code SAVE15, when applied, then total = €85" — specific examples eliminate ambiguity and serve as automated tests
questions.explanation: Specification by Example (Gojko Adzic) uses concrete data to eliminate ambiguity and create executable, living documentation.

questions.stem: Sprint review attendance drops from 15 to 3 stakeholders over 6 sprints. Causes and fix?

options.A: Stakeholders are busy
options.B: Reviews became status meetings (not demos) and/or feedback was not incorporated — restructure to demo working software interactively, add "You Said, We Did" segment
options.C: Cancel reviews, send emails
options.D: Make reviews mandatory

questions.correct_text: Reviews became status meetings (not demos) and/or feedback was not incorporated — restructure to demo working software interactively, add "You Said, We Did" segment
questions.explanation: Attendance decline signals feedback loop failure. Fix by demonstrating working software, visibly tracing feedback influence, and tailoring invitations.

questions.stem: Rewrite user story as Job Story (JTBD): "As a PM, I want a Gantt chart to track progress."

options.A: "I need a better Gantt chart"
options.B: "When I am in a client status meeting needing to show timeline progress, I want to quickly visualise milestones and dependencies so I can confidently communicate dates" — removes role assumption and predefined solution (Gantt chart)
options.C: "System shall display Gantt chart"
options.D: "Given a PM, when login, then show Gantt"

questions.correct_text: "When I am in a client status meeting needing to show timeline progress, I want to quickly visualise milestones and dependencies so I can confidently communicate dates" — removes role assumption and predefined solution (Gantt chart)
questions.explanation: Job Stories (Alan Klement/JTBD): When [situation], I want [motivation] so I can [outcome]. No predefined role or solution — opens design space.

questions.stem: Backlog grew from 50 to 200 stories in 3 months with no removals. Two actions for PO?

options.A: Accept all to maintain satisfaction
options.B: (1) "One in, one out" relative prioritisation policy; (2) quarterly pruning to remove irrelevant stories (YAGNI) — forces trade-offs and reduces noise
options.C: Freeze backlog
options.D: Delegate to BA

questions.correct_text: (1) "One in, one out" relative prioritisation policy; (2) quarterly pruning to remove irrelevant stories (YAGNI) — forces trade-offs and reduces noise
questions.explanation: Relative prioritisation forces trade-offs. Regular pruning removes items older than 6 months without engagement. A healthy backlog has ready, rough, and trash horizons.

questions.stem: What distinguishes Event Storming from traditional requirements workshops?

options.A: Uses sticky notes
options.B: Maps domain events in temporal order, then identifies commands, aggregates, policies, and read models — this bottom-up approach discovers requirements through domain modelling, naturally revealing edge cases and boundaries
options.C: Replaces user stories
options.D: Only for microservices

questions.correct_text: Maps domain events in temporal order, then identifies commands, aggregates, policies, and read models — this bottom-up approach discovers requirements through domain modelling, naturally revealing edge cases and boundaries
questions.explanation: Alberto Brandolini's Event Storming models the domain from events, surfacing missing steps, exception paths, parallel processes, and bounded contexts that interviews miss.

questions.stem: Stakeholder demands RAG reports, Gantt charts, resource utilisation. Team uses sprint reviews, burndowns, task board. SM's approach?

options.A: Produce traditional reports
options.B: Understand underlying info need, demonstrate how Agile artifacts provide same transparency, co-create a reporting format using Agile data
options.C: Refuse — Agile teams don't report
options.D: Have PO create reports

questions.correct_text: Understand underlying info need, demonstrate how Agile artifacts provide same transparency, co-create a reporting format using Agile data
questions.explanation: Stakeholder needs transparency, not specifically Gantt charts. Bridge the gap by showing Agile equivalents and co-creating useful formats.

questions.stem: A developer says "security is not my responsibility — that is the security team's job." What does this indicate?

options.A: Developer is correct
options.B: Team lacks collective ownership — in cross-functional Agile teams, quality including security is everyone's responsibility; DoD should include security checks
options.C: Tester should not test security
options.D: Address security after sprint

questions.correct_text: Team lacks collective ownership — in cross-functional Agile teams, quality including security is everyone's responsibility; DoD should include security checks
questions.explanation: "Whole Team" approach and DevSecOps require collective quality ownership. The response indicates silo mentality incompatible with Agile.

questions.stem: PO wants to shift from vocal-stakeholder-driven to evidence-based decisions. Best techniques?

options.A: More stakeholder meetings
options.B: A/B testing, analytics dashboards, NPS measurement, WSJF with validated cost-of-delay data — creates feedback loop where decisions are validated by outcomes
options.C: Delegate to dev team
options.D: Use story points as value proxy

questions.correct_text: A/B testing, analytics dashboards, NPS measurement, WSJF with validated cost-of-delay data — creates feedback loop where decisions are validated by outcomes
questions.explanation: Evidence-based management replaces opinion with data through Build-Measure-Learn cycles.

questions.stem: Fixed-price client insists on approving every story before development — 5-day bottleneck. Which principle violated?

options.A: Responding to change
options.B: Principle 4 ("daily collaboration") — 5-day queue is batch-and-queue anti-pattern; propose embedding client representative in sprint planning for continuous alignment
options.C: Working software over documentation
options.D: Eliminate approval entirely

questions.correct_text: Principle 4 ("daily collaboration") — 5-day queue is batch-and-queue anti-pattern; propose embedding client representative in sprint planning for continuous alignment
questions.explanation: Batch approval mimics Waterfall phase-gates. Embedding a client rep transforms batch approval into continuous collaboration.

questions.stem: Sponsor is "Resistant," desired level is "Supportive." Best strategy?

options.A: Ignore until supportive
options.B: Identify root cause of resistance, address through one-on-one conversations, demonstrate early wins aligned with sponsor's priorities, involve in decisions — resistance is often based on legitimate concerns
options.C: Replace the sponsor
options.D: Escalate to management

questions.correct_text: Identify root cause of resistance, address through one-on-one conversations, demonstrate early wins aligned with sponsor's priorities, involve in decisions — resistance is often based on legitimate concerns
questions.explanation: Moving along the engagement spectrum requires understanding root causes: fear of change, loss of control, bad experience. Address through dialogue, early wins, and empowerment.

questions.stem: 60% of users use only 3 of 20 features. Remaining 17 features cost 40% of maintenance. PO's recommendation?

options.A: Remove all immediately
options.B: Investigate why (poor discoverability? wrong audience? outdated?), apply sunset strategy with communication and migration paths, gradually retire unjustifiable features
options.C: Build more features
options.D: Leave as-is

questions.correct_text: Investigate why (poor discoverability? wrong audience? outdated?), apply sunset strategy with communication and migration paths, gradually retire unjustifiable features
questions.explanation: Pareto principle applies but removal requires investigation. Classify unused features, communicate deprecation, provide migration paths, retire responsibly.

questions.stem: A Scrum team of 7 has been together for 4 months. Initially productive and collaborative, the team is now experiencing open disagreements about technical direction, with two senior developers frequently clashing. Sprint velocity has dropped 20%. Using Tuckman's model, what stage is this team in, and what should the Scrum Master do?

options.A: Forming — reintroduce the team charter
options.B: Storming — this is a natural and necessary phase; the SM should not suppress conflict but facilitate productive resolution through structured dialogue, helping the team establish norms for technical decision-making and disagreement resolution that will carry them into the Norming stage
options.C: Norming — the team is establishing new norms
options.D: Performing — high-performance teams have healthy conflict

questions.correct_text: Storming — this is a natural and necessary phase; the SM should not suppress conflict but facilitate productive resolution through structured dialogue, helping the team establish norms for technical decision-making and disagreement resolution that will carry them into the Norming stage
questions.explanation: Tuckman's Storming stage is characterised by conflict over roles, approaches, and direction. After an initial productive Forming period (often mistaken for Performing), real disagreements emerge. Velocity drops are common. The SM's role: (1) normalise conflict ("this is healthy and expected"); (2) facilitate structured dialogue (decision matrices, technical spike comparisons); (3) help establish decision-making norms. Suppressing conflict delays Norming.

questions.stem: A SM notices one team member consistently dominates retrospectives while three others remain silent. Using Clark's 4 Stages of Psychological Safety, which stage is the team MOST likely lacking?

options.A: Inclusion Safety — the silent members may not feel they belong
options.B: Contributor Safety — the silent members do not feel safe contributing ideas or observations without fear of ridicule or dismissal; the SM should use techniques like silent brainstorming, anonymous idea boards, or round-robin sharing to create structural contributor safety
options.C: Learner Safety — members fear asking questions
options.D: Challenger Safety — members fear challenging the status quo

questions.correct_text: Contributor Safety — the silent members do not feel safe contributing ideas or observations without fear of ridicule or dismissal; the SM should use techniques like silent brainstorming, anonymous idea boards, or round-robin sharing to create structural contributor safety
questions.explanation: Clark's 4 Stages: (1) Inclusion Safety (belonging), (2) Learner Safety (safe to ask/experiment), (3) Contributor Safety (safe to contribute), (4) Challenger Safety (safe to challenge). One person dominating while others stay silent suggests the silent members do not feel safe contributing — they may fear their input will be dismissed or ridiculed. Structural techniques bypass social dynamics: silent brainstorming (write before speaking), 1-2-4-All (progressive sharing from individual to group), and anonymous boards.

questions.stem: Two team members are in open conflict over whether to use microservices or a monolith. The conflict has escalated from technical discussion to personal attacks. Using the TKI (Thomas-Kilmann Instrument), which conflict mode should the SM facilitate?

options.A: Avoiding — let them cool down and the conflict will resolve
options.B: Collaborating — facilitate a session where both parties articulate their concerns and constraints, explore how elements of both approaches might coexist (e.g., a modular monolith), and reach a solution that addresses both sets of concerns; this requires assertiveness AND cooperativeness
options.C: Competing — let the stronger argument win
options.D: Accommodating — one person should defer to maintain peace

questions.correct_text: Collaborating — facilitate a session where both parties articulate their concerns and constraints, explore how elements of both approaches might coexist (e.g., a modular monolith), and reach a solution that addresses both sets of concerns; this requires assertiveness AND cooperativeness
questions.explanation: TKI defines 5 modes: Competing (assertive, uncooperative), Collaborating (assertive, cooperative), Compromising (moderate both), Avoiding (unassertive, uncooperative), Accommodating (unassertive, cooperative). For a significant technical decision where both parties have valid points, Collaborating is optimal: it invests time to find a win-win. The SM should (1) de-escalate personal attacks; (2) refocus on technical criteria; (3) facilitate structured comparison; (4) explore creative alternatives (modular monolith, strangler fig pattern). Avoiding delays decisions. Accommodating loses valuable input. Competing creates resentment.

questions.stem: A team member consistently delivers late and low-quality work. The SM has had two private coaching conversations without improvement. Using the Speed Leas Conflict Model, at what level is this situation, and what intervention is needed?

options.A: Level 1 (Problem to Solve) — continue coaching
options.B: Level 2 (Disagreement) — involve a mediator
options.C: The situation has likely progressed beyond Level 1 coaching; if the team member is disengaged or resistant, this is Level 2 (Disagreement) or Level 3 (Contest) — the SM should involve the PO and/or management to understand root causes (personal issues, skill mismatch, role dissatisfaction) and establish a clear performance improvement plan with measurable outcomes and a timeline
options.D: Level 5 (Intractable) — remove the team member

questions.correct_text: The situation has likely progressed beyond Level 1 coaching; if the team member is disengaged or resistant, this is Level 2 (Disagreement) or Level 3 (Contest) — the SM should involve the PO and/or management to understand root causes (personal issues, skill mismatch, role dissatisfaction) and establish a clear performance improvement plan with measurable outcomes and a timeline
questions.explanation: Speed Leas levels: L1=Problem to Solve (collaborative), L2=Disagreement (self-protection begins), L3=Contest (win/lose dynamic), L4=Crusade (ideology), L5=Intractable (destruction).
