Two coaching attempts without improvement suggests L2/L3 — the situation requires escalation beyond 1-on-1 coaching. Root cause investigation is critical: poor performance may stem from skill gaps, personal issues, role mismatch, or team dysfunction. A performance improvement plan (PIP) with measurable criteria and a timeline provides clarity and fairness.

questions.stem: A manager asks: "How do I motivate my Agile team?" An Agile coach explains Daniel Pink's Drive model. Which THREE elements does Pink identify as intrinsic motivators?

options.A: Money, status, and promotion
options.B: Autonomy (desire to direct our own work), Mastery (urge to get better at something that matters), and Purpose (yearning to contribute to something larger than ourselves) — these intrinsic motivators are more effective than extrinsic rewards for creative knowledge work
options.C: Competition, recognition, and bonuses
options.D: Safety, belonging, and esteem

questions.correct_text: Autonomy (desire to direct our own work), Mastery (urge to get better at something that matters), and Purpose (yearning to contribute to something larger than ourselves) — these intrinsic motivators are more effective than extrinsic rewards for creative knowledge work
questions.explanation: Daniel Pink's "Drive" identifies Autonomy, Mastery, and Purpose as the three intrinsic motivators for creative work. Extrinsic motivators (money, bonuses) work for routine tasks but can undermine creativity and intrinsic motivation for knowledge work (the "overjustification effect"). For Agile teams: Autonomy = self-organising teams choose how to work. Mastery = continuous improvement, learning new skills. Purpose = understanding how their work impacts users/business. Option A lists extrinsic motivators. Option D references Maslow's hierarchy.

questions.stem: Using Herzberg's Two-Factor Theory, which of the following would be classified as a "Motivator" (satisfaction factor) rather than a "Hygiene" factor (dissatisfaction factor)?

options.A: Salary increase
options.B: Challenging work that provides a sense of achievement — Herzberg's motivators include achievement, recognition, the work itself, responsibility, and advancement; hygiene factors include salary, working conditions, company policy, supervision, and interpersonal relations
options.C: Better office facilities
options.D: Company health insurance

questions.correct_text: Challenging work that provides a sense of achievement — Herzberg's motivators include achievement, recognition, the work itself, responsibility, and advancement; hygiene factors include salary, working conditions, company policy, supervision, and interpersonal relations
questions.explanation: Herzberg's Two-Factor Theory: Hygiene factors (salary, conditions, policy, supervision) prevent dissatisfaction but do not create satisfaction. Motivators (achievement, recognition, meaningful work, responsibility, growth) create genuine satisfaction and motivation. An Agile environment enables motivators: self-organising teams provide responsibility, continuous improvement provides growth, and meaningful product work provides achievement. Raising salary (option A) reduces dissatisfaction but does not increase motivation.

questions.stem: A Scrum team of 11 members is struggling with coordination. Daily standups take 30 minutes, sprint planning takes an entire day, and individual contributions are hard to track. What does the Scrum Guide recommend?

options.A: Add a project coordinator role
options.B: Split into two smaller teams of 5-6 members — the Scrum Guide recommends teams of 10 or fewer; smaller teams communicate better, coordinate more easily, and create stronger individual accountability; each sub-team needs a clear scope boundary to minimise cross-team dependencies
options.C: Keep the team but shorten ceremonies
options.D: Move to Kanban where team size is less constrained

questions.correct_text: Split into two smaller teams of 5-6 members — the Scrum Guide recommends teams of 10 or fewer; smaller teams communicate better, coordinate more easily, and create stronger individual accountability; each sub-team needs a clear scope boundary to minimise cross-team dependencies
questions.explanation: The Scrum Guide (2020) recommends teams of 10 or fewer, noting that smaller teams communicate better and are more productive. With 11 members, the team exceeds this threshold. Communication paths increase exponentially (n(n-1)/2 = 55 paths for 11 people vs. 15 for 6). Splitting reduces coordination overhead and improves individual visibility. Key considerations: shared Definition of Done, cross-team integration strategy, and a coordination mechanism (Scrum of Scrums).

questions.stem: An Agile coach observes that a team member with high Emotional Intelligence (EI) consistently de-escalates tensions, reads team moods accurately, and adapts their communication style to different personalities. Using Goleman's EI framework, which TWO EI components is this person MOST demonstrating?

options.A: Self-awareness and self-regulation
options.B: Social awareness (empathy — reading team moods) and relationship management (de-escalation and adaptive communication) — these are the "other-focused" EI competencies that enable effective team interaction
options.C: Motivation and self-awareness
options.D: Self-regulation and motivation

questions.correct_text: Social awareness (empathy — reading team moods) and relationship management (de-escalation and adaptive communication) — these are the "other-focused" EI competencies that enable effective team interaction
questions.explanation: Goleman's 5 EI components: Self-Awareness (recognising own emotions), Self-Regulation (managing own emotions), Motivation (internal drive), Social Awareness/Empathy (reading others' emotions), Relationship Management (influencing, de-escalating, adapting). The described behaviours — reading moods (empathy) and de-escalating/adapting communication (relationship management) — are the interpersonal EI competencies. These are particularly valuable for Scrum Masters and Agile coaches.

questions.stem: A team is transitioning to mob programming (ensemble programming). What is mob programming, and what is its PRIMARY benefit?

options.A: Multiple teams working on the same feature
options.B: The entire team works together on the same code at the same time, with one "driver" (typing) and the rest as "navigators" (thinking, directing) — the primary benefit is real-time knowledge sharing and collective code ownership, which eliminates knowledge silos, reduces code review bottlenecks, and produces higher-quality solutions through continuous collaboration
options.C: A debugging technique where multiple developers hunt bugs
options.D: A sprint planning technique for large teams

questions.correct_text: The entire team works together on the same code at the same time, with one "driver" (typing) and the rest as "navigators" (thinking, directing) — the primary benefit is real-time knowledge sharing and collective code ownership, which eliminates knowledge silos, reduces code review bottlenecks, and produces higher-quality solutions through continuous collaboration
questions.explanation: Mob programming (Woody Zuill) extends pair programming to the whole team. One driver types while navigators collectively design and direct. Benefits: zero knowledge silos (everyone sees everything), instant code review (quality built in), rapid onboarding for new members, and emergent best practices. Studies show mob programming often produces higher quality with similar or better throughput than individual work, because the cost of context switching, interruptions, and rework is eliminated.

questions.stem: A team lead asks about the difference between a "group of individuals" and a "high-performing team." Using the Katzenbach and Smith team performance curve, at which stage does a group become a "real team"?

options.A: When they sit in the same room
options.B: A real team exists when members hold themselves mutually accountable for shared goals, complement each other's skills, and commit to a common purpose — the performance curve progresses from Working Group → Pseudo-Team → Potential Team → Real Team → High-Performance Team
options.C: When they have a manager
options.D: When they complete their first project

questions.correct_text: A real team exists when members hold themselves mutually accountable for shared goals, complement each other's skills, and commit to a common purpose — the performance curve progresses from Working Group → Pseudo-Team → Potential Team → Real Team → High-Performance Team
questions.explanation: Katzenbach and Smith's team performance curve: Working Group (individual accountability, no shared goal) → Pseudo-Team (labelled "team" but worse than individuals due to coordination overhead without commitment) → Potential Team (developing shared commitment) → Real Team (mutual accountability, complementary skills, common purpose) → High-Performance Team (deeply committed to each other's growth). The critical transition is mutual accountability — when members feel responsible not just for their work but for the team's collective outcomes.

questions.stem:
A distributed Agile team experiences "us vs. them" dynamics between the onshore (5 members) and offshore (4 members) sub-groups. Each group socialises internally but has minimal informal interaction across locations.

What is the MOST effective intervention?

options.A: Add more video calls
options.B: Create cross-location pairing assignments — pair one onshore and one offshore member for specific stories, rotate pairings each sprint, and facilitate virtual team-building activities that create shared experiences; this breaks the in-group/out-group dynamic by creating personal relationships across the location boundary
options.C: Move all team members to one location
options.D: Assign a liaison role between the two groups

questions.correct_text: Create cross-location pairing assignments — pair one onshore and one offshore member for specific stories, rotate pairings each sprint, and facilitate virtual team-building activities that create shared experiences; this breaks the in-group/out-group dynamic by creating personal relationships across the location boundary
questions.explanation: In-group/out-group dynamics are a natural consequence of proximity bias. Cross-location pairing forces personal interaction, builds empathy, and creates shared work context. Rotation ensures all members build cross-location relationships over time. Virtual team-building (gaming, coffee chats, shared learning) supplements work-focused pairing. Option A adds meetings without addressing the social dynamic. Option C may be impractical. Option D institutionalises the divide rather than bridging it.

questions.stem: A SM uses the Delegation Poker technique (Jurgen Appelo, Management 3.0). What are the 7 levels of delegation, and when should a SM operate at each level?

options.A: Levels 1-7 represent increasing autonomy
options.B: The 7 levels are: (1) Tell, (2) Sell, (3) Consult, (4) Agree, (5) Advise, (6) Inquire, (7) Delegate — the SM should adapt their delegation level based on the team's maturity and the decision's impact; new teams may need level 2-3 for process decisions, while mature teams should be at level 6-7 for most decisions
options.C: There are only 3 levels: decide, share, delegate
options.D: Delegation Poker is about poker-style estimation

questions.correct_text: The 7 levels are: (1) Tell, (2) Sell, (3) Consult, (4) Agree, (5) Advise, (6) Inquire, (7) Delegate — the SM should adapt their delegation level based on the team's maturity and the decision's impact; new teams may need level 2-3 for process decisions, while mature teams should be at level 6-7 for most decisions
questions.explanation: Management 3.0's Delegation Poker defines a spectrum from full manager control (Tell) to full team control (Delegate). The SM uses this to make delegation decisions transparent. Example: "Sprint length" might be Level 5 (Advise — SM suggests but team decides). "Architecture decisions" might be Level 7 (Delegate — team decides fully). "Budget decisions" might be Level 3 (Consult — SM decides after team input). The tool makes power dynamics explicit and helps teams understand where they have autonomy.

questions.stem:
A high-performing team suddenly loses its senior architect, who joined a competitor. The remaining team members are anxious about delivering the upcoming complex sprint without their technical anchor.

Using Tuckman's model, what will MOST likely happen?

options.A: Nothing changes — the team will continue Performing
options.B: The team will likely regress to Storming or even Forming — any significant membership change disrupts team dynamics and requires re-norming; the SM should acknowledge the disruption, facilitate knowledge transfer from remaining members, and guide the team through re-forming without assuming the previous dynamic will automatically resume
options.C: The team will immediately replace the architect
options.D: The team should be disbanded and reformed

questions.correct_text: The team will likely regress to Storming or even Forming — any significant membership change disrupts team dynamics and requires re-norming; the SM should acknowledge the disruption, facilitate knowledge transfer from remaining members, and guide the team through re-forming without assuming the previous dynamic will automatically resume
questions.explanation: Tuckman's model is not a one-way progression. Team membership changes force regression because the group dynamics, trust relationships, and role negotiations are disrupted. The degree of regression depends on how central the departing member was. Losing a senior architect — likely a key decision-maker and knowledge holder — will cause significant disruption. The SM should: (1) acknowledge the loss and team anxiety; (2) identify critical knowledge gaps; (3) facilitate role redistribution; (4) accept temporary velocity reduction during re-formation.

questions.stem:
A team's retrospective consistently produces 10-15 action items but only completes 1-2 by the next retrospective. This pattern has repeated for 6 sprints.

What is the ROOT cause, and what should the SM change?

options.A: The team needs longer sprints for more improvement time
options.B: The team is generating too many action items without prioritisation — the SM should limit retrospective outputs to a maximum of 2-3 high-impact, actionable improvements per sprint, assign clear owners and due dates, and add these to the sprint backlog as improvement stories to ensure they receive dedicated capacity
options.C: Retrospectives should be less frequent
options.D: Action items should be assigned to the SM to track

questions.correct_text: The team is generating too many action items without prioritisation — the SM should limit retrospective outputs to a maximum of 2-3 high-impact, actionable improvements per sprint, assign clear owners and due dates, and add these to the sprint backlog as improvement stories to ensure they receive dedicated capacity
questions.explanation: This is the "retrospective cargo cult" anti-pattern: generating items creates the feeling of improvement without actual change. Root cause: too many items dilute focus and commitment. Fix: (1) limit to 2-3 items using dot-voting or impact/effort matrix; (2) assign owners; (3) add to sprint backlog (making improvement work visible and prioritised); (4) review previous items at the start of each retrospective. The Scrum Guide states that the most impactful improvements should be addressed "as soon as possible."

questions.stem:
A team includes a certified Scrum Master who also writes code during sprints. Some team members feel the SM's dual role creates a conflict of interest — when the SM is deep in coding, impediments go unaddressed for hours.

What is the PMI-ACP perspective on this arrangement?

options.A: SMs should never write code
options.B: While dual-role SMs are common in small organisations, the coaching and impediment removal responsibilities must take priority — if coding consistently prevents the SM from fulfilling their servant leadership duties, the arrangement should be reconsidered; the team might designate specific "SM office hours" when the SM is fully available for coaching and impediment resolution
options.C: All team members should code, including the SM
options.D: The SM role is unnecessary if the team is mature

questions.correct_text: While dual-role SMs are common in small organisations, the coaching and impediment removal responsibilities must take priority — if coding consistently prevents the SM from fulfilling their servant leadership duties, the arrangement should be reconsidered; the team might designate specific "SM office hours" when the SM is fully available for coaching and impediment resolution
questions.explanation: The SM's primary responsibilities are servant leadership, coaching, and impediment removal. Coding is a secondary activity that can create conflicts: cognitive immersion in code makes it difficult to monitor team dynamics, and context-switching between coding and coaching reduces effectiveness at both. Pragmatic solutions: dedicate specific times for each role, limit coding to non-critical-path work, or transition coding responsibilities to another team member. The key test: are SM duties being fulfilled effectively?

questions.stem: An organisation measures team performance using individual velocity (story points completed by each developer). What is the PRIMARY problem?

options.A: Velocity is difficult to measure individually
options.B: Individual velocity incentivises working in isolation, cherry-picking easy stories, avoiding collaboration (pairing, code review), and inflating personal story point estimates — it undermines the team-based, collaborative nature of Agile and should be replaced with team-level metrics
options.C: Individual velocity is fine for accountability
options.D: Story points should be replaced with hours

questions.correct_text: Individual velocity incentivises working in isolation, cherry-picking easy stories, avoiding collaboration (pairing, code review), and inflating personal story point estimates — it undermines the team-based, collaborative nature of Agile and should be replaced with team-level metrics
questions.explanation: Individual velocity destroys team dynamics. When individuals are measured on personal output: (1) pairing is disincentivised (two people get half the points each); (2) helping teammates reduces personal score; (3) easy stories are cherry-picked; (4) point inflation occurs (individual gaming). Agile measures team performance: team velocity, team quality, team customer satisfaction. Individual contributions are assessed through peer feedback, collaborative behaviours, and growth trajectories, not personal output metrics.

questions.stem:
A team's Definition of Ready (DoR) includes: acceptance criteria defined, UI mockups attached, technical approach agreed, and dependencies identified. A PO argues that DoR is wasteful because it creates a "mini-Waterfall gate."

Is the PO's concern valid?

options.A: No — DoR is essential and should not be questioned
options.B: Partially valid — a lightweight DoR (acceptance criteria defined, team understands the story) prevents waste from starting unclear work; however, an overly prescriptive DoR (requiring mockups, technical approach, dependency resolution) can create a Waterfall-style phase gate that delays flow and reduces the team's ability to start with exploration; the team should find the right balance
options.C: Yes — DoR should be eliminated entirely
options.D: DoR is required by the Scrum Guide

questions.correct_text: Partially valid — a lightweight DoR (acceptance criteria defined, team understands the story) prevents waste from starting unclear work; however, an overly prescriptive DoR (requiring mockups, technical approach, dependency resolution) can create a Waterfall-style phase gate that delays flow and reduces the team's ability to start with exploration; the team should find the right balance
questions.explanation: Definition of Ready exists on a spectrum. Too little readiness means the team starts work with insufficient understanding, leading to rework. Too much readiness creates a requirements-complete gate that contradicts Agile's iterative discovery approach. The right balance: stories must be understandable and estimable (lightweight DoR), but technical approach and UI design can emerge during the sprint. The Scrum Guide does not mandate DoR — it is a team practice. The PO's concern is valid if the DoR blocks refinement-during-sprint.

questions.stem:
A team consistently achieves high velocity but customer satisfaction scores are declining. Sprint reviews receive positive feedback from internal stakeholders, but NPS from actual end users is dropping.

What is the MOST likely disconnect?

options.A: Velocity is not being measured correctly
options.B: The team is optimising for output (stories delivered) rather than outcomes (customer impact) — internal stakeholders may be praising feature delivery while end users experience problems like poor UX, performance degradation, or features that do not solve real problems; the team needs to incorporate direct user feedback loops and measure outcome metrics
options.C: NPS is an unreliable metric
options.D: Customer satisfaction is outside the team's control

questions.correct_text: The team is optimising for output (stories delivered) rather than outcomes (customer impact) — internal stakeholders may be praising feature delivery while end users experience problems like poor UX, performance degradation, or features that do not solve real problems; the team needs to incorporate direct user feedback loops and measure outcome metrics
questions.explanation: This output-outcome gap is common. High velocity means the team is productive (output), but declining NPS means the product is not improving for users (outcome). Possible causes: building stakeholder-requested features that users do not want; accumulating UX debt while adding features; performance degradation from increasing complexity; or losing focus on user pain points. The fix: direct user feedback (usability testing, customer interviews), outcome metrics (adoption rates, task completion rates), and regular re-validation of the product vision against user needs.

questions.stem: A SM is building a new team and wants to establish a team charter on day one. What should the charter include, and why is it important?

options.A: A list of rules and punishments for violations
options.B: The charter should define: team purpose/mission, shared values, working agreements (core hours, communication channels, decision-making approach), Definition of Done, conflict resolution process, and individual strengths — it is important because explicitly agreeing on norms during Forming prevents ambiguity that leads to unnecessary Storming
options.C: Technical architecture decisions
options.D: Individual performance targets

questions.correct_text: The charter should define: team purpose/mission, shared values, working agreements (core hours, communication channels, decision-making approach), Definition of Done, conflict resolution process, and individual strengths — it is important because explicitly agreeing on norms during Forming prevents ambiguity that leads to unnecessary Storming
questions.explanation: A team charter establishes explicit shared norms during the Forming stage. Key elements: purpose (why we exist), values (what we believe), working agreements (how we operate day-to-day), DoD (our quality standard), conflict resolution (how we disagree productively), and strengths inventory (what each person brings). Making these explicit prevents the friction that arises when implicit assumptions conflict. The charter is a living document — revisited at retrospectives and updated as the team matures.

questions.stem:
A team uses relative estimation with story points and the Fibonacci sequence. A baseline story (user login) is calibrated at 3 points. A new story (multi-factor authentication integration) is estimated at 13 points. A stakeholder asks "How many hours is 13 points?"

What is the correct response?

options.A: 13 points = 52 hours (4 hours per point)
options.B: Story points measure relative complexity, uncertainty, and effort — not time; the team knows that 13-point stories are approximately 4x more complex than the 3-point baseline, but translation to hours depends on who works on it, what unknowns emerge, and what tooling is used; the team uses velocity (points per sprint) for forecasting delivery dates rather than converting points to hours
options.C: Each point equals 1 day
options.D: 13 points is unmeasurable — it should be split

questions.correct_text: Story points measure relative complexity, uncertainty, and effort — not time; the team knows that 13-point stories are approximately 4x more complex than the 3-point baseline, but translation to hours depends on who works on it, what unknowns emerge, and what tooling is used; the team uses velocity (points per sprint) for forecasting delivery dates rather than converting points to hours
questions.explanation: Story points are deliberately abstract. Converting to hours undermines their purpose by introducing individual productivity variance. A 13-point story may take Alice 30 hours and Bob 45 hours — the point value reflects the story's inherent complexity relative to the baseline. Forecasting uses velocity: if the team averages 40 points/sprint, a 13-point story represents ~32% of sprint capacity. Option D has some merit (13 is large and splitting may help), but the question asks about the relationship between points and hours.

questions.stem: A team's velocity over 6 sprints is: 32, 28, 35, 30, 33, 31. The product backlog has 180 remaining story points. How many sprints will likely be needed to complete the backlog?

options.A: 5 sprints
options.B: Using average velocity (31.5 points/sprint), the team needs approximately 6 sprints (180/31.5 = 5.7, rounded up); however, a responsible forecast should also provide a range using best/worst velocity: optimistic (180/35 = 5.1 ≈ 5 sprints) to pessimistic (180/28 = 6.4 ≈ 7 sprints), giving a 5-7 sprint range
options.C: Exactly 5.7 sprints
options.D: Cannot be determined

questions.correct_text: Using average velocity (31.5 points/sprint), the team needs approximately 6 sprints (180/31.5 = 5.7, rounded up); however, a responsible forecast should also provide a range using best/worst velocity: optimistic (180/35 = 5.1 ≈ 5 sprints) to pessimistic (180/28 = 6.4 ≈ 7 sprints), giving a 5-7 sprint range
questions.explanation: Velocity-based forecasting uses historical data. Average velocity = (32+28+35+30+33+31)/6 = 189/6 = 31.5. Sprints needed = 180/31.5 = 5.7. Reporting a single number is misleading; responsible forecasting provides a range. Using the best sprint (35) and worst sprint (28): optimistic = 180/35 = 5.1, pessimistic = 180/28 = 6.4. The range 5-7 sprints communicates uncertainty honestly. Monte Carlo simulation would provide even better probabilistic forecasting.

questions.stem: A team practises "rolling wave planning." What does this mean, and how does it differ from upfront planning?

options.A: Planning in waves of increasing detail — only the near-term work is planned in detail, while future work is planned at progressively higher levels of abstraction; this allows the team to make detailed commitments when information is available and defer detailed planning for distant work that will change
options.B: Re-planning every sprint
options.C: Planning in rotations where different team members take turns
options.D: A visual planning technique using wave-shaped charts

questions.correct_text: Planning in waves of increasing detail — only the near-term work is planned in detail, while future work is planned at progressively higher levels of abstraction; this allows the team to make detailed commitments when information is available and defer detailed planning for distant work that will change
questions.explanation: Rolling wave planning (also called progressive elaboration) applies the Agile principle of deferring decisions to the last responsible moment. Near-term work (next sprint) is detailed and refined. Medium-term work (next 2-3 sprints) has user stories at various refinement levels. Long-term work (next quarter) exists as epics or themes. As time progresses, the "wave" rolls forward — today's medium-term becomes detailed, and new long-term work enters. This contrasts with upfront planning that details everything before starting, which is wasteful because requirements change.

questions.stem:
A release has 6 features (A-F) with dependencies: B depends on A, D depends on C, F depends on D and E. Features C and E have no dependencies. The team has capacity for 2 features per sprint.

What is the optimal sprint-by-sprint delivery plan?

options.A: Sprint 1: A, B; Sprint 2: C, D; Sprint 3: E, F
options.B: Sprint 1: A, C (both have no upstream dependencies); Sprint 2: B, E (B's dependency A is done, E has none); Sprint 3: D, F (D's dependency C is done, F's dependencies D and E are done — but D finishes in this sprint so F must wait); adjusted: Sprint 3: D, E; Sprint 4: F — or optimised: Sprint 1: A, C; Sprint 2: B, E; Sprint 3: D + start F if D completes mid-sprint
options.C: Sprint 1: A, B, C all in parallel
options.D: Sprint 1: F first (most dependencies = most important)

questions.correct_text: Sprint 1: A, C (both have no upstream dependencies); Sprint 2: B, E (B's dependency A is done, E has none); Sprint 3: D, F (D's dependency C is done, F's dependencies D and E are done — but D finishes in this sprint so F must wait); adjusted: Sprint 3: D, E; Sprint 4: F — or optimised: Sprint 1: A, C; Sprint 2: B, E; Sprint 3: D + start F if D completes mid-sprint
questions.explanation: Dependency analysis requires topological ordering. A and C have no dependencies — start both immediately. B depends on A (available Sprint 2). E has no dependencies (can start Sprint 1 or 2). D depends on C (available Sprint 2+). F depends on D and E (both must complete first). Optimal: Sprint 1: A, C. Sprint 2: B, E. Sprint 3: D. Sprint 4: F (or Sprint 3 if D completes early enough). Option A puts B in Sprint 1 before its dependency A. Option D starts with the most dependent item.

questions.stem: A PO asks the team to estimate an epic using Wideband Delphi technique. How does Wideband Delphi work?

options.A: One expert provides the estimate
options.B: Multiple experts independently estimate, results are shared anonymously, outliers discuss their reasoning, and re-estimation occurs through iterative rounds until convergence — this reduces anchoring bias and incorporates diverse perspectives while preserving individual judgement
options.C: The team uses T-shirt sizes
options.D: Historical data from similar projects is used

questions.correct_text: Multiple experts independently estimate, results are shared anonymously, outliers discuss their reasoning, and re-estimation occurs through iterative rounds until convergence — this reduces anchoring bias and incorporates diverse perspectives while preserving individual judgement
questions.explanation: Wideband Delphi (Barry Boehm): (1) Present the work item and any available information. (2) Each expert estimates independently (prevents anchoring). (3) Estimates are collected and shared anonymously. (4) The group discusses, with outliers explaining their reasoning. (5) Re-estimation occurs. (6) Repeat until estimates converge (typically 2-3 rounds). This combines the wisdom of multiple experts while mitigating groupthink and anchoring. Planning poker is a lightweight adaptation of Wideband Delphi.

questions.stem: A team uses a burnup chart rather than a burndown chart. What additional insight does a burnup chart provide?

options.A: Burnup and burndown show identical information
options.B: A burnup chart shows both completed work AND total scope on the same chart — when scope increases (new stories added), the scope line moves up, making scope changes visible; a burndown only shows remaining work, which can hide scope increases (if 10 points are completed but 10 are added, the burndown appears flat, masking both productivity and scope growth)
options.C: Burnup charts are more accurate
options.D: Burnup charts show individual performance

questions.correct_text: A burnup chart shows both completed work AND total scope on the same chart — when scope increases (new stories added), the scope line moves up, making scope changes visible; a burndown only shows remaining work, which can hide scope increases (if 10 points are completed but 10 are added, the burndown appears flat, masking both productivity and scope growth)
questions.explanation: Burndown: single line showing remaining work (descending). When scope changes, the remaining work line adjusts, but you cannot distinguish between "we completed work" and "scope was added." Burnup: two lines — completed work (ascending) and total scope (ascending when scope grows). This visual separation makes scope changes transparent: if the scope line jumps up, everyone sees that new work was added. This is critical for communicating with stakeholders about delivery forecast impacts.

questions.stem: A team commits to 40 story points in sprint planning. Mid-sprint, the PO discovers that a critical production bug must be fixed. The bug is estimated at 8 points. What should happen?

options.A: Add the bug and deliver 48 points
options.B: The PO and team negotiate scope — adding 8 points of unplanned work requires removing approximately 8 points of planned work to maintain a sustainable sprint commitment; the PO decides which planned stories to defer based on relative priority, ensuring the sprint goal remains achievable
options.C: Defer the bug to the next sprint
options.D: Create a separate "hot-fix sprint"

questions.correct_text: The PO and team negotiate scope — adding 8 points of unplanned work requires removing approximately 8 points of planned work to maintain a sustainable sprint commitment; the PO decides which planned stories to defer based on relative priority, ensuring the sprint goal remains achievable
questions.explanation: Sprint capacity is finite. Adding work without removing work leads to overcommitment, quality compromises, and burnout. The negotiation follows: (1) PO assesses bug priority vs. planned stories; (2) if the bug is higher priority, identify stories of equivalent effort to defer; (3) team confirms the adjusted sprint backlog is feasible; (4) sprint goal may need adjustment. Option A overloads the team. Option C risks a critical production issue. Option D disrupts sprint cadence.

questions.stem: A team uses Affinity Estimation to size a large backlog of 80 stories quickly. How does this technique work?

options.A: Each story is estimated individually using planning poker
options.B: The team silently sorts all stories into relative size groups (XS, S, M, L, XL) by comparing them against each other — no discussion during the initial sort; disagreements are resolved by brief discussion only on stories where team members significantly disagree on placement; this processes large backlogs in 30-60 minutes versus hours with planning poker
options.C: Stories are estimated by a single expert
options.D: Estimation is skipped for large backlogs

questions.correct_text: The team silently sorts all stories into relative size groups (XS, S, M, L, XL) by comparing them against each other — no discussion during the initial sort; disagreements are resolved by brief discussion only on stories where team members significantly disagree on placement; this processes large backlogs in 30-60 minutes versus hours with planning poker
questions.explanation: Affinity Estimation (Steve Boehmke): (1) spread all stories on a table or wall; (2) team members silently move stories into relative size groups; (3) any member can move a story they disagree with; (4) when movement stops, discuss only stories that were moved multiple times; (5) assign point values to size groups. Speed advantage: 80 stories can be sized in 30-60 minutes because most stories are non-controversial and the team focuses discussion only on disagreements.

questions.stem: A team's sprint burndown shows a flat line for the first 3 days, then a steep drop on day 4. This pattern repeats every sprint. What does it indicate?

options.A: The team is very efficient at the end of sprints
options.B: Stories are too large — work is not being broken into tasks that can be completed incrementally; the flat period represents "in progress" work that shows no completion until entire stories are finished; the team should break stories into smaller tasks (ideally completable in 1 day or less) for earlier progress visibility
options.C: The burndown chart is inaccurate
options.D: The team works best under pressure

questions.correct_text: Stories are too large — work is not being broken into tasks that can be completed incrementally; the flat period represents "in progress" work that shows no completion until entire stories are finished; the team should break stories into smaller tasks (ideally completable in 1 day or less) for earlier progress visibility
questions.explanation: The "cliff" burndown pattern (flat then steep drop) indicates large work items. Nothing shows as "done" until a big story completes all at once. This masks progress during the flat period and prevents early detection of blockers. Solutions: (1) break stories into tasks completable in 4-8 hours; (2) use "done" at the task level for daily burndown updates; (3) apply the "thin vertical slice" principle — deliver complete thin slices rather than building thick horizontal layers.

questions.stem: The PO wants to create a release plan for the next 4 quarters. The team has limited historical data (only 3 sprints). How should they approach this long-term forecast?

options.A: Refuse — Agile teams do not plan beyond the next sprint
options.B: Use the available velocity data with wide confidence intervals — acknowledge high uncertainty by providing a range (optimistic/pessimistic/most likely) rather than a single date; commit to re-forecasting after each sprint as more velocity data becomes available, narrowing the confidence interval over time (the cone of uncertainty)
options.C: Use the team's initial estimates as exact forecasts
options.D: Base the plan on management's desired dates and work backwards

questions.correct_text: Use the available velocity data with wide confidence intervals — acknowledge high uncertainty by providing a range (optimistic/pessimistic/most likely) rather than a single date; commit to re-forecasting after each sprint as more velocity data becomes available, narrowing the confidence interval over time (the cone of uncertainty)
questions.explanation: Agile teams absolutely do long-term planning — they just acknowledge uncertainty honestly. With only 3 data points, the confidence interval is wide. The Cone of Uncertainty (Barry Boehm) shows that early estimates can be off by 4x. Responsible approach: provide a range using best/worst/average velocity, commit to re-forecasting as data accumulates, and narrow the range over time. After 8-10 sprints, velocity stabilises and forecasts become reliable. Option A misrepresents Agile. Option C ignores uncertainty. Option D is wishful thinking.

questions.stem:
A team uses a Kanban board with columns: Backlog → Analysis → Development → Testing → Done. The Testing column has a WIP limit of 2, but currently has 4 items stuck there because the tester is on sick leave.

What should the team do?

options.A: Increase the WIP limit to 4 temporarily
options.B: Team members should swarm on testing to unblock the bottleneck — WIP limits exist to expose flow problems and trigger the team to resolve them collectively; cross-functional team members should help test, even if testing is not their primary skill, rather than continuing to push more work into Development which would worsen the downstream bottleneck
options.C: Wait for the tester to return
options.D: Move items to Done without testing

questions.correct_text: Team members should swarm on testing to unblock the bottleneck — WIP limits exist to expose flow problems and trigger the team to resolve them collectively; cross-functional team members should help test, even if testing is not their primary skill, rather than continuing to push more work into Development which would worsen the downstream bottleneck
questions.explanation: WIP limits are designed to expose exactly this kind of bottleneck. When a WIP limit is breached, the correct Kanban response is "stop starting, start finishing" — the team stops pulling new work into earlier stages and helps clear the bottleneck. Cross-functional team members helping with testing embodies the Agile principle that the team collectively owns quality. Option A defeats the purpose of WIP limits. Option C delays the entire flow. Option D compromises quality.

questions.stem: A team uses T-shirt sizing (XS, S, M, L, XL) for initial estimation during roadmap planning. They later convert to story points for sprint-level planning. What is the advantage of this two-stage approach?

options.A: T-shirt sizes are more accurate than story points
options.B: T-shirt sizing enables rapid, rough estimation for roadmap-level decisions without the precision overhead of story points — it prevents analysis paralysis during strategic planning while preserving detailed estimation for sprint-level commitment; the coarse-to-fine progression matches the level of uncertainty at each planning horizon
options.C: T-shirt sizes are required by Agile methodology
options.D: Story points should never be used

questions.correct_text: T-shirt sizing enables rapid, rough estimation for roadmap-level decisions without the precision overhead of story points — it prevents analysis paralysis during strategic planning while preserving detailed estimation for sprint-level commitment; the coarse-to-fine progression matches the level of uncertainty at each planning horizon
questions.explanation: Two-stage estimation aligns precision with planning horizon. At the roadmap level, knowing whether a feature is "Small" or "XL" is sufficient for sequencing and resource discussions — investing time in precise story point estimates for work 6 months away is wasteful (estimates will change). At the sprint level, story points provide the precision needed for sprint commitment and capacity planning. This applies the "last responsible moment" principle to estimation effort.

questions.stem: A team uses a cumulative flow diagram (CFD) and observes that the total width of all "in-progress" bands is approximately 30 items, while their throughput is 10 items per week. Using Little's Law, what is their average lead time?

options.A: 10 weeks
options.B: 3 weeks — Little's Law states Lead Time = WIP / Throughput = 30/10 = 3 weeks; to reduce lead time, the team can either reduce WIP (through stricter WIP limits) or increase throughput (through efficiency improvements, bottleneck removal)
options.C: 30 weeks
options.D: 0.33 weeks

questions.correct_text: 3 weeks — Little's Law states Lead Time = WIP / Throughput = 30/10 = 3 weeks; to reduce lead time, the team can either reduce WIP (through stricter WIP limits) or increase throughput (through efficiency improvements, bottleneck removal)
questions.explanation: Little's Law: L = λW, or more practically, Lead Time = WIP / Throughput. WIP = 30 items. Throughput = 10 items/week. Lead Time = 30/10 = 3 weeks. To halve lead time to 1.5 weeks: either reduce WIP to 15 items (same throughput) or increase throughput to 20 items/week (same WIP). In practice, reducing WIP is usually easier and also improves quality through reduced context switching.

questions.stem:
A release train is planning a Program Increment (PI) in SAFe. During PI Planning, the team identifies that their planned capacity is 400 story points but the features requested by the Product Manager total 550 points.

What should happen during PI Planning?

options.A: Commit to all 550 points and work overtime
options.B: The team and Product Manager negotiate scope using the 80% capacity allocation guideline — SAFe recommends teams plan to only 80% of capacity (320 points) to create a buffer for unplanned work and innovation; the remaining features are prioritised, and lower-priority items are moved to the PI Planning Board's "uncommitted objectives" or deferred to the next PI
options.C: Reject all features and re-plan
options.D: Add more teams to the ART

questions.correct_text: The team and Product Manager negotiate scope using the 80% capacity allocation guideline — SAFe recommends teams plan to only 80% of capacity (320 points) to create a buffer for unplanned work and innovation; the remaining features are prioritised, and lower-priority items are moved to the PI Planning Board's "uncommitted objectives" or deferred to the next PI
questions.explanation: SAFe PI Planning explicitly addresses capacity-demand mismatch. Teams plan to approximately 80% of capacity to create a buffer for: (1) unplanned work that emerges mid-PI; (2) risk responses; (3) innovation time. With 400 points capacity, plan 320 points of committed objectives. Remaining features become "uncommitted objectives" (stretch goals) or defer to next PI. The Product Manager prioritises which features make the 320-point cut. This creates realistic plans with built-in resilience.

questions.stem:
A team's cycle time has increased from 5 days to 12 days over the past month. The SM uses the Five Whys technique. The analysis reveals: Long cycle time → items blocked waiting for API team → API team backlogged → API team supports 8 product teams simultaneously → no prioritisation mechanism exists for shared service requests.

What is the root cause, and what is the systemic fix?

options.A: The API team needs more developers
options.B: Root cause: absence of a prioritisation mechanism for shared service requests — the systemic fix is implementing a transparent queue with intake criteria, SLAs, and prioritisation based on business value (WSJF or cost of delay), combined with exploring architectural options to reduce API team dependency (self-service APIs, team topologies restructuring)
options.C: The product team should build their own API
options.D: Escalate to management for faster API team response

questions.correct_text: Root cause: absence of a prioritisation mechanism for shared service requests — the systemic fix is implementing a transparent queue with intake criteria, SLAs, and prioritisation based on business value (WSJF or cost of delay), combined with exploring architectural options to reduce API team dependency (self-service APIs, team topologies restructuring)
questions.explanation: Five Whys reveals the systemic root cause: not the API team's capacity (symptom) but the absence of demand management for shared services. Without prioritisation, 8 teams compete for the same resource with no rational allocation. Fix: (1) implement visible prioritisation (WSJF for the API team's backlog); (2) establish SLAs; (3) longer-term: reduce dependency through self-service APIs, team restructuring (Team Topologies pattern: convert the API team from a "complicated subsystem team" to a "platform team" providing self-service capabilities).

questions.stem:
A team uses a Fishbone (Ishikawa) diagram to analyse why their release quality has declined. They categorise causes under the 6 M's: Manpower, Methods, Machines, Materials, Measurements, and Mother Nature (Environment).

Under which category would "insufficient automated test coverage" MOST appropriately fall?

options.A: Manpower — not enough testers
options.B: Methods — automated test coverage is a process/methodology issue; the team's testing methods and practices have not scaled with the codebase, resulting in insufficient coverage; this is distinct from a people problem (Manpower) or a tooling problem (Machines)
options.C: Machines — testing tools are inadequate
options.D: Measurements — test coverage metrics are wrong

questions.correct_text: Methods — automated test coverage is a process/methodology issue; the team's testing methods and practices have not scaled with the codebase, resulting in insufficient coverage; this is distinct from a people problem (Manpower) or a tooling problem (Machines)
questions.explanation: The 6 M's categorise root causes. "Insufficient automated test coverage" is a process/method gap — the team has not established or maintained adequate testing practices. It is not a people shortage (Manpower), a tool limitation (Machines — they have tools but are not using them fully), or a measurement error (Measurements). Correctly categorising the cause directs the remedy: investing in testing practices, TDD adoption, and coverage standards rather than hiring more testers or buying more tools.

questions.stem:
A project has identified 15 risks. A Pareto analysis of past project failures shows that 3 risk categories — integration failures (35%), requirements misunderstandings (30%), and resource unavailability (15%) — account for 80% of project failures.

What should the team prioritise?

options.A: Address all 15 risks equally
options.B: Focus mitigation efforts on integration failures and requirements misunderstandings first — Pareto's 80/20 principle says that ~20% of risk categories cause ~80% of failures; the team should develop specific mitigation strategies for these top categories (CI/CD for integration, Three Amigos for requirements) while monitoring lower-probability risks
options.C: Ignore risks below 15%
options.D: Create a risk register but take no action

questions.correct_text: Focus mitigation efforts on integration failures and requirements misunderstandings first — Pareto's 80/20 principle says that ~20% of risk categories cause ~80% of failures; the team should develop specific mitigation strategies for these top categories (CI/CD for integration, Three Amigos for requirements) while monitoring lower-probability risks
questions.explanation: Pareto analysis (Vilfredo Pareto, Joseph Juran) identifies the vital few causes that produce the majority of effects. Here, 2 of potentially many risk categories account for 65% of failures. Mitigation strategies: (1) Integration failures → CI/CD, automated integration tests, feature flags, incremental integration; (2) Requirements misunderstandings → Three Amigos, Specification by Example, user story mapping, regular customer demos. Option A spreads effort too thin. Option C ignores meaningful risks. Option D documents without action.

questions.stem: A team conducts a pre-mortem exercise before starting a critical project. How does a pre-mortem work, and what is its advantage over traditional risk identification?

options.A: Review risks after project failure
options.B: The team imagines that the project has already failed and works backwards to identify what went wrong — "It is 6 months from now and this project has failed spectacularly. Why?" — this prospective hindsight technique overcomes optimism bias by making failure psychologically real, causing team members to surface risks they would normally suppress to avoid appearing negative
options.C: Review past project failures
options.D: A risk brainstorming session

questions.correct_text: The team imagines that the project has already failed and works backwards to identify what went wrong — "It is 6 months from now and this project has failed spectacularly. Why?" — this prospective hindsight technique overcomes optimism bias by making failure psychologically real, causing team members to surface risks they would normally suppress to avoid appearing negative
questions.explanation: Gary Klein's pre-mortem technique uses "prospective hindsight" — imagining that a future event has already occurred increases the ability to identify reasons by 30% (research by Mitchell et al.). Traditional risk identification asks "what could go wrong?" which triggers optimism bias. Pre-mortems ask "what DID go wrong?" which triggers loss aversion and critical thinking. Team members feel safer surfacing risks because they are explaining a hypothetical past failure rather than being "negative" about the plan. Output: a richer, more honest risk register.

questions.stem: A team's risk burndown chart shows that total risk exposure (probability × impact) has increased over the last 3 sprints despite active risk mitigation. What should the team investigate?

options.A: The risk burndown chart is unreliable
options.B: New risks are being identified faster than existing risks are being mitigated — the team should check: (1) are mitigated risks being properly closed? (2) are new risks emerging from scope changes, technical discoveries, or external factors? (3) is the team's risk identification improving (which is positive even if the chart looks worse)?
options.C: Stop identifying new risks
options.D: Increase the mitigation budget

questions.correct_text: New risks are being identified faster than existing risks are being mitigated — the team should check: (1) are mitigated risks being properly closed? (2) are new risks emerging from scope changes, technical discoveries, or external factors? (3) is the team's risk identification improving (which is positive even if the chart looks worse)?
questions.explanation: A rising risk burndown can mean several things: new risks emerging (scope creep, technical surprises), existing mitigations being ineffective, or improved risk identification surfacing previously hidden risks (actually a positive sign). The team should separate these causes: chart mitigation effectiveness separately from new risk identification. If mitigations are effective but new risks keep appearing, the root cause may be scope instability or insufficient upfront analysis. If mitigations are ineffective, the strategies need revision. Option C suppresses valuable information. Option D addresses budget without diagnosis.

questions.stem: A team member identifies an impediment: "Our CI/CD pipeline takes 45 minutes to run, so developers batch commits and only integrate 2-3 times per day instead of continuously." Using the Theory of Constraints, what should the team do?

options.A: Accept the pipeline duration as a constraint
options.B: The CI/CD pipeline is the system's constraint (bottleneck) — apply the Theory of Constraints' 5 Focusing Steps: (1) Identify the constraint (45-minute pipeline); (2) Exploit it (optimise without investment — parallelise tests, eliminate redundant checks); (3) Subordinate other processes (developers work on smaller commits compatible with the pipeline); (4) Elevate (invest in faster infrastructure, split the pipeline); (5) Repeat if a new constraint emerges
options.C: Remove CI/CD and do manual testing
options.D: Add a second pipeline

questions.correct_text: The CI/CD pipeline is the system's constraint (bottleneck) — apply the Theory of Constraints' 5 Focusing Steps: (1) Identify the constraint (45-minute pipeline); (2) Exploit it (optimise without investment — parallelise tests, eliminate redundant checks); (3) Subordinate other processes (developers work on smaller commits compatible with the pipeline); (4) Elevate (invest in faster infrastructure, split the pipeline); (5) Repeat if a new constraint emerges
questions.explanation: Eliyahu Goldratt's Theory of Constraints identifies that a system's output is limited by its weakest link. The 5 Focusing Steps systematically address constraints: Identify (the 45-min pipeline), Exploit (parallelise test suites, cache dependencies, remove unnecessary steps — often reduces time 50-70% without investment), Subordinate (adapt work habits to the constraint), Elevate (invest in faster infrastructure if exploit is insufficient), Repeat (find the next constraint). Option D (second pipeline) is an Elevate step that should come after Exploit.

questions.stem: A product in production experiences intermittent failures that the team cannot reproduce consistently. Traditional debugging has not identified the cause. Which problem-detection technique is MOST appropriate?

options.A: Five Whys — ask why 5 times
options.B: Variance analysis combined with systematic data collection — compare environments, configurations, and conditions between failing and non-failing instances to identify the differentiating variable; use A/B environment comparisons, log correlation, and controlled experiments to isolate the cause
options.C: Fishbone diagram
options.D: Hold a retrospective to discuss the issue

questions.correct_text: Variance analysis combined with systematic data collection — compare environments, configurations, and conditions between failing and non-failing instances to identify the differentiating variable; use A/B environment comparisons, log correlation, and controlled experiments to isolate the cause
questions.explanation: Intermittent, non-reproducible failures require systematic variance analysis rather than causal reasoning tools (Five Whys, Fishbone) which work best when the cause-effect chain is traceable. Variance analysis: (1) collect data on all failure instances (time, environment, load, configuration); (2) compare with non-failure instances; (3) identify differentiating variables; (4) form hypotheses; (5) test through controlled experiments. This is the scientific method applied to debugging. Tools: log correlation, APM (Application Performance Monitoring), chaos engineering principles.

questions.stem:
A team uses a "Impediment Board" alongside their Kanban board. Impediments are categorised as: Team-Level (resolvable by the team), Organisation-Level (requires SM/management intervention), and External (outside the organisation). Currently, 3 are Team-Level, 5 are Organisation-Level, and 2 are External.

What does this distribution indicate?

options.A: The team is doing well — most impediments are escalated
options.B: The high proportion of Organisation-Level impediments (50%) suggests systemic organisational barriers that individual teams cannot resolve — the SM should aggregate these with other teams' organisational impediments and present them to leadership as systemic issues requiring structural change, not just tactical fixes
options.C: External impediments are the biggest concern
options.D: The board has too many items

questions.correct_text: The high proportion of Organisation-Level impediments (50%) suggests systemic organisational barriers that individual teams cannot resolve — the SM should aggregate these with other teams' organisational impediments and present them to leadership as systemic issues requiring structural change, not just tactical fixes
questions.explanation: Impediment distribution tells a story. Team-Level impediments are healthy — teams should be able to resolve most issues themselves. A high Organisation-Level proportion signals that the team is blocked by systemic issues (policies, shared services, tooling, organisational structure) that require leadership intervention. Aggregating across teams amplifies the signal: if 5 teams each have 5 organisational impediments, leadership faces 25 impediments that represent systemic dysfunction, not isolated incidents.

questions.stem:
A Scrum Master notices a recurring pattern: the team consistently under-delivers in the first sprint of each quarter because key team members are pulled into quarterly business reviews. This has happened 4 quarters in a row.

Why has the team NOT resolved this, and what should the SM do?

options.A: Accept it as an organisational reality
options.B: This is a predictable, recurring impediment that should be planned for, not suffered through — the SM should proactively reduce sprint capacity in Q1 sprints to account for business review commitments, negotiate with management to stagger reviews or limit participation, and raise it as a systemic impediment that affects sustainable pace
options.C: Remove team members from business reviews
options.D: Extend Q1 sprints to 3 weeks

questions.correct_text: This is a predictable, recurring impediment that should be planned for, not suffered through — the SM should proactively reduce sprint capacity in Q1 sprints to account for business review commitments, negotiate with management to stagger reviews or limit participation, and raise it as a systemic impediment that affects sustainable pace
questions.explanation: A predictable, recurring impediment that repeats 4 times without resolution indicates failure to apply retrospective insights. The SM should: (1) proactively adjust sprint capacity for Q1 sprints (transparency); (2) negotiate with management — perhaps not all team members need to attend all reviews; (3) raise as a systemic impediment affecting Agile Principle 8 (sustainable pace). The fact that it recurs unchanged for 4 quarters suggests either retrospectives are not addressing it or action items are not being followed through.

questions.stem:
During a sprint, the team discovers that a third-party API they depend on will be deprecated in 30 days. Migrating to the replacement API is estimated at 21 story points. The current sprint has 8 points of remaining capacity.

What is the BEST approach?

options.A: Abandon the current sprint and focus on migration
options.B: Complete the current sprint's committed work, then use the remaining 8 points for a migration spike to assess the actual scope and risks — add the full migration as a high-priority item for the next sprint planning, with the spike's findings informing the estimate and approach; escalate to the PO for priority trade-off decisions across the upcoming sprints
options.C: Ignore the deprecation until the API stops working
options.D: Assign a single developer to handle migration in parallel

questions.correct_text: Complete the current sprint's committed work, then use the remaining 8 points for a migration spike to assess the actual scope and risks — add the full migration as a high-priority item for the next sprint planning, with the spike's findings informing the estimate and approach; escalate to the PO for priority trade-off decisions across the upcoming sprints
questions.explanation: This requires balancing sprint commitment with emerging risk. The spike approach: use remaining sprint capacity to investigate the migration scope (read documentation, identify breaking changes, assess test impact). This converts unknown risk into known risk without abandoning sprint commitments. For the next sprint, the PO makes an informed prioritisation decision based on spike findings. 30 days provides time for a planned response rather than a crisis reaction. Option A overreacts. Option C is reckless. Option D under-resources a significant effort.

questions.stem:
A team uses Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA) to assess risks. For a critical payment processing feature, they identify a failure mode: "Payment processed but confirmation email not sent." They rate: Severity = 8 (high impact on customer trust), Occurrence = 3 (unlikely due to reliable email service), Detection = 7 (difficult to detect because the payment succeeds).

Calculate the Risk Priority Number (RPN) and determine the priority.

options.A: RPN = 18 (low priority)
options.B: RPN = 168 (moderate-high priority) — RPN = Severity × Occurrence × Detection = 8 × 3 × 7 = 168; despite low occurrence, the combination of high severity and poor detectability makes this a significant risk requiring mitigation (e.g., adding email delivery confirmation monitoring)
options.C: RPN = 56 (moderate priority)
options.D: RPN = 336 (critical priority)

questions.correct_text: RPN = 168 (moderate-high priority) — RPN = Severity × Occurrence × Detection = 8 × 3 × 7 = 168; despite low occurrence, the combination of high severity and poor detectability makes this a significant risk requiring mitigation (e.g., adding email delivery confirmation monitoring)
questions.explanation: FMEA's RPN = S × O × D. Here: 8 × 3 × 7 = 168. RPN scale typically ranges from 1-1000 (each factor 1-10). 168 indicates moderate-high risk warranting attention. The insight: even with low occurrence, the poor detectability (7/10) means failures will go unnoticed, eroding customer trust silently. Mitigation: email delivery monitoring, bounce detection, and customer-facing "confirmation pending" status. RPN helps prioritise across multiple failure modes — higher RPN = address first.

questions.stem: A team resolves impediments reactively — they wait until problems block progress before addressing them. The SM wants to shift to proactive problem detection. Which THREE practices would enable this?

options.A: More daily standups
options.B: (1) Leading indicators monitoring (pull request queue depth, WIP trends, cycle time trends) to detect flow degradation before it causes blocks; (2) regular tech debt reviews to identify accumulating risks; (3) dependency mapping before each sprint to identify potential blocks before they occur — these practices detect problems while they are still manageable rather than after they become critical
options.C: Longer retrospectives
options.D: Hiring a project manager

questions.correct_text: (1) Leading indicators monitoring (pull request queue depth, WIP trends, cycle time trends) to detect flow degradation before it causes blocks; (2) regular tech debt reviews to identify accumulating risks; (3) dependency mapping before each sprint to identify potential blocks before they occur — these practices detect problems while they are still manageable rather than after they become critical
questions.explanation: Proactive problem detection requires leading indicators (predict problems) rather than lagging indicators (report problems after they occur). Leading indicators: growing PR queue → future code review bottleneck. Rising WIP → future lead time increase. Increasing cycle time trend → emerging flow problem. Tech debt reviews surface risks before they become emergencies. Dependency mapping identifies potential blocks before the sprint starts. These create early warning systems.

questions.stem:
A team performs Value Stream Mapping (VSM) on their software delivery process. They identify: coding (2 days), code review wait (3 days), code review (0.5 days), testing wait (2 days), testing (1 day), deployment wait (4 days), deployment (0.5 days). Total lead time = 13 days. Total value-adding time = 4 days.

What is the process efficiency, and which improvement should be prioritised?

options.A: 31%; reduce coding time
options.B: Process efficiency = 4/13 = 30.8%; the deployment wait (4 days) is the largest single waste and should be prioritised — implementing automated deployment pipelines and reducing approval bureaucracy could eliminate most of this wait, reducing lead time by up to 30%
options.C: 100%; process is efficient
options.D: 50%; address testing

questions.correct_text: Process efficiency = 4/13 = 30.8%; the deployment wait (4 days) is the largest single waste and should be prioritised — implementing automated deployment pipelines and reducing approval bureaucracy could eliminate most of this wait, reducing lead time by up to 30%
questions.explanation: VSM process efficiency = value-adding time / total lead time = 4/13 = 30.8%. Wait times: code review wait (3d) + testing wait (2d) + deployment wait (4d) = 9 days of waste out of 13 total. The deployment wait (4 days) is the single largest waste item. Automating deployments (CI/CD) and replacing manual approval with automated compliance checks can reduce this from 4 days to minutes. This is a Theory of Constraints application: the deployment pipeline is the bottleneck.

questions.stem:
A team uses the PDSA (Plan-Do-Study-Act) cycle for process improvement. They hypothesise that reducing their WIP limit from 5 to 3 will decrease cycle time. After running the experiment for 2 sprints, cycle time dropped from 8 days to 5 days, but the team reports feeling stressed by the lower WIP limit.

What should the team do in the "Act" phase?

options.A: Permanently adopt WIP limit of 3
options.B: Evaluate the trade-off: the cycle time improvement is significant (37.5% reduction), but team stress may indicate sustainability concerns — in the Act phase, the team should either standardise the change with stress-mitigation strategies (clearer priorities, reduced interruptions) or modify to WIP limit of 4 as a compromise, then run another PDSA cycle to validate
options.C: Revert to WIP limit of 5
options.D: Stop using WIP limits entirely

questions.correct_text: Evaluate the trade-off: the cycle time improvement is significant (37.5% reduction), but team stress may indicate sustainability concerns — in the Act phase, the team should either standardise the change with stress-mitigation strategies (clearer priorities, reduced interruptions) or modify to WIP limit of 4 as a compromise, then run another PDSA cycle to validate
questions.explanation: Deming's PDSA cycle: Plan (hypothesis), Do (experiment), Study (analyse results), Act (standardise, modify, or abandon). The experiment produced conflicting results: positive outcome (faster cycle time) with negative side effect (stress). The Act phase should not blindly standardise or abandon. Options: (1) Standardise WIP 3 + address stress (perhaps stress comes from unclear priorities, not the WIP limit itself); (2) Compromise at WIP 4 and run another PDSA cycle; (3) Investigate whether stress decreases as the team adapts. Continuous improvement means iterating, not making permanent decisions from single experiments.

questions.stem: An Agile coach introduces the concept of "Gemba walks" to the organisation's leadership. What is a Gemba walk, and how does it apply to Agile?

options.A: A team-building exercise
options.B: Gemba (Japanese for "the real place") walk involves leaders going to where the work happens — the team room, the Kanban board, the standup — to observe processes firsthand, ask questions, and understand impediments rather than relying on status reports; in Agile, this means leadership participates in events, reads boards, and engages with teams directly to understand reality
options.C: A factory floor inspection technique not applicable to software
options.D: A competitive analysis exercise

questions.correct_text: Gemba (Japanese for "the real place") walk involves leaders going to where the work happens — the team room, the Kanban board, the standup — to observe processes firsthand, ask questions, and understand impediments rather than relying on status reports; in Agile, this means leadership participates in events, reads boards, and engages with teams directly to understand reality
questions.explanation: Taiichi Ohno's Gemba principle: go and see for yourself. In Lean manufacturing, managers walk the production floor. In Agile software development: leaders visit team rooms, attend sprint reviews, read Kanban boards, and observe standups — not to micromanage but to understand reality. Benefits: (1) leaders see actual impediments rather than filtered status reports; (2) teams see leadership engagement; (3) systemic patterns across teams become visible to leaders who visit multiple teams. Gemba walks should be regular, respectful, and focused on understanding, not auditing.

questions.stem:
A team identifies that 30% of their sprint capacity is consumed by unplanned work (production bugs, support requests). They want to improve but disagree on whether to (A) dedicate a rotating "firefighter" team member who handles all unplanned work, or (B) reduce the planned sprint commitment by 30% to absorb unplanned work.

Which approach is BETTER for continuous improvement, and why?

options.A: Approach A — isolates disruption to one person
options.B: Approach B — reducing planned commitment is simpler
options.C: Approach A is tactically better (shields the team), but the continuous improvement approach requires BOTH: use the firefighter pattern to stabilise the situation AND investigate the root causes of the unplanned work to reduce it over time — the 30% unplanned work rate is the symptom, not the problem; the team should track, categorise, and eliminate the sources
options.D: Neither approach addresses the problem

questions.correct_text: Approach A is tactically better (shields the team), but the continuous improvement approach requires BOTH: use the firefighter pattern to stabilise the situation AND investigate the root causes of the unplanned work to reduce it over time — the 30% unplanned work rate is the symptom, not the problem; the team should track, categorise, and eliminate the sources
questions.explanation: Both approaches manage unplanned work but neither reduces it. Continuous improvement demands root cause analysis: Why is 30% of capacity consumed by unplanned work? Common causes: insufficient testing (bugs escaping to production), technical debt (fragile systems), unclear requirements (rework), and poor monitoring (delayed detection). The firefighter pattern provides short-term stability while the team invests in: (1) categorising unplanned work; (2) applying Pareto to find the top causes; (3) addressing root causes (better testing, tech debt reduction, monitoring). The goal: reduce unplanned work from 30% to 10% or less over several sprints.

questions.stem:
A team runs a retrospective and identifies that their biggest time sink is manual regression testing before each release (3 full days). The team wants to implement automated testing but estimates it will take 2 sprints of dedicated effort.

Using Lean concepts, how should the team justify this investment?

options.A: Automated testing is an industry standard
options.B: Frame it as "investment in reducing the cost of delay" — 3 days of manual testing per sprint represents waste (over-processing) and bottleneck time; over 10 sprints, that is 30 days of manual work; a 2-sprint investment that eliminates 80% of this waste pays back within 3 sprints and creates compound returns through faster feedback, higher quality, and more frequent releases
options.C: The team does not need to justify improvements
options.D: Automated testing should be deferred until a quiet period

questions.correct_text: Frame it as "investment in reducing the cost of delay" — 3 days of manual testing per sprint represents waste (over-processing) and bottleneck time; over 10 sprints, that is 30 days of manual work; a 2-sprint investment that eliminates 80% of this waste pays back within 3 sprints and creates compound returns through faster feedback, higher quality, and more frequent releases
questions.explanation: Lean's economic lens: every improvement must be framed in terms of value. Manual regression testing is a recurring waste (muda) — non-value-adding time that delays delivery. Calculate ROI: 3 days/sprint × estimated 80% automation = 2.4 days saved/sprint. Investment: 2 sprints of dedicated work ≈ 4 weeks. Payback: 2.4 days/sprint savings means the investment pays back in ~7 sprints. Beyond ROI: automated tests provide faster feedback (shift-left quality), enable continuous deployment, and increase team confidence in refactoring. Option D's "quiet period" never arrives in active development.

questions.stem: A team uses the "Spotify Health Check" model for team self-assessment. What does this model measure, and how is it used for continuous improvement?

options.A: Individual developer productivity
options.B: The Health Check assesses team health across dimensions like teamwork, mission clarity, process suitability, learning, speed, quality, and fun — each dimension is rated green/yellow/red by team members; the visual dashboard highlights areas of strength and areas needing attention, providing a structured input for retrospective discussions and long-term trend tracking
options.C: Sprint velocity trends
options.D: Customer satisfaction scores

questions.correct_text: The Health Check assesses team health across dimensions like teamwork, mission clarity, process suitability, learning, speed, quality, and fun — each dimension is rated green/yellow/red by team members; the visual dashboard highlights areas of strength and areas needing attention, providing a structured input for retrospective discussions and long-term trend tracking
questions.explanation: Spotify's Squad Health Check model is a team-level self-assessment across ~10 dimensions. Team members rate each dimension using traffic lights (green/yellow/red) and a trend arrow (improving/declining). Dimensions typically include: delivering value, speed, mission, fun, learning, support, pawns or players, process, releasing ease, and teamwork. The model's power: (1) visualises team health holistically (not just output); (2) tracks trends across sprints; (3) identifies systemic patterns when used across multiple teams; (4) provides concrete retrospective focus areas.

questions.stem:
A team's retrospective identifies that code reviews are a bottleneck — PRs wait an average of 2 days for review. The team considers three improvements: (1) assign a daily "review champion," (2) limit PR size to 200 lines, (3) use pair programming instead.

Which combination would create the MOST effective improvement?

options.A: Implement all three simultaneously
options.B: Start with options 1 and 2 together — the review champion ensures daily attention (reducing wait time) while small PRs ensure reviews are quick and thorough (reducing review duration); measure the impact over 2-3 sprints before deciding whether pair programming (option 3) would add further value or is unnecessary given the improvements from 1 and 2
options.C: Only implement option 3 — it eliminates reviews entirely
options.D: Accept code review delays as unavoidable

questions.correct_text: Start with options 1 and 2 together — the review champion ensures daily attention (reducing wait time) while small PRs ensure reviews are quick and thorough (reducing review duration); measure the impact over 2-3 sprints before deciding whether pair programming (option 3) would add further value or is unnecessary given the improvements from 1 and 2
questions.explanation: Continuous improvement should be incremental and measurable. Options 1 and 2 are lightweight, complementary changes: daily review champion addresses the "when" (reviews happen daily, reducing wait time from 2 days to <1 day), and PR size limits address the "how long" (200-line PRs take 15-20 minutes vs. hours for large PRs). Together they likely solve 80% of the problem with minimal disruption. Pair programming (option 3) is a larger process change that may be unnecessary if 1+2 are sufficient. Implementing all three simultaneously (option A) makes it impossible to determine which change drove improvement.

questions.stem: An organisation wants to implement a Kaizen culture. A manager asks: "What is the difference between Kaizen and Kaikaku?"

options.A: They are the same concept
options.B: Kaizen is continuous, incremental improvement (small steps, ongoing, everyone participates) — Kaikaku is radical, revolutionary change (large steps, infrequent, usually driven by leadership); both are necessary: Kaizen maintains daily improvement momentum while Kaikaku addresses systemic issues that incremental change cannot fix
options.C: Kaizen is Japanese; Kaikaku is Chinese
options.D: Kaikaku replaces Kaizen in mature organisations
