questions.correct_text: Kaizen is continuous, incremental improvement (small steps, ongoing, everyone participates) — Kaikaku is radical, revolutionary change (large steps, infrequent, usually driven by leadership); both are necessary: Kaizen maintains daily improvement momentum while Kaikaku addresses systemic issues that incremental change cannot fix
questions.explanation: Kaizen (改善, "change for better"): continuous, small improvements by everyone at every level. Daily, incremental, grassroots. Examples: tweaking standups, improving code review process, adjusting WIP limits. Kaikaku (改革, "radical change"): infrequent, large-scale transformation driven by leadership. Examples: adopting SAFe across the organisation, restructuring around value streams, replacing the tech stack. Both are part of Lean thinking: Kaizen prevents stagnation between Kaikaku events, and Kaikaku addresses structural issues beyond Kaizen's reach.

questions.stem:
A team tracks their escaped defect rate (bugs found in production) over 12 sprints. The rate has been declining steadily from 8 per sprint to 2 per sprint. In the last sprint, it spiked to 6. The team is alarmed.

Using statistical thinking (control charts), how should the team interpret this spike?

options.A: The quality process is failing — immediate investigation
options.B: Determine whether the spike is a special cause variation (an assignable, specific event) or common cause variation (normal process fluctuation) — plot the data on a control chart with upper and lower control limits; if 6 is within the control limits, it may be normal variation requiring no special action; if it exceeds the upper control limit, investigate the specific cause of the spike
options.C: Ignore the spike — it is random
options.D: Reset the defect tracking baseline

questions.correct_text: Determine whether the spike is a special cause variation (an assignable, specific event) or common cause variation (normal process fluctuation) — plot the data on a control chart with upper and lower control limits; if 6 is within the control limits, it may be normal variation requiring no special action; if it exceeds the upper control limit, investigate the specific cause of the spike
questions.explanation: Walter Shewhart's control charts (adopted by Deming) distinguish between: Common Cause variation (inherent process variation — do not react to individual data points) and Special Cause variation (assignable cause — investigate and address). With data ranging from 2-8 historically, 6 is within the historical range and may be common cause variation. However, if the declining trend created a new baseline (recent sprints: 2-3 average), then 6 may exceed the upper control limit. The team should plot the data, calculate control limits, and decide rationally rather than reacting emotionally. Over-reacting to common cause variation (tampering) can actually destabilise a process.

questions.stem: A team wants to measure their improvement over a quarter. Which combination of metrics provides the MOST comprehensive view of Agile team health?

options.A: Velocity only
options.B: A balanced set: (1) Flow metrics (cycle time, lead time, throughput) for delivery performance; (2) Quality metrics (defect rate, escaped defects, test coverage) for build quality; (3) Team health metrics (engagement scores, retrospective action item completion rate) for sustainability; (4) Value metrics (feature adoption rate, NPS, outcome achievement) for customer impact — no single metric tells the full story
options.C: Story points completed per developer
options.D: Number of retrospective action items generated

questions.correct_text: A balanced set: (1) Flow metrics (cycle time, lead time, throughput) for delivery performance; (2) Quality metrics (defect rate, escaped defects, test coverage) for build quality; (3) Team health metrics (engagement scores, retrospective action item completion rate) for sustainability; (4) Value metrics (feature adoption rate, NPS, outcome achievement) for customer impact — no single metric tells the full story
questions.explanation: Comprehensive team health requires balanced metrics across four dimensions: Flow (are we delivering efficiently?), Quality (are we building well?), Team (are we sustainable and improving?), Value (are we making a difference?). Optimising one at the expense of others creates dysfunction: high velocity with low quality, fast delivery of low-value features, or unsustainable pace that burns out the team. This mirrors the Balanced Scorecard approach (Kaplan & Norton) adapted for Agile teams.

questions.stem:
It is the final question of your PMI-ACP preparation. A team has completed a year of Agile practice. They have high velocity, low defect rates, satisfied stakeholders, and stable team membership. The SM asks: "We are performing well. Do we still need retrospectives?"

What is the definitive Agile answer?

options.A: No — retrospectives are for struggling teams
options.B: Yes, absolutely — Agile Principle 12 states "At regular intervals, the team reflects on how to become more effective, then tunes and adjusts its behavior accordingly"; high-performing teams use retrospectives not to fix problems but to discover new levels of excellence, experiment with innovations, challenge assumptions, and prevent the complacency that leads to gradual decline; the moment a team stops improving, entropy begins
options.C: Retrospectives can be reduced to monthly
options.D: Replace retrospectives with management reviews

questions.correct_text: Yes, absolutely — Agile Principle 12 states "At regular intervals, the team reflects on how to become more effective, then tunes and adjusts its behavior accordingly"; high-performing teams use retrospectives not to fix problems but to discover new levels of excellence, experiment with innovations, challenge assumptions, and prevent the complacency that leads to gradual decline; the moment a team stops improving, entropy begins
questions.explanation: This question addresses the fundamental Agile belief in continuous improvement as a permanent practice, not a remedial one. Agile Principle 12 does not say "reflect when things go wrong" — it says "at regular intervals." High-performing teams derive different value from retrospectives: instead of fixing problems (which are rare), they explore innovations, challenge comfortable patterns, deepen collaboration, and prevent the subtle complacency that causes high-performing teams to gradually regress. Toyota (the inspiration for Lean/Agile) has been practicing continuous improvement for 70+ years and shows no sign of stopping. Retrospectives evolve in format and focus — but never in importance.
